questions.text: Ito cells (hepatic stellate cells) are located in which specific region of the liver? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Space of disse

 

In the Disse space are Ito cells/Hepatic stellate cells. Their origins are mesenchymal.

 

Between the liver sinusoid and the hepatocytes is a region known as the space of Disse, sometimes known as the perisinusoidal space.

 

Significance of Ito cells:

 

Most of the time, ito cells (also known as stellate cells) are dormant. They are a substantial source of growth factors essential for liver homeostasis and regeneration and store the fat-soluble vitamin A in their lipid droplets.

 

Ito cells become active when there is liver damage. They release intralobular matrix components such collagen type III (reticular) fibres and replace injured hepatocytes with collagenous scar tissue. This leads to hepatic fibrosis.

 

Note: A narrow space which separates limiting plate (a sleeve of modified hepatocytes) from the connective tissue of the portal area is known as space of moll.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Space of Moll:

 

  • The Space of Moll is located in the eyelid and is not related to the liver. Specifically, it refers to a part of the eyelid's lymphatic drainage system.
  • It has no relevance to the location of Ito cells.

 

Option C. Sinusoids:

 

  • Sinusoids are the capillary-like vessels in the liver where the exchange of substances occurs between the blood and hepatocytes.
  • While Ito cells are closely related to sinusoids and are found in the perisinusoidal space, they are not located within the sinusoids themselves.

 

Option D. Bile Canaliculi:

 

  • Bile canaliculi are small ducts between hepatocytes that collect bile produced by the hepatocytes.
  • Ito cells are not located in the bile canaliculi. Instead, these canaliculi are lined by hepatocytes that actively secrete bile into them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Space of Disse (perisinusoidal space) is a small space between the sinusoidal endothelial cells and the hepatocytes. Ito cells are located in this space. When there is liver injury, these cells can become activated, transform into myofibroblast-like cells, and contribute to the production of collagen and extracellular matrix, leading to liver fibrosis.

questions.text:
A concerned mother takes her daughter of 14 years age who was complaining of pain in the private parts to a gynecologist. On eliciting history, the girl admits she had consensual sexual intercourse with a neighbor and refuses to get examined. What should the gynecologist do? (AIIMS MAY 2020)

 

  1. Document informed refusal
  2. Do not inform the police
  3. Counsel the mother and daughter
  4. Examine with necessary force
  5. Inform the police
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 5 are true 

 

This situation involves multiple aspects: legal, ethical, and medical considerations are paramount. Here's why each statement is addressed as true or false in this context:

 

1. Document informed refusal: True. It is essential for medical practitioners to document any refusal of examination or treatment, particularly in sensitive cases involving minors. Documentation should include detailed information about what was explained to the patient and the guardian, and their reasons for refusal, to ensure clarity and legal safeguarding.

 

3. Counsel the mother and daughter: True. The role of a gynecologist includes providing medical counseling, especially when it involves minors and sensitive issues such as sexual activity. Counseling should aim to educate about the health implications of the sexual activity, the benefits of medical examination, and the legal aspects considering the age of consent.

 

5. Inform the police: True. According to laws in many jurisdictions, including India, any sexual activity with a minor, regardless of consent, is considered statutory rape. Medical professionals are mandated reporters, which means they are legally obligated to report such cases to law enforcement to ensure the safety of the minor and adhere to legal statutes.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Do not inform the police: False. The gynecologist has a mandatory obligation to report cases of suspected statutory rape, as non-reporting could be considered a failure of duty and legal non-compliance.

 

4. Examine with necessary force: False. It is illegal and unethical to perform a medical examination against a patient's will, especially in the case of a minor. The patient's autonomy must be respected, and no examination should proceed without consent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Examination of a victim of sexual assault should be done only after the consent of the victim. It is the accused who can be examined without consent, not the victim. Whether the victim agrees for examination or not, the police always have to be informed as there is an allegation of crime of rape (as sex even with consent with a girl <18 years of age will be considered rape)

questions.text: Most sensitive test for Carpal tunnel syndrome is:(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Durkan’s test

 

CARPAL TUNNEL SYNDROME

 

  • Carpal tunnel syndrome is the most common type of nerve compression syndrome.
  • It occurs when the median nerve is compressed at the wrist.
  • The median nerve extends from the upper arm to the thumb.
  • At the wrist, it passes through a structure called the carpal tunnel.
  • Excess pressure on the wrist may cause swelling, which can lead to Carpal tunnel syndrome.
  • Tests for Carpal tunnel syndrome:
    • Tinel’s sign: In this test, the physician taps over the median nerve at the wrist to see if it produces a tingling sensation in the fingers.
    • Wrist flexion test (or Phalen test): In this test, the patient rests his or her elbows on a table and allows the wrist to fall forward freely. Individuals with Carpal tunnel syndrome will experience numbness and tingling in the fingers within 60 seconds. The more quickly symptoms appear, the more severe the Carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

 

1. Phalen’s test; 2. Reverse Phalen’s test

 

  • Durkan’s test is performed by manual compression of the Carpal tunnel held for up to 30 seconds and recorded as positive if associated with reproduction of distal paresthesias in the median nerve distribution.

 

 

  • Out of these tests, Tinel sign has the highest specificity and Durkan’s test has the highest sensitivity.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Phalen’s test. This test is 42-85% sensitive and 54-98% specific.

 

Option C. Tinel’s sign. This test has the highest specificity but low sensitivity for carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Option D. Cozen test. This test is sensitive for lateral epicondylitis. Its sensitivity is about 84%.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tinel sign has the highest specificity and Durkan’s test has the highest sensitivity for carpal tunnel syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a treatment option in Guillain Barre syndrome? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Steroids

 

Steroids are not effective in the treatment of Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS) and do not improve outcomes. This has been confirmed by multiple studies and clinical trials, leading to their non-recommendation in GBS management protocols.

 

While steroids have no role in acute GBS treatment, they are used in managing Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP), which is a related condition that requires long-term immunosuppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IVIG (Intravenous Immunoglobulin): IVIG is a widely accepted treatment for GBS, where it is used to modulate the immune response. The typical regimen involves a total dose of 2 g/kg given over 2-5 days. IVIG is believed to neutralize circulating antibodies and reduce inflammation, leading to a decrease in the severity and duration of the disease.

 

Option C. Plasmapheresis: Also known as plasma exchange, plasmapheresis is used in GBS to remove harmful antibodies from the blood. This treatment is particularly useful in severe cases and is often started within the first two weeks of symptom onset for maximum effectiveness.

 

Option D. Ventilator support: Because GBS can lead to paralysis of the muscles used for breathing, ventilator support may be necessary for patients with severe respiratory muscle weakness. This supportive care is crucial in managing life-threatening complications of GBS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Steroids are not recommended for treating Guillain-Barre Syndrome due to their lack of efficacy in this specific condition, while IVIG and plasmapheresis are effective treatments. Supportive care, such as ventilator support, plays a vital role in managing severe cases where respiratory muscles are compromised.

 

Reference - Harrison neurology, Immune mediated neuropathies/GBS/Chap 447/12730

choices.text: Malignant melanoma
Rosai Dorfman disease

questions.text: A woman who had undergone total knee replacement surgery comes with complaints of knee pain with the loosening of implants. The following histopathological slide was obtained which showed foreign body giant cells along with the appearance highlighted in the image below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metallosis

 

The given clinical scenario and image with the said foreign body giant cell point towards a diagnosis of metallosis.

 

Metallosis is an uncommon complication following total joint replacements of high wear joints like hip and knees. It occurs when metallic components in medical implants, specifically joint replacements, abrade against one another. The metal from the prosthesis infiltrates the bone and soft tissue surrounding it resulting in pain or squeaking on weight bearing or loosening of implant. Sometimes it may be asymptomatic with imaging findings (cloud sign or bubble sign). Aspiration reveals dark fluid consisting of metallic debris.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ochronosis: Ochronosis is a metabolic disorder characterized by the deposition of homogentisic acid in connective tissues, leading to pigmentation and arthritis. It is not associated with metallic debris or foreign body giant cells.

 

Option C. Malignant melanoma: Malignant melanoma is a type of skin cancer that would present with different histological findings, such as atypical melanocytes. It does not involve foreign body giant cells or metallic debris.

 

Option D. Rosai-Dorfman disease: This is a rare disorder characterized by massive lymphadenopathy and histiocytosis with distinctive histological features, including the presence of histiocytes that exhibit emperipolesis. It does not involve metallic particles or joint replacements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metallosis is a rare complication of joint replacement surgeries, characterized by the release of metallic debris from implants, leading to a foreign body reaction with the formation of foreign body giant cells and potential loosening of the implant.

choices.text: It has multiple reducing ends
It can be stored at multiple organs
It can provide glucose for about 1 week when needed

questions.text: Glucose is stored in the form of glycogen because? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is compact

 

Glycogen is a multibranched polysaccharide of glucose that serves as a form of energy storage in animals, fungi, and bacteria. It is the main storage form of glucose in the human body as it is compact.

 

In humans, glycogen is made and stored primarily in the cells of the liver and skeletal muscle. Liver glycogen helps to maintain the blood glucose levels in the fasting state. Most of the liver glycogen gets depleted after 18hrs of fasting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It has multiple reducing ends: Glycogen has multiple non-reducing ends, which facilitate rapid mobilization of glucose, not reducing ends.

 

Option C. It can be stored at multiple organs: Glycogen is mainly stored in the liver and skeletal muscles, not in multiple organs.

 

Option D. It can provide glucose for about 1 week when needed: Liver glycogen stores are typically depleted after about 18 hours of fasting, not 1 week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen is stored in a compact form, allowing efficient storage of large amounts of glucose in liver and muscle cells, enabling rapid mobilization of glucose when needed.

choices.text: Start antibiotics and send samples for culture

questions.text: A patient who is intubated had an X-ray done. The radiograph is shown below. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ultrasound guided aspiration

 

Chest radiograph shows Unilateral Left pleural effusion. In the absence of suspicion for transudative effusion, thoracocentesis is indicated in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suction with percussion physiotherapy is recommended in suspected collapse due to mucus plugging etc.

 

Option B. Antibiotics are initiated if suspicion of severe CAP is present.

 

Option C. Chest physiotherapy is given to reduce collapse and pulmonary rehabilitation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Calculate the respiratory quotient (RQ) in a patient with 50kg body weight, if the CO2 exhaled is 200ml/min and 02 consumed is 250 ml/min? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.8

 

The respiratory quotient is 0.8.

 

This ratio of carbon dioxide output to oxygen usage is called the respiratory quotient. In the above problem, the CO2 production is 200mL/min, while the 02 consumption is 250mL/min.


So, Respiratory quotient = 200/250 = 0.8

 

Educational Objective:

 

The respiratory quotient (RQ) is used for determining the metabolic utilization of various foods.

 

  • RQ of carbohydrates is 1
  • RQ of fats is 0.70.
  • RQ of proteins is 0.80.

questions.text: Macula densa is formed by which part of the nephron? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DCT

 

 

Macula densa is formed by specialized tubular epithelial cells of the distal convoluted tubule. The juxtaglomerular complex consists of macula densa cells in the initial portion of the distal tubule and juxtaglomerular cells in the walls of the afferent and efferent arterioles.

 

The macula densa is a specialized group of epithelial cells in the distal tubules that comes in close contact with the afferent and efferent arterioles. The macula densa cells contain Golgi apparatus, which are intracellular secretory organelles directed toward the arterioles, suggesting that these cells may be secreting a substance toward the arterioles.

 

Tubuloglomerular feedback is the mechanism that regulates GFR through renal tubule and macula densa. When the glomerular filtrate passes through the terminal portion of thick ascending segment, macula densa acts like a sensor. It detects the concentration of sodium chloride in the tubular fluid and accordingly alters the glomerular blood flow and GFR. Macula densa detects the sodium chloride concentration via Na+K+2Cl– cotransporter (NKCC2).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCT (Proximal Convoluted Tubule): Incorrect. The proximal convoluted tubule is involved in the reabsorption of water, ions, and nutrients, but it does not form the macula densa.

 

Option C. Afferent arteriole: Incorrect. The afferent arteriole brings blood into the glomerulus and contains juxtaglomerular cells, but it does not form the macula densa.

 

Option D. Bowman's capsule: Incorrect. Bowman's capsule surrounds the glomerulus and is involved in the initial filtration of blood to form urine but does not form the macula densa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The macula densa, formed by cells of the distal convoluted tubule (DCT), is crucial for sensing sodium chloride concentration in the tubular fluid and regulating glomerular filtration rate (GFR) through the tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism.

questions.text: Identify the seeds shown in the image below: (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nigella sativa 

 

The seeds shown in the given image are of the plant Nigella sativa. 

 

Other names - black cumin or kalonji.

 

Method of action - Sativa modulates the neuronal release of GABA, glycine, aspartate and glutamate on cultured cortical neurons and also possesses a potent central nervous system (CNS) sedative and analgesic activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tropicana canna: This option is incorrect as Tropicana canna refers to a type of plant known for its large, colorful leaves and flowers, not for its seeds.

 

 

Option C. Datura seeds: Incorrect, as Datura seeds are typically flatter and have a distinct shape compared to Nigella sativa. Datura is also known for its toxic properties and is used in traditional medicine with caution.

 

 

Option D. Opium seeds: Incorrect. Opium seeds likely refer to poppy seeds, which are smaller and have a different texture and appearance compared to Nigella sativa seeds.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nigella sativa, or black cumin, is not only recognized for its unique seed appearance but also for its significant medicinal properties, including sedative and analgesic effects on the central nervous system.

choices.text: 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid daily
60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly
100 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly
100 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid daily

questions.text: Dr. Sanjana is leading a health initiative in Karnataka, focusing on the prevention of anemia among adult women through the Anemia Mukth Bharath initiative. She needs to communicate the correct dosage of iron and folic acid supplementation. What is the recommended dose according to the guidelines? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly

 

  • As per the Anemia Mukth Bharat initiative guidelines, it is recommended for adult females to consume 60 mg of elemental iron along with 500 mcg of folic acid in tablet form on a weekly basis.
  • These tablets have a sugar-coated exterior and are colored red.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Waxy cast
RBC cast
WBC cast
Maltese cross cast

questions.text: During rounds, you come across the urinalysis report of the 30-year-old male diagnosed with Fabry's disease. What type of urinary casts would you expect to see in the report? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Maltese cross cast

 

Maltese cross urinary casts are seen in a patient diagnosed with Fabry's disease.

 

Urine analysis in Fabry's disease may reveal oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarized light showing a Maltese cross appearance.

 

 

Maltese cross birefringence has also been described in:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans, cholesterol ester storage disease, babesiosis, and in urine sediments of a patient with nephrotic syndrome and erythropoietic protoporphyria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waxy cast: Waxy casts are typically seen in chronic kidney disease and are associated with severe tubular atrophy and stasis of urine flow. They do not exhibit a Maltese cross pattern.

 

Option B. RBC cast: RBC casts are indicative of glomerular injury, such as in glomerulonephritis, and are not associated with Fabry's disease.

 

Option C. WBC cast: WBC casts are typically seen in conditions like pyelonephritis or interstitial nephritis, where there is inflammation involving the renal tubules or interstitium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maltese cross casts in urinalysis are indicative of Fabry's disease due to the presence of glycolipid-laden renal tubular cells. These casts show a characteristic birefringent pattern under polarized light.

choices.text: Eye drops first, ointment 15 min later
Ointment first, eye drops 15 min later

questions.text: What is the correct order of using eye drops and eye ointment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Eye drops first, ointment 15 min later

 

To ensure proper absorption of medication, it is recommended to use eye drops before ointment. Eye drops have a thinner consistency and are absorbed more quickly, whereas ointments are thicker and need more time for absorption. Therefore, eye drops should be used first, followed by ointment after a gap of 15 minutes, especially when using both at the same time. Ointments are typically used at bedtime due to their prolonged absorption time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ointment first, eye drops 15 min later and D. Ointment first, then eye drops immediately: Incorrect because the ointment could prevent the eye drops from being absorbed properly by creating a barrier.

 

Note - Ointments are generally used last, particularly at bedtime, to maintain medication contact with the eye surface for an extended period, aiding in treatment effectiveness, especially in conditions requiring continuous exposure to the medication.

 

Option C. Eye drops first, then ointment immediately: Incorrect as applying ointment immediately after drops could interfere with the absorption of the drops.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Always use eye drops before eye ointment when both forms of medication are prescribed. Allowing a gap of 15 minutes between applying drops and ointment ensures maximum effectiveness of both medications without interference in absorption.

questions.text: A senior ENT specialist at the hospital is conducting the clinical examination depicted in the provided image. Which of the subsequent anatomical structures will not be visible to him? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arytenoids

 

While conducting a posterior rhinoscopy with the held post-nasal mirror, the specialist would not have a view of the arytenoids.

 

  • Arytenoids are seen on indirect laryngoscopy.
  • The posterior rhinoscopy mirror has two bends in the shaft and is bayonet shaped.
  • The structures seen in posterior rhinoscopy are:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoids: These are clearly visible during posterior rhinoscopy, which is aimed at examining the nasopharynx, where the adenoids are located.

 

Option C. Torus tubarius: This structure, which surrounds the pharyngeal opening of the Eustachian tube, is also visible during a posterior rhinoscopy.

 

Option D. Upper surface of soft palate: This area can be inspected during posterior rhinoscopy for signs of inflammation, lesions, or other abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The arytenoids are viewed using indirect laryngoscopy, not posterior rhinoscopy, due to their location in the larynx. Posterior rhinoscopy provides visualization of the nasopharyngeal region, aiding in the assessment of structures like adenoids, torus tubarius, and the upper surface of the soft palate, important for diagnosing various nasopharyngeal conditions.

 

Additional Information

 

Structures seen on indirect laryngoscopy

choices.text: Low molecular weight heparin

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be useful in a patient with severe COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Favipiravir

 

Favipiravir is an antiviral drug that has been studied for use in COVID-19, but its effectiveness, particularly in severe cases, is less clear compared to other treatments. Favipiravir is known to work against RNA viruses, but its role in the treatment of severe COVID-19 has not been established as a standard of care.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH): Patients with severe COVID-19 are at increased risk of thromboembolic events. LMWH is used to prevent blood clots and is an important part of the management of hospitalized COVID-19 patients, especially those with severe disease.

 

Option B. Oxygen: Oxygen therapy is crucial for patients with severe COVID-19, especially those experiencing respiratory distress and hypoxemia (low blood oxygen levels). It is a key supportive treatment.

 

Option D. Steroids: Corticosteroids like dexamethasone have been shown to reduce mortality in patients with severe and critical COVID-19, particularly those requiring respiratory support. They are used to reduce inflammation in the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Favipiravir is least likely to be useful in a patient with severe COVID-19 compared to low molecular weight heparin, oxygen, and steroids, which have well-established roles in managing severe cases of the disease.

questions.text: A diabetic patient walks into your clinic and does "namaste". The image is given below. What could be the probable cause? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cheiroarthropathy

 

Incomplete approximation of one or more of the digits when the patient attempts to approximate the palmar surfaces of the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints with palms pressed together and the fingers abducted.

 

It is associated with both Microvascular disease and macrovascular risk.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Flexor tenosynovitis: Involves inflammation of the tendon sheaths and is typically painful, which might include swelling and crepitus upon movement. It does not typically present with the inability to approximate the palms as in cheiroarthropathy.

 

Option B. Dupuytren's contracture: Results in fibrosis of the palmar fascia leading to permanent bending of the fingers into the palm. Unlike cheiroarthropathy, Dupuytren's typically produces visible nodules and cords in the palm, pulling the fingers inward.

 

Option D. Ankylosis: Involves the complete fusion of a joint leading to total immobility. This would manifest as rigid, immovable joints in fixed positions, not merely stiff and difficult to approximate as in cheiroarthropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cheiroarthropathy is a significant indicator of chronic diabetic complications affecting the connective tissue. Recognizing this condition is important as it often correlates with other microvascular complications of diabetes such as retinopathy and nephropathy, prompting comprehensive management of the patient's diabetes to prevent further complications.

questions.text: Which part of the internal capsule is affected in hemiplegia due to ischemic stroke? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior Limb

 

The posterior limb of the internal capsule is the most commonly affected area in cases of hemiplegia due to ischemic stroke. This area carries the corticospinal tract, which is essential for motor control. When the posterior limb is compromised, it disrupts the corticospinal pathway, leading to muscle weakness or paralysis on the opposite side of the body from the lesion.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrolentiform: Primarily involved in visual processing. Damage here would likely lead to visual field defects rather than motor dysfunction.

 

Option B. Anterior limb: Primarily associated with cognitive and emotional functions due to its connectivity between the thalamus and the frontal lobe. Lesions here generally do not cause hemiplegia.

 

Option C. Sublentiform: Involved in auditory and gustatory pathways, thus unrelated to motor control functions affected in hemiplegia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of ischemic stroke, damage to the posterior limb of the internal capsule results in hemiplegia because of the disruption of corticospinal tracts. This knowledge aids in accurate stroke localization and informs rehabilitation strategies to help regain motor functions.

choices.text: Breech identified for the first-time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery
Breech delivery is done in a hospital where a facility for emergency CS is available
Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labor
Should be done by a skilled obstetrician

questions.text: A woman in labour presented to the ER. A vaginal breech delivery was planned for her. What statement regarding the management is false? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Breech identified for the first-time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery

 

Explanation:

 

The statement that breech presentation identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery is false.

 

Breech identified for the first-time during delivery is not automatically a contraindication for a vaginal breech delivery. It is crucial to assess the situation carefully, considering the skill of the obstetrician and the facilities available, but it does not universally rule out the possibility of a vaginal breech delivery.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Breech delivery is done in a hospital where a facility for emergency CS is available: This is correct because the presence of a facility for emergency cesarean section is essential for managing unexpected complications during a breech delivery.

 

Option C. Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labor: This is correct because continuous fetal heart rate monitoring is crucial to detect any signs of fetal distress during a breech delivery.

 

Option D. Should be done by a skilled obstetrician: This is correct as vaginal breech deliveries should be performed by an experienced and skilled obstetrician to manage the potential risks and complications effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breech presentation identified for the first-time during delivery is not an automatic contraindication for vaginal delivery, provided other criteria are met and facilities are available.

 

Ref: Page no 449, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition.

questions.text: In case of meniscal tear, in which of the following zones the healing is best seen? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red zone

 

VASCULAR REGIONS IN THE MENISCUS

 

  • Vascular supply to the menisci originates predominantly from the inferior and superior lateral and medial geniculate arteries via the perimeniscal capillary plexus.
  • At birth, the entire meniscus is vascular. Following birth, the menisci become increasingly avascular (decrease in vascularity continues up to age 9 years), so by maturity only the peripheral 10-25% of the tissue is perfused.
  • In adults, only 10-25% of lateral meniscus and 10-30% of medial meniscus is vascular.
  • This gives rise to 3 distinct regions of the menisci: 
    • The peripheral relatively vascularized region called the red-red zone (Zone 1)
    • The completely avascular inner 2/3rd zone is known as the white-white zone (Zone 3)
    • Zone of transition between the two (border of avascular and vascular area), which is called the red-white zone (Zone 2)
       
  • There is a direct relationship between the vascularization and capacity of the tissue to heal, predisposing the white-white zone to permanent posttraumatic and degenerative lesions.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Red-white zone. The red-white zone is the middle third with less vascularization but can heal through sometimes.

 

Option C. White zone. The white-white zone has no blood capillaries at all and therefore, cannot heal. They usually require surgery to remove or cut out the torn portion of the meniscus.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The red zone of the meniscus is the most vascularized zone.
  • Any injury at this zone will heal on its own, without a requirement of surgery.

choices.text: Laparoscopic ovarian drilling

questions.text: All of the following can be used for the treatment of PCOD except? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ulipristal

 

Explanation:

 

  • Ulipristal is not used for the treatment of PCOD.
    • It is a selective progesterone receptor modulator.
    • It is used as an emergency contraceptive and in medical management of fibroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clomiphene: Clomiphene is an anti-estrogen used in ovulation induction in women with PCOS (1st line agent) and infertility

 

  • Gonadotropins can also be used in PCOS with infertility in those who have clomiphene resistance (2nd line therapy)

 

Option B. Letrozole: But nowadays Letrozole (aromatase inhibitor) is the drug for ovulation induction in PCOS with infertility.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic ovarian drilling: It is recommended as second-line therapy in PCOS

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulipristal is not used for the treatment of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS). It is a selective progesterone receptor modulator primarily used for emergency contraception and managing uterine fibroids.

 

Ref: Page 244, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Glycopyrrolate is used as a preanesthetic agent for? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reducing the secretions 

 

  • Mechanism of Action: Glycopyrrolate is an anticholinergic agent, which means it acts by blocking the action of acetylcholine on muscarinic receptors.
  • Effect: One of the effects of this action is the reduction in the production of secretions, such as saliva and bronchial mucus.
  • Clinical Use: Given before anesthesia, it can prevent excessive secretions that might interfere with the procedure or increase the risk of aspiration. Hence, this is the primary reason glycopyrrolate is used as a preanesthetic agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sedative effect: Glycopyrrolate does not have inherent sedative properties. While it may have some central side effects due to its anticholinergic action, its quaternary structure limits its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier. Thus, it doesn't produce sedation in the same manner as agents specifically designed for that purpose, like benzodiazepines.

 

Option C. Skeletal muscle relaxant: Glycopyrrolate does not have skeletal muscle relaxant properties.

 

Option D. Anxiolytic: Glycopyrrolate is not used as an anxiolytic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glycopyrrolate is primarily used as a preanesthetic agent to reduce secretions, thus preventing complications during anesthesia and surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following does not present with maculopapular rash? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zoster (shingles)

 

A maculopapular rash is not seen in zoster (shingles).

 

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution as shown in the image below.

 

 

Herpes zoster:

 

  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  1. Painful zoster infections in adults
  2. Facial zoster at any age
  3. Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rubella: Presents with a maculopapular rash as shown in the image below, which consists of minute, discrete macules.

 

 

  • The rash appears within 24 hours of onset of prodromal symptoms.

 

Option C. Dengue (during febrile phase): Dengue fever can present with a maculopapular rash during its febrile phase.

 

Option D. Measles: Measles is characterized by fever and a maculopapular skin rash, which is accompanied by immune clearance of measles virus (MV)-infected cells

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zoster (shingles) does not present with a maculopapular rash but rather with a painful, vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution. In contrast, rubella, dengue during the febrile phase, and measles are classic causes of maculopapular rashes.
 

 

Ref- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no. 25.27-25.28
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106
Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 4.13

choices.text: Atropine and neostigmine are very useful in the management of krait bite
Neostigmine and ventilatory support are used in treatment along with ASV
ASV is the mainstay of treatment
Current ASV in India is less effective against humped pit viper

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the management of snakebite in India? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atropine and neostigmine are very useful in the management of krait bite 

 

Neostigmine (along with atropine) can be used for neurotoxic snakes (both cobra and krait). But the usefulness is much less in krait bite, and much more in cobra bite.

 

  • Mechanism of Neostigmine: Neostigmine is the inhibitor of acetylcholinesterase enzyme. So, it will act as an antidote to acetylcholinesterase enzyme component of cobra and krait venom
  • Why Neostigmine is less useful in Krait: Krait, in addition also have some toxins that inhibit the release of acetylcholine from presynaptic terminal at neuromuscular junction. Neostigmine will not be helpful to counter the effect of these toxins. 
  • Why Atropine used with Neostigmine: As neostigmine increases the amount of acetylcholine, both nicotinic and muscarinic effects occur. But to treat snake bite we need only nicotinic effects at neuromuscular junction. Atropine is an antimuscarinic agent and helps to counter the muscarinic effects of nicotine, especially bradycardia. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neostigmine and ventilatory support are used in treatment along with ASV:
This statement is true. Neostigmine can be part of the management for neurotoxic snake envenomations, and ventilatory support may be necessary if there is significant respiratory compromise. ASV (Anti-Snake Venom) is also used as it neutralizes the venom.

 

Option C. ASV is the mainstay of treatment: True. ASV remains the primary treatment for snakebite envenomations in India, effectively neutralizing the venom of various snake species.

 

Option D. Current ASV in India is less effective against humped pit viper: This is true. There are regional variations in the efficacy of ASV based on the specific snake species prevalent in those regions, and ASV formulations may be less effective against certain species, such as the humped pit viper.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of snake bite:

 

  • First Aid treatment have limited role. Reassure the patient, immobilize the limb and keep it below the heart level. Light pressure can be applied in neurotoxic snakes.
  • Anti-snake venom (ASV) is the main treatment for snake bite. It contains antivenom against the 4 common poisonous snakes in India (Cobra, Krait, Russel’s viper and saw scaled viper). It does not contain antivenom against humped pit viper, which is found in some states of India, but still can be partially effective in it due to cross antibodies formation. 
  • Treatment in addition to ASV:
    • Vasculotoxic symptoms: Dialysis and Blood Transfusion
    • Musculotoxic symptoms: Dialysis
    • Neurotoxic snakes: Ventilation and Neostigmine (along with atropine)

 

Other Options: Explained above

questions.text: A stool sample is collected. The specimen is processed for examination and is labeled at different levels as A, B, C, and D. Identify the level at which parasitic ova will be seen when viewed under a microscope? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

Level D will show parasitic ova in formal ether sedimentation test.

 

 

The above image shows formal ether sedimentation technique.

 

Sedimentation techniques use solutions of lower specific gravity than the parasitic organisms, thus concentrating the latter in the sediment. It takes advantage of the high specific gravity of protozoan cysts and helminth eggs compared to water. Their natural tendency to settle out in aqueous solutions can be accelerated by light centrifugation.

 

Formalin fixes the eggs, larvae, oocysts, and spores, so that they are no longer infectious, as well as preserves their morphology. Fecal debris is extracted into the ethyl acetate phase of the solution. Parasitic elements are sedimented at the bottom.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A: This level contains ether, which is used to extract fecal debris.

 

Option B. B: This level is where the plug of debris is found after centrifugation.

 

Option C. C: This level contains formalin, which fixes and preserves the morphology of the parasitic elements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The formal ether sedimentation technique separates parasitic elements based on their specific gravity. Parasitic ova, cysts, and larvae will be concentrated in the sediment at the bottom of the tube, labeled as level D.

questions.text: Dr. Verma is examining the criteria used to establish the Recommended Daily Allowance (RDA) for nutrients and focuses on the typical characteristics of a "reference woman". Which of the following correctly describes this reference woman used for RDA calculations? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Weight 55 kgs

 

  • Weight of 55 kgs: This is used as a standard measurement in RDA calculations to reflect an average baseline for determining nutrient needs in adult women.
  • It represents a balance that is thought to be typical or ideal for maintaining health without excessive caloric intake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The reference woman used in the calculation of recommended daily allowance (RDA)

 

  • Aged between 19-39 years
  • Non pregnant, non-lactating
  • Weight=55kgs
  • Height = 1.61 m
  • BMI=21.2
  • Free from disease and physically fit for active work
  • Engaged in moderate activity for 8 hours on each working day
  • Spends 8 hours in bed, 4-6 hours in sitting and moving, 2hours in walking and in active recreation or household activities.

questions.text: Identify the type of skull fracture in the given image? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fissured 

 

Image shows thin lines, which are not displaced. This is characteristic of fissured (linear) #

 

Fissured (linear) fractures present as thin, non-displaced lines and are the most common type of skull fracture, typically resulting from broad surface impacts, such as in road traffic accidents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ring Fracture: Caused by a fall from height, presenting as a fracture around the foramen magnum.

 

Option B. Depressed Fracture: Caused by heavy objects with a small surface area, takes the shape of the weapon.

 

Option D. Hinge Fracture: Divides the skull into anterior and posterior halves, often associated with motorcyclist injuries.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Skull fractures 

 

  1. Linear fracture/ primary fracture/ fissured fracture                                                 
    • Fracture looks like a thin line 
    • Due to striking with a broad surface, e.g. ground 
    • Most common skull fracture, 
    • Usually seen in Road traffic accident
       

  2. Depressed fracture/ signature fracture 

    • Due to a heavy objects with small surface area . e.g. hammer 
    • Takes the shape of the weapon 

     

  3. Indented fracture / ping pong fracture / ponds #
    • Skull is depressed like a ping pong ball 
    • Seen in infants 
       
  4. Gutter fracture 
    • Long narrow depressed fracture 
    • Bullet passing adjacent to skull 
       
  5. Sutural fracture / diastatic fracture 
    • Sutures separate
    • Seen In <3 yrs of age 
       
  6. Ring fracture 
    • Cause – fall from height 
    • # around foramen magnum 
    • Associated # of vertebrae 
       
  7. Hinge fracture / motorcyclist fracture 
    • Skull divided into anterior and posterior halves 
       
  8. Spider web fracture / mosaic fracture / comminuted fracture 
    • Multiple fractures of skull

questions.text: What is the causative organism for the condition shown in the image below? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echinococcus granulosus

 

The given image shows a hydatid cyst in the liver. Large, unilocular/multilocular, well-defined, hypodense cysts. Contains multiple internal “daughter” cysts of lower density than “mother” cyst (exocyst). Curvilinear ring-like calcification of pericyst (wall).

 

Causative organism – Echinococcus granulosus

 

Definitive hosts – Dogs, Intermediate host – Sheep, Accidental intermediate host – Human (end stage host)

 

In the liver, the pressure effect of the cyst can produce symptoms of obstructive jaundice and abdominal pain. With biliary rupture, the classic triad of biliary colic, jaundice, and urticaria is observed. Passage of hydatid membranes in the emesis (hydatid emesia) and passage of membranes in the stools (hydatid enterica) may occur rarely.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schistosoma japonicum: This parasitic worm causes schistosomiasis, primarily affecting the intestines and liver, but it does not form hydatid cysts.

 

Option C. Trypanosoma cruzi: This protozoan parasite causes Chagas disease, which primarily affects the heart and digestive system, not forming cysts in the liver.

 

Option D. Schistosoma mansoni: This parasitic worm also causes schistosomiasis, affecting the intestines and liver, but it does not form hydatid cysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The condition shown in the image, characterized by a hydatid cyst in the liver, is caused by Echinococcus granulosus. The cysts contain internal daughter cysts and can lead to symptoms related to the pressure effect on the liver and biliary system.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman who presented with complaints of fever and joint pain develops the following lesion on her nose after a few days of taking NSAIDs. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chikungunya

 

The given history of fever and joint pain along with centrofacial hyperpigmentation shown in the image suggests a diagnosis of Chikungunya. Hyperpigmentation associated with Chikungunya fever is macular and most commonly affects the nose and cheeks.

 

  • Chik sign: Nose pigmentation is striking in cases of Chikungunya fever and is termed as Chik sign. It appears as the fever subsides and persists for about 3–6 months.
  • The hyperpigmentation mimics melasma and may be misdiagnosed if the clinical history is not taken properly.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Dengue: Incorrect. Dengue fever does not typically present with centrofacial hyperpigmentation.

 

Option C. Melasma: Incorrect. Melasma presents as hyperpigmented patches but is unrelated to fever and joint pain.

 

Option D. Fixed drug eruption (FDE): Incorrect. FDE is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction characterized by well-defined, hyperpigmented plaques that occur at the same location on re-exposure to the drug. These lesions are usually associated with NSAIDs but present differently, often as brown hyperpigmented plaques following vesiculobullous lesions.

 

Additional Note on FDE:

 

  • FDE Characteristics: Typically occurs on the lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, or oral mucosa. Presents 30 min to 8 hours after drug exposure, with a burning sensation and reappearance at the same site.

 

Educational Objective:


In patients with fever and joint pain developing centrofacial hyperpigmentation, consider Chikungunya fever, particularly with the presence of Chik sign on the nose and cheeks. Proper history is crucial to avoid misdiagnosis, such as mistaking the presentation for melasma.

choices.text: Increase in FEV1> 12% after salbutamol inhalation

questions.text: All the following PFT findings in a child are suggestive of asthma except? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Day- night variation of FEV1 > 12%

 

A day-night variation of FEV1 > 12%, is not a standard measure used in the diagnosis of asthma. While diurnal variation in peak expiratory flow (PEF) is often used to monitor asthma control, it is not specifically measured by FEV1, and a >12% variation in FEV1 between day and night is not typically used as a diagnostic criterion for asthma.

 

Pulmonary Function Tests (PFTs) are essential in diagnosing and managing asthma, particularly in identifying airflow obstruction and its reversibility. Specific findings on PFTs suggestive of asthma include:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in FEV1> 12% after salbutamol inhalation: An increase in FEV1 (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second) by more than 15% after the administration of a bronchodilator like salbutamol is indicative of reversible airway obstruction, which is characteristic of asthma.

 

Option B. FEV1/FVC< 80%: A FEV1/FVC (Forced Vital Capacity) ratio of less than 80% is suggestive of obstructive lung disease, including asthma. This ratio decreases because of the increased airway resistance in asthmatic patients.

 

Option D. Decrease in FEV1>12% after exercise: A decrease in FEV1 by more than 15% after exercise is a sign of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, a common feature of asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An increase in FEV1 > 12% after bronchodilator use and a FEV1/FVC ratio < 80% are key PFT findings suggestive of asthma.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of this condition affecting hair? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trichothiodystrophy

 

The given clinical image of hair seen under polarizing microscopy reveals tiger tail banding (alternating light and dark bands) characteristic of trichothiodystrophy.

 

Trichothiodystrophy/PIBIDS syndrome: Autosomal Recessive condition

 

  • Photosensitivity (unlike XP, has NO increased skin cancer risk)
  • Ichthyosis
  • Brittle hair (short/sparse on scalp/brows/lashes w/alternating light and dark bands on polarizing light microscopy (“tiger-tail” abnormality)
  • Intellectual impairment and ataxia
  • Decreased fertility/hypogonadism
  • Short stature

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichorrhexis nodosa: It is associated with node formation. It may be seen in arginosuccinic aciduria. Characterized by classical appearance as if two paint brushes are rubbing against each other described as Thrust Paintbrush appearance.

 

 

Option B. Trichorrhexis invaginata: Also known as Bamboo hair having Golf tee or Ball & Socket appearance, is characterized by invagination of the distal hair shaft into the proximal portion. Seen in Netherton’s syndrome.

 

 

Option D: Monilethrix: Beaded hair seen in Menkes disease.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Tiger tail" banding of hair under polarized light microscopy is indicative of trichothiodystrophy, a condition characterized by brittle hair with reduced sulfur content and potentially associated with multisystem involvement.

 

Ref - Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page no 1537

Rooks Textbook of dermatology 9th edition Volume III Pages 68.19, 78.10 89.53-54

questions.text: Counter force brace is used for:(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tennis elbow

 

TENNIS ELBOW OR LATERAL EPICONDYLITIS

 

  • Any occupation that requires repeated/sustained wrist extension or repeated pinching/grasping can result in lateral epicondylitis; the condition is, therefore, not limited to sports-related (i.e., one-handed tennis back hand) injuries.
  • Classically, this is tendonitis of the extensor carpi radialis brevis (common extensor origin) tendon at the lateral humeral epicondyle, but can affect the extensor carpi radialis longus at the supracondylar line.

 

 

  • It may result in small tears, fibrocartilaginous metaplasia, microscopic calcification and painful vascular reaction in tendon fibers close to lateral epicondyle (degenerative changes with angiofibroblastic proliferation).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Localized tenderness at or just below lateral epicondyle.
    • Pain can be reproduced by passively stretching the extensor radialis brevis. This is done by extending the elbow, pronating the forearm and then passively flexing the wrist or active extension of wrist against resistance can produce pain (Cozen’s test).

 

 

  • Pain with resisted extension (as seen in the Chair test) or with activities such as wrist dorsiflexion or gripping activities is typically reported by the patient.
     

  • Management:
    • Usual treatment includes work modification to minimize contributing activities with the focus on a better anthropomorphic match between the user and their work environment in contrast to a one-size-fits-all design strategy.
    • Acute pain can be treated with anti-inflammatories, cold pack massage over the extensor origin, rest, a wrist extensor strengthening regimen, or use of a counterforce (“tennis elbow”) brace.
    • The proposed mechanism for this brace is the dissipation of the forces away from the injured tissue to the surrounding noninjured area. 
    • This type of brace can be both a rehabilitative and a functional orthosis.

 

 

  • Chronic lateral epicondylitis treatment strategies in the context of employment are more controversial.
     

  • Some common treatments include steroid injection, platelet rich plasma, dry needling/trigger point injections, physical therapy to include isometric and concentric exercises, and stretches.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Wrist drop. For wrist drop due to radial nerve palsy, a dynamic cock-up splint is given.

 

 

Option C. Foot drop. For foot drop, an AFO or ankle-foot orthosis or leaf brace is given.

 

 

Option D. Ankle sprain. For ankle sprain, an adjustable ankle brace is given.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Counter force brace is used for the rehabilitation of tennis elbow.
  • This brace dissipates the forces away from the injured tissue to the surrounding non-injured area.

choices.text: Vagal output to cardiac fibres increase

questions.text: Which of the following events occur immediately when a person changes his/her posture from supine to standing? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decrease in firing from baroreceptor

 

When a person changes posture from supine to standing, the immediate effect is a decrease in mean arterial pressure (MAP) due to gravity causing blood to pool in the lower extremities. This results in decreased venous return and cardiac output and decreased firing from the baroreceptors.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vagal output to cardiac fibers increase: Incorrect. The vagal (parasympathetic) output decreases when standing to allow an increase in heart rate and cardiac output.

 

Option C. Mesenteric vasoconstriction: Incorrect. Although mesenteric vasoconstriction occurs due to sympathetic activation, it is not the immediate response; the initial response is the decrease in baroreceptor firing.

 

Option D. Increase cardiac contractility: Incorrect. While increased cardiac contractility occurs due to sympathetic activation, it is a subsequent response following the decrease in baroreceptor firing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate response when a person changes posture from supine to standing is a decrease in baroreceptor firing due to a reduction in mean arterial pressure.

questions.text: A patient after a roadside trauma presented to the trauma center. He has a severe pain in his left hip and, on examination the hip is exquisitely tender with restricted range of motion. The patient is lying in the posture seen below. Which of the following deformity is seen in the patient? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior dislocation of hip

 

ANTERIOR DISLOCATION OF HIP

 

  • Anterior dislocations occur with the hip externally rotated and abducted.

 

 

FABER position of limb after dislocation

 

  • The degree of flexion at the time of injury determines the eventual position of the femoral head.
  • They are associated with lengthening.
  • It is less common than posterior dislocation
  • It is divided into various types according to the position assumed by the femoral head: 
    • Pubic
    • Obturator
    • Perineal
       
  • Clinical Features:
    • Patient assumes externally rotated, abducted and slightly flexed posture at the affected hip, with restriction of movement.
    • Head of femur is often felt either anteriorly (superior type) or in the groin (inferior type).
       
  • Imaging Findings
    • Dislocation is usually seen on AP view; in a few cases, lateral view may be needed to establish the diagnosis.

 

 

  • Treatment: 
    • An anterior dislocation usually can be reduced without surgery by pulling longitudinally on the thigh.
    • If the dislocation cannot be reduced by these maneuvers, open reduction is performed.
       
  • Complication: 
    • Avascular necrosis.
    • Because of their anterior relationship to the hip, the femoral vessels and nerve may be injured, especially with pubic dislocations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior dislocation of hip. The head of the femur is pushed out of the acetabulum posteriorly. It is more common (90%). The injury is sustained by violence directed along the shaft of the femur, with the hip flexed in motor accidents. It is, therefore, also known as dashboard injury.

 

 

The patient presents with a history of severe trauma followed by pain, swelling and deformity (flexion, adduction and internal rotation – FADIR), associated with a shortening of the leg.

 

 

In plain radiograph, the femoral head is out of the acetabulum.

 

 

The thigh is internally rotated so, the lesser trochanter is not seen. Shenton’s line is broken. In most cases, it is possible to reduce the hip by closed manipulation under general anaesthesia. Open reduction may be required in cases where closed reduction fails, if there is intra-articular loose fragment, and if the acetabular fragment is large and is from the weight-bearing part of the acetabulum. Complications include injury to the sciatic nerve, avascular necrosis of the femoral head, osteoarthritis, myositis ossificans.

 

Option C. Inferior dislocation of hip. Inferior dislocation of hip or luxatio erecta femoris is the rarest among all types of hip dislocation. It can be caused by a severe trauma to the hip. Most of the reported cases involve the pediatric age group. There are two types of inferior hip dislocation; ischial type and obturator type. In the obturator type, when a force is applied to femur while the hip joint is in abduction and flexion, the femoral head dislocates anteriorly and inferiorly to the obturator foramen. In the ischial type, a force is applied to femur while hip and knee joints are in hyperflexion without abduction or external rotation. The femoral head dislocates inferiorly next to the ischium. The ischial type is more common than the obturator type.

 

 

Option D. Central dislocation of hip. A central dislocation involves the femoral head being forced downward. Acetabular fractures with central hip dislocation result from direct axial loading through the greater trochanter in abduction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Restricted hip range of motion with FABER deformity of the hip is suggestive of anterior dislocation of the hip.

questions.text: Which of the following procedure is shown in the image given below? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior ethmoidal nerve block

 

The procedure shown in the given image is an anterior ethmoidal nerve block.

 

The anterior ethmoidal nerve supplies the roof of the nasal cavity. It is a branch of the Nasociliary nerve which in turn is a branch of the ophthalmic nerve (V1). It is sometimes used in endonasal surgery.

 

Detailing the Procedure:

 

  • Purpose: Used predominantly to numb the area for surgical procedures within the nasal cavity.
  • Method: Involves injection near the anterior ethmoidal foramen to block the nerve that transmits sensation from the nasal roof.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasolacrimal duct syringing: This procedure is used to check the patency of the nasolacrimal duct. It involves flushing the duct with saline to check for blockages, typically conducted by inserting a syringe into the puncta near the medial canthus of the eye. However, this is not related to the procedure shown in the image since it involves the eye directly and is performed with the eyes open to access the puncta.

 

Option C. Infraorbital nerve block: This block anesthetizes the area supplied by the infraorbital nerve, which affects the lower eyelid, upper lip, and cheek. It is generally performed via an intraoral approach at the infraorbital foramen, located below the orbit, which is not depicted in the image.

 

Option D. Trephination of the frontal sinus: This surgical procedure involves making an incision in the floor of the frontal sinus to facilitate drainage. This procedure targets a different anatomic location and involves surgical tools, not the approach shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An anterior ethmoidal nerve block is crucial for numbing the nasal cavity area, particularly in endonasal surgeries. It is essential for procedures requiring detailed work near the roof of the nasal cavity, reflecting the significance of understanding the specific nerve anatomy for effective anesthesia.

questions.text: A drug that selectively reduces the reuptake of serotonin would likely cause which of the following side effects? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sexual dysfunction

 

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are a class of drugs that specifically inhibit the reuptake of serotonin. One of the well-documented side effects of SSRIs is sexual dysfunction, which may manifest as decreased libido, delayed ejaculation, anorgasmia, or erectile dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Constipation: Some antidepressants, particularly tricyclic antidepressants, can cause constipation, but it's not a primary side effect of SSRIs.

 

Option C. Sialorrhea: This refers to excessive drooling or salivation. It's not typically a side effect of SSRIs.

 

Option D. Visual disturbance: While many drugs can cause visual disturbances, it's not a hallmark side effect of SSRIs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Side effects of SSRIs include:

 

  • Most common: Nausea
  • Most common long-term side effects: Sexual dysfunction including delayed orgasm, poor erection and low libido.
  • CNS side effects- Paradoxical anxiety, sedation, vivid dreams, sweating, seizures, EPSE etc.
  • QTc prolongation
  • Weight gain

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 1018-1020.

questions.text: The pretracheal layer of deep cervical fascia encloses all of the following structure, except? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sternocleidomastoid

 

All the above structures are enclosed by the pretracheal layer of deep cervical fascia except sternocleidomastoid. It is enclosed by the investing layer of deep cervical fascia.

 

The deep cervical fascia of the neck is organized into the following layers:

 

  • The investing layer - surrounds all structures in the neck
  • The prevertebral layer - surrounds the vertebral column and the deep muscles associated with the back.
  • The pretracheal layer - encloses the viscera of the neck
  • The carotid sheath - receives a contribution from the other three fascial layers

 

The strap muscles of the neck, including the sternohyoid, omohyoid, sternothyroid, and thyrohyoid, are covered by the pretracheal fascia. To encapsulate the thyroid gland, it divides. The recurrent laryngeal nerve, which is located in the groove between the trachea and the oesophagus, is likewise surrounded by this tissue.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophagus: The esophagus is indeed enclosed by the pretracheal fascia in its cervical portion. The fascia extends posteriorly from the trachea to envelop the esophagus, giving some form of fascial support to this structure as it descends through the neck.

 

Option C. Sternohyoid: The sternohyoid muscle is one of the infrahyoid muscles and lies superficially in the anterior part of the neck. It is indeed enclosed by the pretracheal layer of the deep cervical fascia. This layer of fascia extends inferiorly from the hyoid bone to the thorax and surrounds the thyroid gland, trachea, and infrahyoid muscles, including the sternohyoid.

 

Option D. Thyroid gland: The thyroid gland is an endocrine gland situated anteriorly in the midline and the side of the neck, straddling the trachea. The pretracheal fascia contributes to the formation of the capsule of the thyroid gland, thus enclosing it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM) is not enclosed by the pretracheal fascia. Instead, the SCM is associated with the superficial layer of the deep cervical fascia (also known as the investing layer). This layer of the fascia envelops both the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles, acting as an investing layer for these superficial neck muscles.

choices.text: Ejaculation
Dilation of bronchus
Increased cardiac contractility

questions.text: Muscarinic receptor stimulation primarily causes which of the following actions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Erection

 

  • Parasympathetic (muscarinic) stimulation result in erection whereas sympathetic stimulation causes ejaculation.
  • Parasympathetic system causes bronchoconstriction whereas sympathetic system result in bronchodilation.
  • Increase in cardiac contractility is primarily action of beta 1 receptors of the heart.

 

Mnemonic

 

Point and Shoot:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ejaculation: Ejaculation is primarily mediated by the sympathetic nervous system, not the parasympathetic system. Thus, muscarinic receptor stimulation does not cause ejaculation.

 

Option C. Dilation of bronchus: The parasympathetic system causes bronchoconstriction. Bronchodilation is mediated by the sympathetic nervous system.

 

Option D. Increased cardiac contractility: Increased cardiac contractility is primarily an action of beta-1 adrenergic receptors, which are part of the sympathetic nervous system. Muscarinic receptor stimulation generally results in decreased heart rate and contractility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscarinic receptor stimulation is associated with parasympathetic responses such as erection, while sympathetic stimulation is responsible for ejaculation, bronchodilation, and increased cardiac contractility.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely regarding Rh incompatibility in a newborn?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased urine bilirubin

 

Increased urine bilirubin is the least likely finding in newborns with Rh incompatibility. Rh incompatibility occurs when the mother is Rh-negative, and the baby is Rh-positive, leading to hemolysis of the baby's red blood cells. This hemolysis releases hemoglobin, which is broken down into biliverdin and then into unconjugated bilirubin. This unconjugated bilirubin is lipid-soluble and cannot be excreted directly in the urine because it needs to be conjugated by the liver to become water-soluble. However, the enzyme required for this conjugation (glucuronyl transferase) is immature in newborns, especially in those with Rh incompatibility, leading to an accumulation of unconjugated bilirubin in the blood.

 

Unconjugated bilirubin is not excreted in the urine; instead, it is converted to urobilinogen and stercobilinogen in the intestines by bacteria, which are then excreted in the urine and feces, respectively. This process is why increased fecal urobilinogen and stercobilinogen are likely findings in Rh incompatibility. The lack of mature enzyme activity in the liver of a newborn prevents significant conjugation and excretion of bilirubin in the urine, making increased urine bilirubin an unlikely finding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased unconjugated bilirubin: This is a common finding in newborns with Rh incompatibility due to the hemolysis of red blood cells, which leads to the release of hemoglobin that is converted to unconjugated bilirubin.

 

Option B. Increased fecal urobilinogen: This is likely because unconjugated bilirubin, once processed by intestinal bacteria, is converted into urobilinogen and stercobilinogen, which are then excreted in the feces.

 

Option D. Increased stercobilinogen: Like urobilinogen, stercobilinogen is a breakdown product of bilirubin excreted in the feces, making its increase likely in Rh incompatibility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Rh incompatibility, increased urine bilirubin is unlikely due to the immaturity of the newborn's liver enzymes needed for bilirubin conjugation.

questions.text: A patient presented with paradoxical respiration. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. D

 

Explanation:

 

Paradoxical respiration occurs due to the damage of the phrenic nerve, which is marked as D, in the given image.

 

The structures marked in the image are:

 

A. Right vagus nerve

B. Left vagus nerve

C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve (inferior laryngeal nerve)

D. Right phrenic nerve

 

 

The phrenic nerve provides motor innervation to the diaphragm, the primary muscle of inspiration. Damage or paralysis of one phrenic nerve can cause one hemidiaphragm to rise during inspiration instead of descending as it normally does, leading to paradoxical movement. This is especially noticeable when the patient is in a supine position. If the right phrenic nerve is affected, the right hemidiaphragm will exhibit this paradoxical movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right vagus nerve: The vagus nerve (10th cranial nerve) has a broad distribution and is involved in the parasympathetic innervation of many organs in the thorax and abdomen. It also provides sensory innervation to the larynx, trachea, esophagus, and a portion of the external ear. It doesn't innervate the diaphragm directly for its motor function.

 

Option B. Left vagus nerve: Similarly to the right vagus, the left vagus nerve provides parasympathetic innervation to many thoracic and abdominal organs but does not control diaphragmatic contractions.

 

Option C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve (inferior laryngeal nerve): This is a branch of the vagus nerve that innervates most intrinsic muscles of the larynx. The recurrent laryngeal nerve is important for vocal cord function. Damage to this nerve can lead to hoarseness or voice changes but does not directly affect respiratory mechanics in the manner described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paradoxical movements in the chest are as follows:

 

  • Paradoxical respiration - the aberrant contraction of the abdomen or chest walls, which causes them to move in rather than out during inhalation. It appears in the flail chest.

 

Paradoxical movement of the diaphragm - Normally, during inspiration, the diaphragm descends. Yet, due to diaphragmatic paralysis in phrenic nerve palsy cases, the affected side of the diaphragm moves upward (paradoxical breathing). The gold standard test to find this is to stimulate the phrenic nerve electrically or magnetically while simultaneously recording the transdiaphragmatic pressure and/or the compound muscle action potential. Both fluoroscopy and ultrasonography can show this.

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady presented to the casualty with Hb - 5.4 g/dL, urea-86 mg/dL, creatinine- 6 mg/dL, calcium - 12 mg/dL, potassium - 4.4 mEq/L. Bone marrow aspiration shows > 60% of plasma cells. What is the next line of management? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone + Fluids

 

Features are suggestive of Multiple myeloma presenting with Mild Hypercalcemia with no pulmonary edema. Hence, treatment with steroids and IV fluids are recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dialysis is recommended if Hyperkalemia, Pulmonary edema, refractory acidosis, and Uremia.

 

Option C. Dexamethasone + lenalidomide is recommended in definitive therapy for MM along with bortezomib +/- Daratumumab (Anti CD38).

 

Option D. Bone marrow transplant is considered upfront in high-risk disease as definitive therapy.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Immediate management of a newly diagnosed multiple myeloma patient presenting with anemia, renal failure, and hypercalcemia should prioritize rapid medical intervention to stabilize the patient. This includes hydration and the use of steroids to reduce plasma cell proliferation and calcium levels. Subsequent treatments will be based on the patient’s response and overall treatment strategy.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Plasma cell dyscrasia/Chap 111

choices.text: Cryptosporidium parvum is the most common organism implicated worldwide
Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in stool
It is an obligate intracellular organism

questions.text: A patient who underwent a renal transplant 3 months ago comes with complaints of diarrhea for the last 9 days. The stool sample was subject to Kinyoun stain revealing 4-6m structures shown below. Which of the following is true about the organism? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in stool

 

Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in the stool.

 

Causative organism - Cryptosporidium hominis (more common), C.parvum

 

Causes intractable diarrhoea in immunocompromised patients.

 

Infective form - oocyst.

 

The oocyst is spherical or oval and measures about 5 μm in diameter. Oocyst does not stain with iodine and is acid-fast. The wall of the oocysts is thick, but in 20% cases, wall may be thin. These thin-walled oocysts are responsible for autoinfection.

 

Diagnosis is made by demonstration of the oocysts in feces.

 

  • A direct wet mount reveals colorless, spherical oocyst of 4-5 μm, containing large and small granules.
  • The oocysts are difficult to visualize in unstained wet preparations. Modified ZN staining is the method of choice and by this method oocysts appear as red acid-fast spheres, against a blue background.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pathogen does not show autoinfection: This is incorrect. Cryptosporidium can indeed cause autoinfection. Thin-walled oocysts are responsible for autoinfection, perpetuating the infection within the host.

 

Option B. Cryptosporidium parvum is the most common organism implicated worldwide: While Cryptosporidium parvum is a common cause, Cryptosporidium hominis is more frequently implicated in human infections worldwide.

 

Option D. It is an obligate intracellular organism: Cryptosporidium is not strictly obligate intracellular; it can survive outside the host as an oocyst.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptosporidium oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in the stool, and the infection can cause severe diarrhea, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. The oocysts are identifiable by their acid-fast property in modified Ziehl-Neelsen stains.

 

Comparative features of coccidian parasites:

questions.text: Identify the lesion as shown in the image below? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neuropathic ulcer

 

  • The provided image indicates the presence of a neuropathic ulcer.

 

Neuropathic ulcers, also known as trophic ulcers, are the result of nerve damage, typically in individuals with conditions like diabetes or peripheral neuropathy. These ulcers are often painless and can develop on the soles of the feet or other areas subject to pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial insufficiency: Arterial insufficiency ulcers are typically caused by poor blood circulation, often due to arterial disease. They often occur on the feet, toes, or lower legs and can appear as painful, pale wounds with well-defined edges. Other signs of ischemia are seen

 

 

Option C. Venous ulcers: Venous ulcers are typically caused by venous insufficiency, which leads to poor blood circulation in the legs. These ulcers often appear near the ankles and are characterized by swelling, redness, and sometimes pain.

 

 

Option D. Tuberculous ulcers: Tuberculous ulcers are a manifestation of tuberculosis infection in the skin. They are characterized by the presence of nodules or ulcers with undermined edges and a necrotic center.

 

 

Tuberculous ulcer with typical bluish undermined margins overlying sternal tuberculosis focus  

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neuropathic ulcers result from peripheral neuropathy, where lack of sensation over pressure points leads to unnoticed minor wounds or cuts, eventually developing into ulcers.
  • Features of neuropathic ulcers include painless, punched out ulcers with regular margins, commonly located on the plantar surface of the foot.
  • Ulcer margins show the presence of calluses.

choices.text: Maternal Deaths per 10,000 women in reproductive age group
Maternal Deaths per 100,000 women in reproductive age group

questions.text: Dr. Aishwarya, a public health official, is discussing the maternal health situation in a rural district of Uttar Pradesh at a Panchayat meeting. She emphasizes the importance of understanding the maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for her district. Which definition best describes the MMR? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Maternal Deaths per 100,000 live births 

 

  • MMR is Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births.
  • Maternal Mortality rate (MMR): Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births, where a ‘maternal death’ is defined as ‘death of a woman while pregnant or during delivery or within 42 days (6 weeks) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration or site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes’.
  • MMR is a ratio (Maternal mortality rate is a misnomer; MMR is not a rate)

 

 

Additional Information

 

  • MMR World: 216 per 100,000 live births; Causes of MMR (globally):
    • Hemorrhage (25%)
    • Indirect causes (20%)
    • Infection (15%)
    • Unsafe abortion (13%)
    • Eclampsia (12%)
    • Obstructed labour (8%)
  • MMR India: 97 per 100,000 live births [2023]; Causes of MMR (India) [SRS 2023]:
    • Hemorrhage (38%)
    • Other conditions (34%)
    • Sepsis (11%)
    • Abortion (8%)
    • Obstructed labour (5%)
    • Hypertensive disorders (5%)
  • Maternal mortality rate (MMRate): Dividing the average annual number of maternal deaths in a population by the average number of women of reproductive age (typically those aged 15 to 49 years) who are alive during the observation period. 

 

MMRate reflects not only the risk of maternal death per pregnancy or per birth, but also the level of fertility in a population

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MMR is a crucial indicator of maternal health in a population, reflecting the risk of maternal death associated with childbirth and its management.
  • It is typically expressed per 100,000 live births to provide a clear picture of maternal health risks and the effectiveness of health interventions aimed at reducing these risks in specific areas or populations.

questions.text: Identify the condenser? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) B

 

B: The condenser is located beneath the microscope stage and is used to focus light onto the specimen. It typically contains lenses that gather and concentrate light from the illuminator and direct it through the specimen for optimal viewing.
