Other Options

 

Option A. A: This is the coarse focusing knob, which is used to bring the specimen into general focus by moving the stage up and down.

 

Option B. C: This represents the objective lenses, which are used to magnify the specimen.

 

Option D. D: This is the illuminator, which is the light source that provides illumination for viewing the specimen.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Dr. Sharma, the head of the pediatric department at a renowned medical college in Uttar Pradesh, is conducting a training session for new medical officers. As part of the session, he aims to ensure the officers are well-versed with the national health programs related to child health. He poses the question, "Under the Rashtriya Bal Swashthya Karyakram (RBSK) initiative, which of these diseases is not covered? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Congenital glaucoma

 

  • While congenital cataract is explicitly mentioned as part of the initiative's coverage, congenital glaucoma is not typically listed among the prioritized conditions for screening under the RBSK.
  • This omission might be due to the relative rarity or specific screening requirements of congenital glaucoma compared to more commonly addressed conditions in public health programs.

 

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)

 

  • Importance: Child Health Screening and Early Intervention Services Program under National Rural Health Mission
  • Target group:
    • 0-6 years old children (Rural areas + Urban slums)
    • 6-18 years old children (Enrolled in government schools)
  • Targeted diseases (4D’s):
    • Defects at birth
    • Diseases in children
    • Deficiency conditions
    • Developmental delays including disabilities

 

Educational Objective:

 

Targeted diseases:

choices.text: Previous infection even if patient has been asymptomatic
That the patient is in window period

questions.text: The presence of antibodies against SARS CoV2 in the blood likely indicates? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Previous infection even if patient has been asymptomatic

 

The presence of antibodies against SARS CoV 2 in the blood likely indicates a previous infection even if the patient has been asymptomatic.

 

1-3 weeks after symptoms onset, SARS CoV2 antibody become detectable. At this time infectiousness is decreased and some amount of immunity from future infection has developed.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Presence of acute viral load: The presence of antibodies does not indicate an acute viral load. Acute infection is usually detected through the presence of viral RNA using PCR tests, not antibodies.

 

Option C. A high risk of reinfection: The presence of antibodies suggests that the individual has some level of immunity, which generally reduces the risk of reinfection rather than increasing it.

 

Option D. That the patient is in window period: The window period refers to the time after initial infection when antibodies are not yet detectable. Therefore, the presence of antibodies indicates that the patient is beyond the window period.

 

Educational objective

 

The presence of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 in the blood likely indicates a previous infection, which may have been asymptomatic. This serological evidence shows that the person has developed an immune response to the virus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the surgeon with a recurrent inguinal hernia. The surgeon decides to perform a hernioplasty, and the patient inquiries about the most appropriate type of mesh to be used. The surgeon wants to ensure that the patient is aware of the various types of meshes that can be used in hernioplasty. Which of the following is the most appropriate mesh for use in hernioplasty? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lightweight mesh with large pores

 

Lightweight meshes with large pores are considered the most appropriate choice for hernioplasty. They provide adequate support to repair the hernia while allowing for better tissue integration and reduced inflammation. This type of mesh is associated with lower postoperative pain and discomfort.

 

Heavyweight mesh:

 

  • Heavyweight meshes are typically not recommended for hernioplasty because they can lead to increased inflammation, tissue response, and a higher risk of complications. They may cause stiffness and discomfort in the area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most appropriate mesh to use in hernioplasty is a lightweight mesh with large pores.
  • Lightweight meshes induce a less-pronounced foreign body reaction and decreased inflammatory response, leading to better tissue incorporation, increased prosthesis compliance, and decreased patient discomfort and pain.
  • Meshes with large pores allow for increased soft tissue ingrowth and exhibit less inflammatory infiltrate, connective tissue, and scar bridging. This results in less adhesion, better tissue incorporation, and decreased patient discomfort and pain.
  • “Meshes with thinner strands and larger spaces (pores) between them are preferred because they have better tissue integration, less contracture, less foreign body reaction, more flexibility and improved comfort.” Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1063.
  • Meshes used in hernioplasty can be synthetic or biological, with synthetic meshes made from Polypropylene, Polyester, or PTFE.

questions.text: A 51-year-old bomb blast victim is brought to the casualty with life-threatening injuries. There was a lot of chaos and no one was available to sign consent for emergency surgery. Despite surgery the patient died. The doctor is not responsible under which doctrine? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Doctrine of anticipation 

 

Core Concept

 

Operating without consent in life threatening emergency

 

  • IPC Section 92 - Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent
  • This means that the doctor can perform life-saving procedures in a patient with life-threatening injuries without obtaining consent specially if delay in treatment in order to obtain consent would result in harm to the patient. 
  • This is also called as the doctrine of anticipation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Res ipsa loquitur:

 

  • It is a Latin phrase for "the thing speaks for itself."
  • Here the Negligence is so obvious that it does not require expert testimony or specific evidence to establish a breach of the standard of care.
  • The event is unusual and wouldn't occur without negligence

 

Option C. Doctrine of extended consent: suppose some another pathology is discovered during surgery then another consent is taken. This is called doctrine of extended consent

 

Option D. Doctrine of conjugated consent: Consent for multiple procedures given together

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Doctrine of anticipation," which permits medical interventions without prior consent in emergencies where delays could result in harm or death to the patient. This doctrine is crucial in understanding the legal protections afforded to doctors making critical decisions under duress and with the intent to save lives.

questions.text: GeneXpert detects mutations in which of the following genes? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) rроB

 

GeneXpert is a molecular diagnostic tool widely used for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and resistance to rifampicin. It identifies mutations in the rpoB gene, which encodes the beta subunit of RNA polymerase. These mutations are responsible for rifampicin resistance, a critical marker for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB).

 

rpoB: The target gene for rifampicin resistance detection by GeneXpert. Mutations here confer rifampicin resistance

 

WHO strongly recommends Xpert assay for the diagnosis of TB and multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB in patients with HIV infection (WHO 2013).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. inhA: The inhA gene is associated with resistance to isoniazid and ethionamide. However, GeneXpert does not detect mutations in this gene.

 

Option C. katG: The katG gene is associated with resistance to isoniazid, another key TB drug. GeneXpert does not detect mutations in this gene.

 

Option D. pncA: The pncA gene is associated with resistance to pyrazinamide. GeneXpert does not detect mutations in this gene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gene(s) involved in anti-tuberculosis drug resistance –

questions.text: A male baby born to a non-consanguineous couple develops blisters on areas of friction. Their previous baby also had similar complaints and died at the age of 2 weeks. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epidermolysis bullosa 

 

The clinical history points to a diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa congenita.

 

Epidermolysis bullosa is a mechanobullous disease characterized by blistering in areas of mechanical trauma. Blisters commonly appear on trauma-prone areas such as hands, feet, elbows, and knees. There are three types:

 

  • Epidermolysis bullosa simplex: Defective K5/K14 protein
  • Junctional epidermolysis bullosa: Defective Laminin
  • Dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa: Defective Collagen-7

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chronic bullous disorder of childhood: Incorrect. This condition presents with bullous lesions resembling a string of pearls or cluster of jewels appearance. It is an IgA-mediated immunobullous disorder manifesting in early childhood, not a congenital condition.

 

Option C. Congenital syphilis: Incorrect. Syphilitic pemphigus appears as a vesiculobullous disorder, and the VDRL test is the investigation of choice.

 

Option D. Neonatal pemphigus: Incorrect. This autoimmune disease occurs due to the transfer of maternal IgG autoantibodies to desmoglein 3. It is characterized by transient flaccid blisters and affects the skin and, rarely, mucous membranes.

 

Educational Objective:


Epidermolysis bullosa is a congenital mechanobullous disorder marked by blistering in response to minor trauma. It is vital to recognize this to differentiate from other vesiculobullous conditions and manage accordingly.

questions.text: As filtrate flows through PCT, the concentration of all of the following decreases except: (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chloride

 

Normally in the PCT, Glucose & Amino Acid maximally approx. 100% reabsorbed; Bicarbonate approx.-80-85% and about 60-70 per cent of the filtered load of sodium and water and a slightly lower percentage of filtered chloride are reabsorbed by the proximal tubule before the filtrate reaches the loops of Henle. Hence, the concentration of chloride relatively increases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amino acid: The concentration of amino acids decreases significantly as they are almost entirely reabsorbed in the PCT.

 

Option B. Glucose: Glucose concentration also decreases drastically due to nearly complete reabsorption in the PCT.

 

Option D. Bicarbonate: A large percentage of bicarbonate is reabsorbed in the PCT, leading to a decrease in its concentration in the filtrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As filtrate flows through the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), the concentration of chloride increases relative to other substances, which are more extensively reabsorbed. This includes glucose and amino acids, which are almost completely reabsorbed, and bicarbonate, which is substantially reabsorbed.

choices.text: Protects the acid labile drug from gastric acidity
Protects the gastric mucosa from irritant effects of certain drugs
Prolongs the half-life of the drug

questions.text: Many drugs are given as enteric coated tablets. All of the following are the advantages of enteric coating of drugs EXCEPT? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Prolongs the half-life of the drug

 

Enteric coatings on tablets protect acid-labile drugs from gastric acidity, protect the gastric mucosa from irritant effects, and deliver drugs distal to the stomach. However, they do not prolong the half-life of a drug, which is determined by the drug's metabolism and elimination from the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Enteric-coated drugs are designed with a special coating that resists dissolution in the acidic environment of the stomach. This coating dissolves instead in the more alkaline environment of the small intestine. The primary purposes of this enteric coating are:

 

Option A. Protect the acid-labile drug from gastric acidity: Some drugs are unstable in the acidic environment of the stomach and can be degraded before they have a chance to be absorbed. Enteric coating protects these drugs from the acidic gastric environment, ensuring they reach the intestine, where they can be absorbed effectively.

 

Option B. Protect the gastric mucosa from the irritant effects of certain drugs: Certain drugs can irritate the gastric mucosa, leading to discomfort or even ulcers. Enteric coating prevents these drugs from being released in the stomach, thereby reducing the risk of gastric irritation.

 

Option D. Deliver drugs distal to the stomach: Enteric coating is also used to ensure that a drug is released in the intestine rather than the stomach, which can be important for drugs that are intended to act in the intestine or are better absorbed from the intestinal lining.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enteric coating is primarily used to protect acid-labile drugs from gastric acidity, protect the gastric mucosa from irritant effects, and ensure drug delivery distal to the stomach. It does not prolong the half-life of the drug.

choices.text: The survival rate of graft is 95% in the first year
The life expectancy is doubled in a diabetic patient with renal transplant
The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year
The treatment of chronic rejection has improved over the last 10 years

questions.text: A diabetic nephropathy patient is an ideal candidate for renal graft transplant. Which of the following statements is true? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year

 

In the absence of graft rejection, transplantation is financially advantageous for a patient with diabetic nephropathy. When compared to two years of dialysis, transplant surgery is less expensive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Graft survival rate is ~80-82% at the end of first year.

 

Option B. The life expectancy of a patient with diabetic nephropathy is not doubled post-transplant.

 

Option D. Chronic graft rejection following renal transplantation is referred to as chronic allograft nephropathy (CAN) which consists of tubular atrophy, glomerulosclerosis, fibrosis of the renal interstitium, and fibrous thickening of the arteries.

 

HLA mismatching, acute episodes of graft rejection, age mismatch between donor and recipient, smoking, and acute episodes of graft rejection are risk factors that put a recipient at risk for long-term graft rejection. Treatment is difficult and no significant improvement has been seen over last 10 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal transplantation becomes cost-effective after the second year post-transplant for diabetic nephropathy patients compared to ongoing dialysis. This consideration, coupled with improved quality of life and potential prolongation of life expectancy, makes it a favorable option for suitable candidates.

choices.text: GI manifestations occurs at a lower radiation dose than bone marrow depression
Bone marrow suppression appear at doses greater than 1 Gy
Bone marrow suppression occurs earlier than neurovascular effects
GI manifestations occur at a lower radiation dose than neurovascular effects

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding acute radiation syndrome? (AIIMS 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. GI manifestations occurs at a lower radiation dose than bone marrow depression

 

The statement that gastrointestinal (GI) manifestations occur at a lower radiation dose than bone marrow depression is false. In acute radiation syndrome (ARS), the threshold radiation dose for GI syndrome (8-12 Gy) is higher than that for hematopoietic syndrome, which involves bone marrow suppression (2-8 Gy). Therefore, bone marrow suppression occurs at lower doses compared to GI manifestations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bone marrow suppression appears at doses greater than 1 Gy: This statement is true as bone marrow suppression typically begins to appear at doses around 2 Gy, which is greater than 1 Gy.

 

Option C. Bone marrow suppression occurs earlier than neurovascular effects: This is true as bone marrow suppression from radiation occurs at lower doses and thus earlier than neurovascular effects, which occur at the highest dose thresholds (12-100 Gy).

 

Option D. GI manifestations occur at a lower radiation dose than neurovascular effects: This is true, as GI manifestations appear at a dose range of 8-12 Gy, which is lower than the dose range for neurovascular effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute Radiation Syndrome (ARS)

 

  • Occurs with accidental exposure of very high dose radiation
  • Result of nuclear accidents

questions.text: Please identify the retractor depicted in the image below:(INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mollison's mastoid retractor

 

  • The instrument shown in the above image is Mollison's mastoid retractor.
  • It is used in mastoidectomy to retract soft tissues after incision and elevation of flaps. It is self-retaining and hemostatic.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Joll's retractor is used in thyroid surgery. It is self-retaining retractor.

 

 

Option B. Perkins retractor is used to open small incisions with minimal damage to surrounding tissues.

 

 

Option D. Langenbeck retractor is used to hold back, edges of incisions, tissue or organs

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mollison's Mastoid retractor is specifically tailored for ear surgeries, particularly mastoidectomy, where precise and sustained retraction of soft tissues is crucial. Understanding the specific applications and features of various retractors enhances surgical efficiency and safety.

questions.text: The enzyme that is not used in cholesterol synthesis? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HMG CoA lyase

 

Initially, acetoacetyl CoA is formed by condensation of two molecules of acetyl-CoA by cytosolic thiolase which then enters the cholesterol synthesis pathway along with a molecule of acetyl-CoA.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiolase: Thiolase is involved in the initial steps of cholesterol synthesis.

 

Option B. HMG CoA Reductase: HMG CoA reductase is a key enzyme in the cholesterol synthesis pathway.

 

Option C. HMG CoA Synthase: HMG CoA Synthase: HMG CoA synthase is involved in Both cholesterol synthesis and ketone body synthesis by forming HMG-CoA.

 

Educational Objective :

 

HMG CoA lyase is not used in the cholesterol synthesis pathway; it is involved in ketogenesis.

questions.text: A patient undergoes thyroid surgery, and their surgeon is aiming to minimize nerve injury during the procedure. Which of the following nerves is least likely to be injured during thyroid surgery? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Marginal mandibular nerve

 

The marginal mandibular nerve is located in the lower part of the face, near the mandible. It is not directly associated with thyroid surgery and is far less likely to be injured during the procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrent laryngeal nerve: The recurrent laryngeal nerve is one of the most critical nerves to be cautious of during thyroid surgery. It runs near or through the thyroid gland and is vulnerable to injury in region of Berry’s ligament.

 

Option B. Ansa cervicalis: The ansa cervicalis is a nerve loop formed by cervical spinal nerves. While it may be in the vicinity of thyroid surgery, it is less likely to be directly affected by the procedure compared to other nearby nerves like the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Option C. External laryngeal nerve: The external laryngeal nerve is also in the vicinity of thyroid surgery and is most commonly injured during thyroid surgery. Its main function is to supply the cricothyroid muscle.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The marginal mandibular nerve is the nerve least likely to be injured during thyroid surgery.
  • The nerve is high up, closer to the mandibular margin.
  • The ansa cervicalis may be injured if the strap muscles are not cut high enough during surgery.
  • The superior laryngeal nerve may be injured near the superior pole of the thyroid.
  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve may be injured if dissection is done below the cricoid cartilage or near the tracheoesophageal groove

questions.text: Given is a model of embryological development of the heart. Which structure develops from the area marked with red arrow?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Infundibulum

 

Explanation:

 

The marked object is the conus cordis (middle part of bulbus cordis). From this structure, the heart's infundibulum emerges.

 

The heart is represented in the model at the stage of embryology where both heart tubes have merged and are undergoing dextro-looping, or bending. During day 23 of intrauterine life, this occurs.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atria: The atria of the heart primarily develop from the primitive atrial chamber or sinus venosus, not from the conus cordis. The sinus venosus will contribute to the formation of the smooth parts of the right and left atria. The atrial appendages or auricles, however, develop from the primitive atrium.

 

Option B. Left Ventricle: The left ventricle arises mainly from the primitive ventricle of the embryonic heart tube. As the heart develops, the primitive ventricle gives rise to the muscular parts of both the left and right ventricles, but primarily the left.

 

Option D. Interventricular septum:The interventricular septum separates the right and left ventricles. It has a muscular part and a membranous part. The muscular part primarily develops from the growth of the myocardium of the primitive ventricle. The conus cordis and the truncus arteriosus contribute to the formation of the membranous part of the interventricular septum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The infundibulum, also referred as the conus arteriosus or the outflow tract, develops from the conus cordis. It represents the smooth-walled, anterior portion of the right ventricle and leads to the pulmonary trunk in the mature heart.

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)
Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient was brought to the ER after RTA, her RR is 22/min, BP is 90/60mmHg. On examination, hyper-resonance is heard over the right side of the chest. The chest X-ray performed is given below. What would be the appropriate management in this case? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

 

The given scenario of tachypnea, hypotension, hyper-resonance and x ray showing absent right broncho-vascular markings is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

 

This option correctly addresses the likely diagnosis of a pneumothorax. The initial needle insertion can decompress the tension pneumothorax, and subsequent placement of an intercostal drain allows for continuous drainage of pleural air or fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS: This option suggests inserting a needle into the 5th ICS to relieve tension pneumothorax, which can occur due to trauma. While this can be a life-saving procedure, the presence of hyper-resonance on examination suggests a pneumothorax, but it does not address the drainage of pleural fluid, which is the primary concern in this case.

 

Option C. Aspiration of the pleural fluid: Aspiration of pleural fluid may be indicated in cases of pleural effusion, but it does not address the likely pneumothorax seen in this patient's presentation.

 

Option D. No intervention needed: With the patient's clinical presentation, including respiratory distress, low blood pressure, and hyper-resonance, intervention is indeed needed. Failure to intervene could lead to worsening respiratory compromise and potentially life-threatening consequences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tension pneumothorax usually occurs due to trauma, such as a rib fracture, a puncture wound, or chest surgery, but it can also develop spontaneously in patients with underlying lung diseases, such as emphysema or cystic fibrosis.
  • Immediate treatment of tension pneumothorax is essential to prevent respiratory and cardiac arrest. The first step is to perform needle decompression, which involves inserting a large-bore needle into the affected side of the chest to release the trapped air in the triangle of safety. After that, a chest tube is inserted to further drain the air and prevent the reoccurrence of a pneumothorax.

choices.text: Tzanck cells
Pund cells

questions.text: A young male presents to the STD clinic with painful lesions as shown in the image. What is the most likely microscopic finding of the lesion? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tzanck cells

 

The clinical picture is suggestive of genital herpes.

 

Tzanck cells – multinucleate giant cells seen on Tzanck smear in herpes simplex virus infection.

 

Herpetic lesions usually begin as clusters of small bumps, then blisters, followed by open sores or ulcers. Lesions coalesce and usually heal over several weeks at various rates. Local pain is a prominent and common complaint. Patients with genital herpes may also complain of pain in the groin area secondary to local adenopathy. Women often present with complaints of genital swelling, discharge, and dysuria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pund cells: Donovan bodies are seen within large, mononuclear (Pund) cells as gram-negative intracytoplasmic cysts filled with deeply staining bodies. Seen in granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) which is a genital ulcerative disease caused by the intracellular gram-negative bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

 

Donovanosis lesions usually start as a painless papule or subcutaneous nodule. The lesions develop the classic “beefy-red” appearance due to their high vascularity. The initial lesion takes on an ulcerative morphology after minor trauma. There is usually no regional lymphadenopathy. Developing subcutaneous granulomas known as pseudo buboes is possible.

 

 

Option C. Henderson-Patterson bodies: intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies (molluscum bodies, or Henderson-Paterson bodies) are seen in molluscum contagiosum. Lesions are painless, discrete, nontender, flesh-colored, dome-shaped papules (bumps, dimples) that show a central umbilication.

 

 

Option D. Guarnieri bodies: B-type inclusions, formerly known as Guarnieri bodies are cellular features found upon microscopic inspection of epithelial cells of individuals suspected of having poxvirus or vaccinia virus.

 

Educational Objective

 

The presence of Tzanck cells, which are multinucleated giant cells, is indicative of herpes simplex virus infection. This is the most likely microscopic finding in a patient with painful genital lesions consistent with genital herpes.

questions.text: What concentration of tetanus antitoxin in the blood is considered clinically protective against tetanus? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) >0.01 IU/ml

 

  • Specific antibody concentrations greater than 0.01 IU/mL were considered protective against tetanus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aim of active Immunisation with TT:

 

  • Vaccinate the entire community
  • Ensure protective level of antitoxin ~ 0.01 IU/mL serum throughout life

questions.text: A woman with Grave's disease was taking antithyroid medication throughout her pregnancy. The baby was born with aplasia cutis congenita. Which drug could have caused this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carbimazole 

 

Carbimazole intake during the first trimester of pregnancy is associated with aplasia cutis congenita.

 

Carbimazole and methimazole are linked to teratogenic effects, including:

 

  • Aplasia cutis congenita: Congenital absence of scalp hair and skin, often accompanied by calvarial defects
  • Choanal atresia
  • Tracheoesophageal fistula
  • Fetal goiter

 

The drug of choice for treating hyperthyroidism in the first trimester is propylthiouracil (PTU) because it has a lower risk of teratogenic effects compared to carbimazole or methimazole. However, PTU use is restricted to the first trimester due to the risk of hepatotoxicity and is replaced by methimazole (or carbimazole) in the second and third trimesters.

 

Radioiodine therapy is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Levothyroxine: Incorrect. Levothyroxine is a synthetic thyroid hormone and does not have teratogenic effects.

 

Option C. Methimazole: Partially correct. Methimazole, like carbimazole, can also cause aplasia cutis congenita but was not selected in this context.

 

Option D. Hydrouracil: Incorrect. Hydrouracil is not used for treating hyperthyroidism and is not associated with teratogenic effects like aplasia cutis congenita.

 

Educational Objective:


Carbimazole and methimazole are associated with teratogenic effects, including aplasia cutis congenita, when used in early pregnancy. Propylthiouracil (PTU) is preferred in the first trimester to minimize teratogenic risks but is later replaced to avoid hepatotoxicity.

questions.text: Dialysis will prevent all except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peripheral Neuropathy

 

Dialysis is effective in removing many waste products and toxins from the blood, which can alleviate a range of symptoms associated with uremia. However, it is less effective in preventing or reversing complications that arise from the accumulation of middle molecular weight substances, such as those implicated in peripheral neuropathy.

 

 

Peripheral neuropathy in dialysis patients is largely attributed to the build-up of middle molecular weight molecules like beta 2 microglobulin, which are not efficiently removed by standard dialysis membranes. Native kidneys or high-flux dialyzers are more effective at removing these molecules, but even these can have limited efficacy. Peripheral neuropathy is thus a complication less responsive to conventional dialysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seizures: These are often caused by severe uremia or electrolyte imbalances, both of which can be effectively managed through dialysis.

 

Option B. Metabolic acidosis: Dialysis helps correct metabolic acidosis by removing excess acids from the blood and restoring bicarbonate levels.

 

Option D. Uremic pericarditis: Uremic toxins that contribute to inflammatory conditions such as pericarditis are effectively removed through dialysis, thereby preventing this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While dialysis effectively manages many complications of renal failure such as seizures, metabolic acidosis, and uremic pericarditis, it is less effective for peripheral neuropathy due to its limited ability to remove middle molecular weight toxins that contribute to nerve damage. Ongoing management and treatment strategies need to consider these limitations.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Nephrology, Dialysis

questions.text: The punishment for the death of a patient by spurious drug? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Life imprisonment 

 

  • The punishment for the death of a patient by a spurious drug is life imprisonment as it leads to grievous hurt which is punishable by life imprisonment as per Drugs and Cosmetics act.
  • Spurious or imitation drug products are drug formulations manufactured. concealing the true identity of the product and made to resemble another drug, especially some popular brand, to deceive the buyer and cash on the popularity of original product.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, the distribution of spurious drugs that result in death constitutes grievous hurt, warranting severe legal consequences including life imprisonment.

questions.text: A 3-year-old toxic child presents with tachypnea, high-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and developed difficulty in swallowing with drooling of saliva within 4-6 hours of fever. Along with airway management. Which of the following needs to be given? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IV Ceftriaxone

 

The clinical presentation of this 3-year-old child, including tachypnea, high-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, dysphagia, and drooling of saliva, suggests acute epiglottitis, a potentially life-threatening condition. Acute epiglottitis is an emergency that can result in airway obstruction due to severe inflammation of the epiglottis and surrounding structures. The management of acute epiglottitis involves the following key steps:

 

  1. Airway Management: Immediate attention to securing the airway is crucial, often requiring endotracheal intubation or, in severe cases, tracheostomy, to prevent airway obstruction.
  2. Empirical Antibiotic Therapy: IV Ceftriaxone is the antibiotic of choice for empirical treatment in acute epiglottitis. Ceftriaxone covers the most common causative organisms, including Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), which is the most frequent pathogen responsible for this condition.
  3. Dexamethasone is often used as adjunctive therapy to reduce airway edema.

 

Once the culture and sensitivity results are available, antibiotic therapy may be adjusted according to the identified pathogen. The immediate empirical use of Ceftriaxone is crucial in managing this condition until further microbiological data is obtained.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nebulisation with racemic adrenaline: This treatment is typically indicated in cases of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis), not in acute epiglottitis. Croup presents with a "barking" cough and usually a more gradual onset compared to epiglottitis.

 

Option C. Diphtheria antitoxin: This is used in the treatment of diphtheria, which presents with a characteristic thick gray pseudomembrane in the throat, and is not related to the clinical features described here. Diphtheria can also cause descending paralysis and other systemic symptoms not seen in this case.

 

Option D. Start steroids: Steroids are indicated in the management of croup to reduce airway inflammation but are not the first-line treatment in epiglottitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency requiring immediate airway management and empirical antibiotic therapy, with IV Ceftriaxone being the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following childhood injuries will lead to a fish tail injury? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Distal humerus in children

 

  • Fishtail deformity of the distal humerus is a rare delayed complication of distal humeral fractures in children characterized by a contour abnormality of the distal humerus.
  • It results from a non-developing or underdeveloped lateral trochlea.

 

 

  • It has been described after a variety of distal humeral fractures in early childhood, most commonly after supracondylar fractures, or lateral Condyle fractures.
  • If identified in a young child, surgical closure of the medial and lateral portion of the physis may prevent the deformity from progressing and would not cause significant additional humeral length discrepancy.
  • Whilst initially presumed to be a benign condition, long-term follow-up suggests that patients with fishtail deformity are prone to:
    • Functional impairment
    • Ongoing pain
    • Development of early osteoarthrosis

 

Option B. Distal radius. Distal Radius Fractures are the most common site of pediatric forearm fractures and generally occur as a result of a fall on an outstretched hand with the wrist extended. Metaphyseal fractures can be at the volar apex (colle’s fracture) or dorsal apex (Smith’s fracture) or incomplete (torus/buckle fracture). Diaphyseal fracture may involve both bone fracture, plastic deformation or greenstick fracture. Fracture with dislocation includes monteggia and galeazzi fractures.

 

 

Option D. Distal femur. Distal femur fractures in children can have various fracture patterns, including supracondylar fractures, or fractures of any pattern from the Salter-Harris classification.  Salter-Harris II fractures of the distal femur are the most common pattern in children. Even though distal femur fractures are relatively uncommon injuries, they can have significant implications for limb alignment and future growth. Distal femur fractures in children are typically related to trauma, such as falls, motor vehicle accidents, or contact sports. Patients have pain, swelling about the knee, deformity, and an inability to bear weight on the affected leg. Closed manipulation and casting is an option in displaced fractures, although they have significant potential for instability, which could lead to malunion. Internal fixation is the most commonly chosen treatments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fish tail deformity is a rare complication of distal humerus fracture in children.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes in close proximity to the area marked by the arrow in the given image? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Middle meningeal artery

 

Explanation:

 

The middle meningeal artery (MMA) is a branch of the maxillary artery (a terminal branch of the external carotid artery). The MMA enters the middle cranial fossa by passing through the foramen spinosum. After entering the skull, it courses laterally to the pterion.

 

Given the proximity of the MMA to the pterion, trauma to this region can lead to an extradural (epidural) hematoma if the MMA is torn. This is because the MMA runs just deep to the pterion, between the skull and the dura mater.

 

This makes the MMA the artery most closely related to the pterion, and a fracture at the pterion can lead to rupture of this artery.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Internal carotid artery:

 

  • The internal carotid artery (ICA) is a major artery that supplies blood to the brain. It arises from the common carotid artery and enters the cranial cavity through the carotid canal.
  • While the ICA does travel inside the skull and provides blood to the brain, it doesn't have a direct relationship with the pterion. It is more medial in its course.

 

Option C. Anterior cerebral artery:

 

  • The anterior cerebral artery is one of the terminal branches of the internal carotid artery. It supplies the medial and superior parts of the brain.
  • Though it's an essential artery for cerebral circulation, it doesn't have a direct relationship with the pterion, as its course and distribution are more medial.

 

Option D. Deep temporal artery:

 

  • The deep temporal arteries are branches of the maxillary artery that ascend between the temporalis muscle and the side of the skull.
  • They supply the temporalis muscle, and while they are in the vicinity of the pterion, they are not as closely related as the middle meningeal artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterion is an H shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

 

  • Frontal bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Parietal bone.

 

Given that it rests across the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and the lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere, it is a significant structure. Since the bone in this region is fragile, any injury could cause the middle meningeal artery to burst, resulting in an extradural hematoma.

choices.text: SBP > 140 mm Hg and DBP < 90 mmHg

questions.text: All of the factors would suggest a higher risk for a patient with TIA developing stroke in the future according to ABCD2 scoring except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Age < 60 years

 

The ABCD2 score is a clinical tool used to predict the short-term risk of stroke after a transient ischemic attack (TIA). The scoring system includes several factors that help assess this risk. Here’s why option A is the correct answer:

 

  • Age < 60 years: According to the ABCD2 scoring system, a patient who is aged 60 years or older scores 1 point, indicating a higher risk. Therefore, being younger than 60 does not contribute to an increased score, making it the correct choice for the exception in this question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duration of TIA > 5 mins: In the ABCD2 score, the duration of the TIA is an important factor. TIA lasting 10-59 minutes scores 1 point, and TIA lasting more than 60 minutes scores 2 points. Duration less than 10 minutes would score 0. However, since the option simply says "Duration of TIA > 5 mins," without specifying how much longer, it's less clearly defined in this question, but generally longer durations imply a higher score.

 

Option C. SBP > 140 mm Hg and DBP < 90 mmHg: High blood pressure at the time of TIA, defined as SBP ≥ 140 mm Hg or DBP ≥ 90 mm Hg, scores 1 point in the ABCD2 score.

 

Option D. Diabetes: The presence of diabetes in a patient who has experienced a TIA adds 1 point to the ABCD2 score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Additional D3-Dual TIA (within 7 days of first TIA), Imaging (MRI, DWI) were added to original score. However, all these perform very poorly in the light of recent evidences.

choices.text: 2 and 4 are correct
1, 3 and 5 are correct
1, 4 and 5 are correct
2, 4 and 5 are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding mechanisms of depolarization, Repolarization, and hyperpolarization in a skeletal muscle action potential?(INICET May 2020)

 

  1. Depolarization due to influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels
  2. Depolarization due to influx of Na+ through ligand-gated channels
  3. Repolarization due to efflux of K+ through a voltage-gated channel
  4. Repolarization due to efflux of K+ through a ligand-gated channel
  5. Hyperpolarization due to efflux of K+
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3 and 5 are correct

 

Action potential in skeletal muscle:

 

During the onset of depolarization, voltage gated sodium channels open and there is slow influx of Na+. When depolarization reaches 7 to 10 mV, the voltage gated Na+ channels start opening at a faster rate. It is called Na+ channel activation. When the firing level is reached, the influx of Na+ is very great and it leads to overshoot.

 

But the Na+ transport is short lived. It is because of rapid inactivation of Na+ channels. Thus, the Na+ channels open and close quickly. At the same time, the K+ channels start opening. This leads to efflux of K+ out of the cell, causing repolarization.

 

Unlike the Na+ channels, the K+ channels remain open for longer duration. These channels remain opened for few more milliseconds after completion of repolarization. It causes efflux of a greater number of K+ producing more negativity inside. It is the cause for hyperpolarization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2 and 4 are correct: Incorrect. Depolarization in skeletal muscle is due to the influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels. Repolarization is due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels.

 

Option C. 1, 4 and 5 are correct: Incorrect. Repolarization is due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels.

 

Option D. 2, 4 and 5 are correct: Incorrect. Depolarization in skeletal muscle is due to the influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels, and repolarization is due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In skeletal muscle action potential, depolarization occurs due to the influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels, repolarization occurs due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, and hyperpolarization is caused by the prolonged efflux of K+.

choices.text: First assessment with sonography in trauma
Focussed assessment with sonography in trauma

questions.text: The acronym FAST refers to: (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Focused assessment with sonography in trauma

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • FAST stands for Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma and is a non-invasive, rapid bedside test that uses sonography to detect free fluid in the abdomen.
  • It is used to evaluate patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries and can be performed within 2-4 minutes.
  • The subxiphoid transverse view is used to assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries.
  • The longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant is used to assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch.
  • The longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant is used to assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury.
  • The transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region are used to assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas.
  • eFAST is an extended version of FAST that incorporates left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and hemothorax.

choices.text: Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid

questions.text: Which of the following is the antidote for fibrinolytic therapy? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid


Fibrinolytic therapy involves the use of drugs (like alteplase, streptokinase, etc.) to break down blood clots. Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid (EACA) and tranexamic acid are antifibrinolytic agents that can be used to counteract bleeding due to excessive fibrinolysis, which can occur during or after fibrinolytic therapy. These work by inhibiting plasminogen activators and, to a lesser degree, plasmin activity, thereby reducing the breakdown of fibrin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protamine Sulphate: This is used as an antidote for heparin overdose, not for fibrinolytic therapy. Protamine sulphate binds to and inactivates heparin.

 

Option B. Dalteparin: Dalteparin is a low molecular weight heparin and is an anticoagulant itself. It is not used as an antidote for fibrinolytic therapy.

 

Option D. Alteplase: Alteplase is a fibrinolytic agent, not an antidote. It is used to dissolve blood clots in conditions like acute ischemic stroke, pulmonary embolism, and myocardial infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid is the antidote for fibrinolytic therapy, used to counteract excessive bleeding due to fibrinolysis. It works by inhibiting plasminogen activators and stabilizing clots.

questions.text: Which of the following tests are used for the evaluation of scoliosis?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bending forward

 

SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Scoliosis is characterized by lateral curvature of the spine associated with rotation of the involved vertebrae and classified by its anatomic location, in either the thoracic or lumbar spine, with rare involvement of the cervical spine.
  • Clinical Findings:
    • Scoliosis in adolescents does not typically cause significant pain.
    • If a patient has significant pain, she/he should be evaluated to rule out the possibility of some other disorder such as infection or tumor.
    • Deformity of the rib cage and asymmetry of the waistline are clinically evident for curvatures of 30 degrees or more.
    • Lesser curves may be detected through a forward bending test (Adam’s test), which is designed to detect early abnormalities of rotation that may not be apparent when the patient is standing erect.
    • Structural curve becomes more prominent on forward bending as opposed to postural scoliosis.
    • Rotation of the spine may be measured with a scoliometer.
    • Rotation is associated with a marked rib hump as the lateral curvature increases in severity.
       
  • Imaging:
    • Radiographs taken of the entire spine in the standing position in both the posterior anterior (PA) and lateral planes are the most valuable for diagnosis.
    • Usually, a primary curve is evident with compensatory curvature to balance the body.
       
  • Treatment:
    • Treatment of scoliosis depends on the curve magnitude, skeletal maturity, and risk of progression.
    • Specific management is dependent on the Cobb angle, measured on a standing PA X-ray of the spine.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Scoliosis curve evaluation is done by forward bending test/Adam’s test.
  • A structural scoliotic curve becomes more prominent on forward bending while the postural curve disappears.

questions.text: A TPN bag consists of 100g glucose, 30g amino acids, and 40g lipids. What is the amount of calories delivered? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 880 Kcal

 

In patients who cannot (unconscious; removal of large part of gut) or should not (major trauma or surgery) use their gastrointestinal tract, total parenteral feeding has to be resorted. The solution may be infused through one of the large vessels like subclavian vein or superior vena cava, where the blood flow is sufficient to dilute the hypertonic solution. This procedure is known as total parenteral nutrition (TPN) or intravenous hyperalimentation.

 

The number of calories delivered by the given TPN (Total Parenteral Nutrition) bag is 880 Kcal.

 

The caloric values of different food components are:

• Carbohydrate (glucose) - 4KCal/g

• Proteins (amino acids) - 4.2KCal/g = ~4KCal/g

• Fat (lipids) - 9Kcal/g

 

Calculation of the number of calories:

• 100 gm of glucose = 100 × 4 KCal=400 KCal

• 30 gm of amino acids = 30 × 4 KCal= 120 KCal

• 40 gm of lipids = 40 × 9 KCal= 360 KCal

Total amount of calories delivered= 400+120+360=880 Kcal

 

Note: The caloric value of alcohol is 7KCal/g.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) is a method used to deliver nutrients directly into the bloodstream when patients cannot use their gastrointestinal tract. The caloric value of the nutrients provided in the TPN bag can be calculated based on the caloric content of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats.

 

Caloric Values:

 

  • Carbohydrates (glucose): 4 KCal/g
  • Proteins (amino acids): Approximately 4 KCal/g
  • Fats (lipids): 9 KCal/g

choices.text: Produces NLF producing colonies in MacConkey agar

questions.text: All of the following is true regarding scrub typhus except: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Produces NLF producing colonies in MacConkey agar

 

Causative organism – Orientia tsutsugamushi (an obligate intracellular Gram-negative bacterium).

 

They cannot grow on cell free media. They are readily cultivated in yolk sac of developing chick embryos. They also grow on mouse fibroblast, HeLa, Hep-2, Detroit 6 and other continuous cell lines.

 

Vector - Infected chiggers (trombiculid mite larvae).

 

Host: A number of small rodents particularly wild rats of subgenus Rattus are the natural hosts for scrub typhus. Human infection takes place when man accidentally picks up an infective larval mite while walking, sitting, or lying on the infested ground.

 

The adult mites have a four-stage lifecycle: egg, larva, nymph and adult.

 

The larva is the only stage (chigger) that can transmit the disease to humans and other vertebrates, since the other life stages (nymph and adult) do not feed on vertebrate animals. Both the nymph and the adult are free-living in the soil.

 

Signs and Symptoms- Fever and chills, Headache, Body aches and muscle pain. Dark, scab-like region at the site of the chigger bite (also known as eschar). Mental changes, ranging from confusion to coma. Enlarged lymph nodes and rash are also seen.

 

Diagnosis of scrub typhus that includes enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), immunofluorescence assay (IFA), immunochromatographic test (ICT), Weil–Felix, polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transmitted by chiggers: This is true. Scrub typhus is transmitted by the larvae (chiggers) of trombiculid mites.

 

Option B. Lymphadenopathy is a feature: This is true. Enlarged lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy) are a common feature of scrub typhus.

 

Option D. Man is an accidental host: This is true. Humans are accidental hosts who become infected when they come into contact with infected chiggers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is an obligate intracellular bacterium that cannot grow on cell-free media like MacConkey agar. It requires living cells for its cultivation. Scrub typhus is transmitted by chiggers and features symptoms such as fever, lymphadenopathy, and a characteristic eschar at the site of the bite. Humans are accidental hosts for this infection.

questions.text: A gynecologist performs a hysterectomy for endometrial carcinoma. Despite the adequate precaution, the ureter was injured intraoperatively. The gynecologist is not held responsible under? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medical maloccurence 

 

The gynecologist cannot be held responsible for the above act under medical maloccurence.

 

Medical maloccurence/Inevitable Accident: 

 

  • It is defined as an unfavorable outcome, but not resulting from malpractice.
  • Despite giving best treatment patient may fail to respond properly or may suffer some adverse reactions of the drug leading to temporary or permanent deformities. This is known as a medical maloccurence/inevitable accident.
  • If the doctor can prove this before the court, it will be an absolute defense against malpractice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Novus actus interveniens: This legal term refers to a new intervening act that breaks the chain of causation, leading to a result that might not have been foreseeable. This does not apply here as the injury was directly related to the surgical procedure, not an external unrelated event.

 

Option C. Res ipsa loquitor: Latin for "the thing speaks for itself," this doctrine applies in cases where the injury would not typically occur without negligence. This option would suggest a presumption of negligence because such injuries usually do not occur without a breach in the standard of care. However, the context given indicates precautions were taken, so this is not the best answer.

 

Option D. Physician error: This implies a mistake made by the physician that could lead to legal liability. In this scenario, it was noted that all standard precautions were followed, thus excluding this option as the appropriate answer given that no specific error or negligence was cited.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medical maloccurence is critical to understand that not all adverse outcomes in medicine result from negligence. Some are inherent risks of medical procedures despite the highest standards of care. Recognizing this helps in managing patient expectations and can protect healthcare providers in cases where complications arise despite proper precautions.

questions.text: Identify the equipment shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High flow nasal cannula

 

  • Components:
    • Flow generator: This delivers a continuous flow of medical gas, which can be up to 60 liters per minute (L/min) or more in some devices.
    • Heated humidifier: The gas is passed through a humidifier, which warms and saturates the gas with water vapor, providing near 100% humidity. This prevents mucosal drying and enhances mucociliary clearance.
    • Nasal cannula: Despite the term "nasal cannula," the prongs for HFNC are broader and shorter than traditional cannulas. They don't completely occlude the nares, allowing for the patient to breathe room air in addition to the provided gas mixture if needed.

 

Mechanism of Action:

 

  • Gas Conditioning: The humidified and warmed gas ensures better comfort and reduced airway resistance, potentially improving mucociliary function.
  • PEEP Effect: The high flow rates create a degree of positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) in the nasopharynx. This can be beneficial in preventing alveolar collapse and can recruit alveoli, improving oxygenation.
  • Enhanced CO2 Washout: HFNC reduces the anatomical dead space in the nasopharynx, aiding in more efficient removal of carbon dioxide.
  • Continuous High Flow: The high flow rates ensure that the fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) is more consistent, irrespective of the patient's respiratory pattern.

 

Advantages:

 

  • Better oxygenation: By delivering higher flow rates, HFNC can achieve better and more consistent oxygenation compared to standard oxygen therapy.
  • Comfort: Patients often find HFNC more comfortable than non-invasive positive pressure ventilation masks.
  • Flexibility: Patients can eat, drink, and communicate while using HFNC.

 

Indications:

 

  • Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure: Especially if caused by conditions like pneumonia or pulmonary edema.
  • Post-extubation support: In patients at risk for reintubation.
  • During procedures: Like bronchoscopy, to maintain oxygenation.
  • In conditions like COPD and asthma: It may aid in CO2 washout.

 

Limitations and Contraindications:

 

  • Severe hypercapnic respiratory failure: HFNC doesn't provide as much ventilation support as bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP) or mechanical ventilation.
  • Uncooperative or unconscious patients: Due to aspiration risk.
  • Facial trauma or recent facial surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mechanical ventilator: A mechanical ventilator is a device used to support or replace spontaneous breathing. It is more complex and provides controlled ventilation through an endotracheal tube or tracheostomy.

 

Option B. Infusion pump: An infusion pump delivers fluids, such as nutrients and medications, into a patient's body in controlled amounts. It is not related to respiratory support.

 

Option C. CPAP machine: A Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) machine delivers a continuous level of positive airway pressure to keep the airways open. It is commonly used in sleep apnea but does not provide the high flow rates and humidification characteristic of HFNC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • High flow nasal cannula (HFNC) is a respiratory support system that delivers high flow rates of humidified and warmed oxygen, providing benefits such as improved oxygenation, patient comfort, and flexibility in use.

choices.text: Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, induced labour
Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, spontaneous labour
Multiparous without previous CS, spontaneous labour
Multiparous without previous CS, induced/CS before labour

questions.text: Modified Robson's classification class 1 includes: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, spontaneous labour

 

Class 1 of the Modified Robson's classification specifically includes:

 

  • Nulliparous: A woman who has never given birth before.
  • Singleton: A pregnancy involving only one fetus.
  • Cephalic: The fetal presentation is head-down.
  • ≥37 weeks: The pregnancy is at or beyond 37 weeks of gestation.
  • Spontaneous labour: Labour onset is spontaneous, not induced or via cesarean section.

 

This classification is used to categorize pregnant women for analyzing obstetric outcomes, interventions, and cesarean section rates. The Modified Robson’s classification is a system developed by the World Health Organization to help in understanding and comparing cesarean section rates and labor outcomes across different settings.

 

 

Robson’s 10 groups

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, induced labour: This option describes Class 2 of the Modified Robson's classification, which includes nulliparous women with a singleton cephalic fetus who are ≥37 weeks and have induced labor or a cesarean section before labor.

 

Option C. Multiparous without previous CS, spontaneous labour: This option describes Class 3 of the Modified Robson's classification, which includes multiparous women (without previous cesarean section) with a singleton cephalic fetus who are ≥37 weeks and are in spontaneous labor.

 

Option D. Multiparous without previous CS, induced/CS before labour: This option describes Class 4 of the Modified Robson's classification, which includes multiparous women (without previous cesarean section) with a singleton cephalic fetus who are ≥37 weeks and have induced labor or a cesarean section before labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Class 1 of the Modified Robson's classification includes nulliparous women with a singleton cephalic fetus who are ≥37 weeks and are in spontaneous labor.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/259512/9789241513197-eng.pdf?sequence=1

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after sustaining multiple injuries in a motor vehicle accident. The patient is hemodynamically unstable and requires a massive blood transfusion. The physician is concerned about the potential adverse effects of the transfusion and wants to monitor the patient closely. The physician wants to confirm which of the following adverse effects is not commonly observed in patients who receive a massive blood transfusion? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypercalcemia

 

This is not a common adverse effect of blood transfusions. Blood transfusions are more likely to cause hypocalcemia due to citrate binding calcium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypocalcemia: It can occur after a massive blood transfusion because citrate, an anticoagulant used in blood storage bags, can bind to calcium, reducing its levels when the transfused blood is administered. Citrate is used to prevent blood clotting during storage but can have this effect when transfused.

 

Option C. Hypokalemia: It can rarely occur after a massive blood transfusion because of dilution of recipient’s blood potassium.

 

Option D. Hyperkalemia: This is a potential adverse effect of a massive blood transfusion. Stored blood cells can undergo lysis leading to higher potassium levels in the blood products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypocalcemia and not Hypercalcemia is an adverse effect of massive blood transfusion.
  • Massive blood transfusion instead leads to Hypocalcemia as the anticoagulant citrate binds to calcium.

 

The complications of massive blood transfusion are:

 

  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypothermia
  • Alkalosis

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presented with burns injury. She is covered with burns on her head and neck, both upper limbs, front and back of the chest. Calculate the percentage of burns? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 45%

 

To calculate the percentage of burns, the "Rule of Nines" is commonly used in medicine. According to this rule, each area of the body is assigned a percentage value.

 

For example, the head and neck are typically assigned 9%, each upper limb is assigned 9% (18% total for both), and the front and back of the chest are assigned 18%. When we add these percentages together, we get a total of 45% burns.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The percentage of burns calculated in the given patient is 45% according to Wallace's rule of nine.

 

Calculation:

 

  • Burns on the head & neck would account for 9% of burns.
  • Burns on both upper limbs (9% for each limb) would add to 18%
  • Burns on both sides of the chest would account for 18%

Therefore, the total percentage of burns in the given patient is 9+18+18 = 45%

 

Wallace's rule of nine:

questions.text: Isotype switching is seen in? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Activated B cells  

 

Isotype switching is seen in activated B cells.

 

Isotype switching: Conversion of one antibody class (isotype) to another resulting from the genetic rearrangement of heavy-chain constant-region genes in activated B cells.

 

Isotype switching is dependent on the presence of both antigens and cytokines secreted by T-cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Helper T cells: While Helper T cells (especially Th2 cells) provide the necessary cytokines that drive isotype switching in B cells, they themselves do not undergo isotype switching.

 

Option C. Cytotoxic T cells: Cytotoxic T cells (CD8+ T cells) are involved in killing infected or cancerous cells and do not produce antibodies or undergo isotype switching.

 

Option D. Naive B cells: Naive B cells, which have not yet encountered their specific antigen, initially produce IgM and IgD. They do not undergo isotype switching until after activation by an antigen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isotype switching is a process that occurs in activated B cells, allowing them to produce different classes of antibodies to effectively combat various types of pathogens.

questions.text: 50yr old male presenting with diffuse back pain; Cervical spine Xray shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. DISH

 

Explanation:

 

The age more than 50 yrs. and diffuse flowing ossification with no joint fusion and normal iv-disc space favors a diagnosis of DISH.

 

Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH), also known as Forestier disease, is a common condition characterized by bony proliferation of the spine affecting elderly individuals. On imaging, it is typically characterized by the flowing ossification of the anterior longitudinal ligament involving the thoracic spine.

 

There is no involvement of the sacroiliac synovial joints.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ankylosing spondylitis: This condition would typically present with a "bamboo spine" appearance, resulting from fusion across the intervertebral disc spaces and sacroiliac joints, which is not evident in this X-ray.

 

Option C. Klippel-Feil syndrome: This syndrome involves congenital fusion of any two of the cervical vertebrae, which does not match the findings in this X-ray.

 

Option D. Sprengel deformity: This refers to an abnormally high scapula, a condition unrelated to the spinal changes observed in the X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DISH or Forestier's disease is recognized radiologically by its classic flowing ossification along the spine's anterior longitudinal ligament, sparing joint spaces and disc heights, often seen in individuals older than 50 years without signs of sacroiliac joint involvement.

 

DISH VS   Ankylosing spondylitis

questions.text: A psychiatric patient was started on lithium for the management of bipolar disorder. To monitor the blood lithium levels, at what time interval should the blood sample be collected after the administration of lithium tablets? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. After 12 hours

 

Lithium has a very narrow therapeutic index; therefore, the blood levels of lithium have to be monitored. Blood samples to measure lithium levels are typically collected 12 hours after the last dose. This timing is chosen because it represents the 'trough' level – the lowest concentration of the drug in the bloodstream before the next dose is due. Measuring at this point helps to ensure that the lithium level stays within the therapeutic range and avoids toxicity.

 

Plasma Levels of Lithium:

 

  • For prophylaxis of mania – 0.5 – 0.7 mEq/L
  • For acute mania – 0.8 – 1.2 mEq/L
  • Toxicity is seen when it is > 1.5 mEq/L
  • Dialysis is required at levels >4 mEq/L

 

Educational Objective:

 

To monitor lithium levels accurately and ensure they remain within the therapeutic range, blood samples should be collected 12 hours after the last dose. This helps in avoiding toxicity and ensuring the efficacy of the treatment for bipolar disorder.

choices.text: Human cells can divide a finite number of times only
Free radical oxidation level is unrestricted
RNA polymerase can function for a finite number of times only

questions.text: What is true about the Hayflick limit? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Human cells can divide a finite number of times only

 

Leonard Hayflick discovered that cultured normal human cells have limited capacity to divide, after which they become senescent — a phenomenon now known as the ‘Hayflick limit’.

 

Each time a cell undergoes mitosis, the telomeres on the ends of each chromosome shorten slightly. Cell division will cease once telomeres shorten to a critical length. Hayflick interpreted his discovery to be aging at the cellular level. The aging of cell populations appears to correlate with the overall physical aging of an organism. Normal human fetal cell population will divide between 40 and 60 times in cell culture before entering a senescence phase. However, this limit does not apply to stem cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Free radical oxidation level is unrestricted: Free radical oxidation is related to oxidative stress and damage but is not directly related to the Hayflick limit.

 

Option C. Telomerase activity is unrestricted: In most somatic cells, telomerase activity is limited, leading to telomere shortening. However, certain cells like stem cells and cancer cells exhibit higher telomerase activity, allowing them to bypass the Hayflick limit.

 

Option D. RNA polymerase can function for a finite number of times only: RNA polymerase activity is not directly linked to the Hayflick limit and does not have a finite number of times it can function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hayflick limit describes the finite number of times that normal human cells can divide before they become senescent, primarily due to telomere shortening.

questions.text: Ammonia in the brain is detoxified to form? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutamine

 

First Line of Defense (Trapping of Ammonia) - Being highly toxic, ammonia should be eliminated or detoxified, as and when it is formed. Even very minute quantity of ammonia may produce toxicity in central nervous system. But, ammonia is always produced by almost all cells, including neurons. The intracellular ammonia is immediately trapped by glutamic acid to form glutamine, especially in brain cells. The glutamine is then transported to liver, where the reaction is reversed by the enzyme glutaminase. The ammonia thus generated is immediately detoxified into urea. Aspartic acid may also undergo similar reaction to form asparagine.

 

 

Ammonia trapping as glutamine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urea: Urea is the primary form of nitrogen excretion in the liver, but it is not the form in which ammonia is detoxified in the brain.

 

Option C. Ammonium ions: Ammonium ions can be a form of ammonia detoxification in the kidney, but not the primary method in the brain.

 

Option D. Alanine: Alanine plays a role in transporting ammonia from muscle to the liver, but it is not the primary detoxification product in the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the brain, ammonia is detoxified by converting it to glutamine, which is then transported to the liver for further detoxification into urea.

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is primarily secreted by the region labeled ‘A’ in the given coronal section of the brain? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Dopamine

 

Explanation:

 

The substantia nigra is the region highlighted in the illustration (meaning- dark substance). Dopamine is the neurotransmitter released by this region.

 

A component of the nigrostriatal pathway is the substantia nigra. Parkinson's disease may be caused by the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetylcholine (ACh):

 

  • Acetylcholine is a neurotransmitter that plays key roles in the peripheral nervous system (PNS) and central nervous system (CNS).
  • In the PNS, ACh is the neurotransmitter released from the axon terminals of motor neurons, making muscles contract. It's also the neurotransmitter in all autonomic ganglia.
  • In the CNS, ACh is involved in a variety of functions, such as attention, arousal, and memory. Loss of cholinergic neurons in the brain, especially in the basal nucleus of Meynert, has been linked with Alzheimer's disease.
  • However, ACh is not the primary neurotransmitter of the substantia nigra.

 

Option C. Glutamine:

 

  • It's worth noting that there's a potential mix-up in the options: Glutamine is an amino acid, while "glutamate" is the neurotransmitter.
  • Glutamate is the primary excitatory neurotransmitter in the CNS and plays crucial roles in synaptic plasticity, which is the cellular basis for learning and memory.
  • While glutamate is widespread in the brain, it's not the primary neurotransmitter of the substantia nigra.

 

Option D. Noradrenaline :

 

  • Noradrenaline is both a hormone and a neurotransmitter. It plays roles in attention, focus, and the fight-or-flight response by preparing the body to react to threats.
  • In the CNS, noradrenergic neurons primarily arise from the locus coeruleus in the pons and project to various regions of the brain, influencing attention, arousal, and mood.
  • While noradrenaline plays a role in various brain functions, it's not the neurotransmitter secreted by the substantia nigra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dopamine:

 

Dopamine is one of the major neurotransmitters in the brain and is involved in several key functions, including mood regulation, reward-seeking behavior, and motor control.

 

The substantia nigra, specifically its pars compacta region, contains dopaminergic neurons that project to the striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen). This pathway is known as the nigrostriatal pathway and is critical for regulating voluntary movement.

 

Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra is the primary pathological feature of Parkinson's disease, leading to motor symptoms such as bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not need dose adjustment in renal failure? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Linagliptin

 

Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes. Unlike other DPP-4 inhibitors, linagliptin is primarily excreted via the enterohepatic system, with only a small fraction eliminated by the kidneys. Therefore, it does not require dose adjustments in patients with renal impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sitagliptin: This DPP-4 inhibitor is primarily excreted by the kidneys, and its dose usually needs to be adjusted in patients with renal impairment.

 

Option B. Saxagliptin: Saxagliptin and its active metabolite are primarily eliminated by the kidneys, necessitating dose adjustments in patients with renal failure.

 

Option C. Vildagliptin: Vildagliptin is partially excreted by the kidneys, and dose adjustment is recommended in patients with moderate to severe renal impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Linagliptin is a unique DPP-4 inhibitor that does not require dose adjustments in patients with renal failure due to its primary excretion via the enterohepatic system. This makes it an advantageous option for managing type 2 diabetes in patients with compromised renal function.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are related to the same core pathology except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alzheimer’s disease

 

Alzheimer's disease is a 3-amyloidopathy characterized by the accumulation of Aβ amyloid protein not an alpha-synucleinopathy.

 

Alpha-synucleinopathies:  A neurodegenerative disorders displaying an altered α-synuclein (αS) in the brain tissue and incorporates clinical entities such as Parkinson disease (PD), PD with dementia, dementia with Lewy bodies, and multiple-system atrophy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parkinson's disease: An alpha-synucleinopathy characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein in Lewy bodies within the substantia nigra.

 

Option C. Lewy body dementia: Another alpha-synucleinopathy where alpha-synuclein aggregates are found in Lewy bodies within the cortical and subcortical areas of the brain.

 

Option D. Multisystem atrophy: A neurodegenerative disorder also categorized as an alpha-synucleinopathy, where alpha-synuclein accumulates in glial cytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alzheimer's disease is characterized by the accumulation of β-amyloid and tau proteins, differentiating it from alpha-synucleinopathies like Parkinson's disease, Lewy body dementia, and multisystem atrophy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male arrives at the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. The patient's vital signs are stable, and a focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) is ordered. Which condition is least likely to be diagnosed using FAST? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retroperitoneal hematoma

 

Detecting retroperitoneal hematoma is challenging with FAST because it is located deep within the abdominal cavity, behind the peritoneum. FAST primarily focuses on the pericardium, pleura, and peritoneum, making it less suitable for detecting retroperitoneal injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pericardial Effusion: FAST is effective at detecting pericardial effusions. It involves examining the pericardial sac for fluid accumulation with probe placed in epigastrium.

 

Option B. Pneumothorax: eFAST can detect pneumothorax to some extent by visualizing the pleural space for the presence of air.

 

Option D. Renal Injury: FAST can detect renal injuries by examining the perinephric space for signs of bleeding or fluid accumulation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Among the given options, FAST is the least effective in diagnosing retroperitoneal hematoma due to poor sensitivity of ultrasound for detecting it.
  • CT scan is the preferred diagnostic tool for retroperitoneal injuries, but it should only be performed on hemodynamically stable patients.
  • FAST stands for Focussed Assessment with Sonography for Trauma and is a non-invasive, rapid bedside test used to detect free fluid in the abdomen using sonography.
  • The patient is positioned supine, and a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer is used to scan the subxiphoid, right and left upper quadrants, and suprapubic region to assess potential thoracoabdominal injuries.
  • eFAST is an extended version of FAST that incorporates left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and hemothorax.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with history of fever with bloody diarrhea 2 weeks back, followed by swollen, red and erythematous joints. What is the likely cause? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Shigella

 

REACTIVE ARTHRITIS/REITER’S SYNDROME

 

  • The patient presents with a classic picture of reactive arthritis. 

  • Reactive arthritis is precipitated by antecedent gastrointestinal and genitourinary infections and manifests as an asymmetric sterile oligoarthritis, typically of the lower extremities.

  • Reactive arthritis occurs most commonly in young men and is associated with HLA-B27 in 80% of patients.

  • Etiopathogenesis:

    • Most cases of reactive arthritis develop within 1-4 weeks after either a gastrointestinal infection (usually with Shigella, Salmonella, Yersinia, or Campylobacter) or a sexually transmitted infection (with Chlamydia trachomatis or perhaps Ureaplasma urealyticum).

  • Clinical Features:
