    • The arthritis is most commonly asymmetric and frequently involves the large weight-bearing joints (chiefly the knee and ankle). 

    • Sacroiliitis or ankylosing spondylitis is observed in at least 20% of patients, especially after frequent recurrences.

    • Triad: Arthritis + Conjunctivitis + Urethritis/Cervivitis (in females)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotavirus. Rotavirus is a common cause of viral gastroenteritis, particularly in infants and young children. Typical symptoms among children with rotavirus infection include vomiting; watery, non-bloody diarrhea; and fever. In severe cases, dehydration, seizures, and death can occur. It is not commonly associated with reactive arthritis.

 

Option C. E.coli. While some strains of E. coli (like enterohemorrhagic E. coli O157:H7) can cause bloody diarrhea, and some E. coli infections have been linked to reactive arthritis, Shigella is more classically and frequently associated with it, especially given the history of fever and bloody diarrhea.

 

Option D. Giardia. Giardia is a parasite that causes giardiasis, characterized by watery, foul-smelling diarrhea, gas, and abdominal cramps. It is not typically associated with reactive arthritis. Inflammatory arthritis has been described following enteric infections with Giardia sp. The interval between the preceding infection and the manifestation of arthritis is 2-4 weeks. Post-infectious arthritis has a predilection for joints of the lower limbs particularly the knee and ankle. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Joint infection can occur as a manifestation of gastrointestinal infection from pathogen Shigella. 

  • This is most commonly found, and is called reactive arthritis, which causes joint swelling, pain and erythema. 

  • It is commonly associated with HLA B27.

choices.text: It may lead to pugilistic ear
It is caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space
All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented at the hospital with a reported history of ear trauma. Upon examination, there was observed swelling, tenderness, and discoloration of the ear. Which of the following is false regarding the given image?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Resolves spontaneously

 

The condition depicted in the image is perichondrial hematoma, commonly resulting from blunt trauma to the ear. This condition does not resolve spontaneously and requires medical intervention to prevent complications such as infection or the permanent deformity known as cauliflower ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It may lead to pugilistic ear: This is true. If untreated, the hematoma can lead to fibrosis and calcification, causing a deformity known as cauliflower ear or pugilistic ear.

 

Option B. It is caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space: True. The swelling and discoloration are due to blood accumulating in the perichondrial space, which separates the ear cartilage from the overlying skin.

 

Option D. All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics: This is considered a good practice to prevent infection, especially since the ear's vascular supply is compromised, increasing the risk of perichondritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perichondrial hematoma does not resolve on its own and requires prompt medical treatment to prevent complications like infection and the formation of cauliflower ear. Management typically involves aspiration of the hematoma, application of a pressure dressing to maintain ear contour, and administration of prophylactic antibiotics to prevent infection.

choices.text: Toluidine blue 'O' and malachite green
Carbol fuschin and methylene blue
Carbol fuschin and malachite green
Toluidine and methylene blue

questions.text: A patient has complained of fever with chills. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils. Albert staining is to be done. What are the constituents of Albert's stain? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toluidine blue ‘O’ and malachite green

 

Albert stain is a type of differential stain used for staining high-molecular-weight polymers of polyphosphate known as metachromatic granules or volutin granules found in Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Metachromatic granules are also found in Yersinia pestis, and Mycobacterium species.

 

Albert stain is composed of two reagents:

 

  • Albert’s A solution consist of
    • Toluidine blue - 0.15 gm
    • Malachite green - 0.20 gm
    • Glacial acetic acid - 1 ml
    • Alcohol (95% ethanol) - 2ml

 

Dissolve the dyes in alcohol and add to the distilled water and acetic acid. Allow the stain to stand for one day and then filter. Add Distilled water to make the final volume 100ml.

 

  • Albert’s B solution consist of
    • Iodine - 2gm
    • Potassium iodide (KI) - 3 gm
    • Dissolve KI in water and then add iodine. Dissolve iodine in potassium iodide solution

 

Albert stain is basically made up of two stains that are toluidine blue’ O’ and malachite green both of which are basic dyes with high affinity for acidic tissue components like cytoplasm. The pH of Albert stain is adjusted to 2.8 by using acetic acid which becomes basic for volutin granules as the pH of volutin granule is highly acidic. Therefore, on applying Albert’s stain to the smear, toluidine blue’ O’ stains volutin granules i.e the most acidic part of cell and malachite green stains the cytoplasm blue-green. On adding Albert’s iodine due to effect of iodine, the metachromatic property is not observed and granules appear blue in color.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Carbol fuschin and methylene blue: This combination is typically used in acid-fast staining (Ziehl-Neelsen stain) for mycobacteria.

 

Option C. Carbol fuschin and malachite green: This combination is not typically used for staining metachromatic granules.

 

Option D. Toluidine and methylene blue: This combination is not specific for metachromatic granules and is not used in Albert staining.

 

Educational Objective

 

Albert stain, which contains Toluidine blue 'O' and Malachite green, is specifically used for staining metachromatic granules in Corynebacterium diphtheriae. These granules are an important diagnostic feature for diphtheria.

questions.text: Decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle occurs at which level of the brainstem ?  (AIIMS May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Midbrain

 

Explanation:

 

The decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle occurs in the midbrain, at the level of the inferior colliculus.

 

The midbrain has four decussations:

 

  • At the level of the superior colliculus:
    • Ventral tegmental decussation of the rubrospinal tract
    • Dorsal tegmental decussation of the tectospinal tract

 

 

  • At the level of the inferior colliculus:
    • Decussation of superior cerebellar peduncles
    • Decussation of trochlear nerve

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pons: The pons is a part of the brainstem located above the medulla and below the midbrain. It contains nuclei that deal with sleep, respiration, bladder control, hearing, taste, eye movement, facial expressions, facial sensation, and posture. While the pons does have connections with the cerebellum (mainly through the middle cerebellar peduncle), the decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle doesn't happen here.

 

Option C. Diencephalon: The diencephalon is a region of the forebrain that includes the thalamus, hypothalamus, and epithalamus. While the superior cerebellar peduncle does send fibers to the thalamus, the decussation doesn't happen in the diencephalon.

 

Option D. Medulla: The medulla oblongata, commonly referred to simply as the medulla, is the lower part of the brainstem. It's continuous with the spinal cord and contains many important neural pathways and centers for autonomic functions. The medulla does contain decussations, but they are mainly associated with the pyramidal tracts (motor pathways) and not with the superior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The midbrain, or mesencephalon, is the uppermost part of the brainstem, lying between the pons and the diencephalon. The superior cerebellar peduncle fibers decussate (cross) in the midbrain to reach the contralateral red nucleus and thalamus. This is why lesions in the cerebellum typically affect the same side of the body: the fibers effectively "double-cross," first decussating in the midbrain and then crossing again at higher levels in the brain.

choices.text: Insert a central venous catheter as the initial IV access of choice

questions.text: Before transferring the patient to the operating theatre, which of the following is necessary to do for a 60-year-old man who has been experiencing abdominal pain for the past six hours, has a BP of 84/50mmHg, RR of 26/min, saturation of 92% with 6 L of oxygen, and has extraluminal air in the abdomen on radiograph? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer 2 litres of crystalloid infusion

 

This is the correct option. The patient's low blood pressure (84/50 mmHg) and extraluminal air in the abdomen suggest a possible abdominal catastrophe, such as a perforated viscus. Administering crystalloid fluids is essential to address hypovolemia and improve blood pressure. The goal is to stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status and then perform an emergency laparotomy and repair the perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubate the patient: While intubation may be necessary in some cases of severe respiratory distress or respiratory failure, it is not indicated in this situation.

 

Option B. Insert a central venous catheter as the initial IV access of choice: While establishing intravenous (IV) access is important for administering fluids and medications, inserting a central venous catheter is a more invasive procedure and not the initial step. Peripheral IV access can be established quickly and is usually sufficient for initial resuscitation.

 

Option D. Verify the diagnosis with CECT (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography): While a CT scan may be necessary for confirming the diagnosis and identifying the specific issue, it is not the initial step in managing a patient in this critical condition. Stabilizing the patient's vital signs and addressing potential hypovolemia should come first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the given clinical scenario, volume resuscitation is crucial for maintaining BP as the patient has no history of trauma, indicating a possible bowel perforation.
  • Peripheral large-bore cannula may be used for initial volume resuscitation, and a central venous catheter may be required if vasopressors are planned.
  • Intubation may not be necessary since the patient is maintaining saturation.
  • CT scan may not be necessary as the provisional diagnosis of bowel perforation has already been established, and the patient's vital signs should be considered.

choices.text: Cells don't lyse in hypotonic solution

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spherical cells may be seen

 

G6PD deficiency can have spherical red cells.

 

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD. is an enzyme that helps in the synthesis of NADPH. NADPH helps in keeping glutathione in a reduced state (GSH). This reduced glutathione acts as a defense against oxidative damage.

 

In G6PD deficiency, RBCs are exposed to oxidants. These cross-linking of the reactive sulfhydryl groups in the globin chain of hemoglobin. These are then deposited as inclusions in RBC membranes as Heinz bodies. When these RBCs pass-through spleen, macrophages pluck out these membrane inclusions. The remaining cells are seen as bite cells. Less severely damaged cells lose a part of their membrane, forming spherocytes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spectrin: Spectrin is a part of the RBC membrane skeleton. It is commonly defective in hereditary spherocytosis.

 

Option C. Cells don't lyse in hypotonic solution: Normal biconcave RBCs have a bit of an 'extra space'. They can accommodate a little fluid when exposed to a hypotonic solution. But spherocytes have already lost a part of its membrane, so are relatively full. Hence if they are placed in a hypotonic solution, they absorb more fluid and result in lysis of RBCs. This forms the basis of testing spherocytes in Hereditary spherocytosis or G6PD and is known as osmotic fragility testing.

 

Option D. Cells lyse in hypertonic solution: Placing RBCs in a hypertonic solution causes them to lose water and shrink, but significant hemolysis does not typically occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

What is G6PD Deficiency?

 

  • A genetic enzymopathy, inherited in an X-linked recessive manner.
  • G6PD is an enzyme in the pentose phosphate pathway that generates NADPH, which helps maintain reduced glutathione (GSH).
  • GSH protects red blood cells (RBCs) from oxidative damage.

 

What Happens in G6PD Deficiency?

 

  • Without enough G6PD, RBCs are vulnerable to oxidative stress, such as:
    • Infections
    • Drugs (e.g., sulfa drugs, antimalarials)
    • Fava beans

 

Key peripheral smear findings:

 

  • Bite cells
  • Heinz bodies

 

In glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, red blood cells become spherical (spherocytes) due to oxidative damage and the removal of damaged membrane by the spleen, leading to hemolytic anemia.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1198-1199

choices.text: Regeneration is limited to the limbus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about corneal epithelium? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bowman's membrane regenerates.

 

The false statement about the corneal epithelium is B, stating that "Bowman's membrane regenerates." This is incorrect as Bowman's membrane is an acellular layer composed of collagen fibers and, once damaged, does not regenerate. The other statements regarding the corneal epithelium are true and align with the anatomical and functional characteristics of the cornea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Regeneration is limited to the limbus: This is true as limbal stem cells are key to the regeneration of the corneal epithelium.

 

Option C. Lined by stratified squamous epithelium: True, this describes the specific cell type forming the corneal epithelium.

 

Option D. Apical cells have microvilli: Also true, the microvilli increase the surface area for better adhesion of the tear film, enhancing eye lubrication and protection.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for hairy cell leukemia? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cladribine

 

It is a purine analogue used in the treatment of Hairy cell leukemia.

 

Cladribine-phosphates interfere with DNA synthesis and repair through incorporation into DNA and through inhibition of enzymes involved in DNA metabolism, including DNA polymerase and ribonucleotide reductase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A & D are not used in Hairy cell leukemia.

 

Option C. Hairy cell leukemia patients have mutation in BRAF pathway and hence, Vemurafenib (BRAF inhibitor) is used as second line agent in refractory cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cladribine remains the first-line treatment for hairy cell leukemia due to its high efficacy in inducing remissions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old resident physician was exposed to HIV through a needlestick injury and has come to the emergency department seeking help. You decide to start her on post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). Which of the following drug combinations is most recommended for PEP in this scenario? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Lamivudine + Tenofovir + Dolutegravir for 4 weeks 

 

  • Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is an emergency treatment for HIV exposure, typically recommended to be started as soon as possible after exposure, ideally within 2 hours and no later than 72 hours.
  • The choice of antiretroviral therapy for PEP should be guided by current recommendations that prioritize effectiveness and tolerability.
  • Lamivudine + Tenofovir + Dolutegravir (Option B): This combination is currently recommended for PEP due to its high efficacy, good tolerability, and strong safety profile. Tenofovir and Lamivudine provide a potent backbone of nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs), while Dolutegravir acts as an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI), which has a rapid onset of action and is well-tolerated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post Exposure Prophylaxis HIV

 

Preferably within 24 hours. Maximum within 72 hours.

 

Duration of prophylaxis is 28 days

questions.text: A 40-year-old nurse in the infectious diseases ward is reviewing the necessary precautions for attending to patients with various primary diagnoses. For which of the following patients would she NOT need to take special airborne precautions? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Herpes Zoster 

 

  • While Herpes Zoster (shingles) can be contagious, it primarily requires contact precautions unless disseminated or in the immunocompromised, where it might necessitate airborne precautions if there are pulmonary symptoms.
  • Generally, for localized shingles in an immunocompetent patient, standard precautions along with contact precautions are sufficient, thus not routinely requiring airborne precautions like the diseases listed in the other options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculosis: Requires airborne precautions due to the high risk of transmission through airborne particles, particularly the respiratory droplets that can suspend in the air for extended periods.

 

Option C. Measles: Highly contagious and spreads through airborne transmission. Airborne precautions are essential due to measles' ability to remain airborne for up to two hours after the infected person has left the area.

 

Option D. Chicken Pox (Varicella): Also spread through airborne transmission, requiring similar precautions to measles to prevent the spread of the virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Measles, Tuberculosis, and chickenpox require airborne transmission precaution unlike herpes zoster.
  • The patient should be made to wear a mask for source control.
  • A fit-tested NIOSH-approved N95 or higher-level respirator should be used by the healthcare personnel whilst care delivery.

choices.text: Basal lamina lining the serous acini
Presence of serous acini with acidophilic tip

questions.text: Which of the following features differentiates the exocrine pancreas from the parotid gland? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Absence of striated duct

 

Absence of striated duct in exocrine pancreas differentiates it from the parotid gland.

 

The exocrine pancreas is comprised entirely of serous acini. Therefore, its general structure is similar to that of the parotid gland, but the two are easily distinguished by:

 

  1. The parotid gland has striated and intercalated intralobular ducts, whereas the pancreas has only the intercalated type.
  2. The excretory ducts of the parotid gland are striated columnar, whereas the excretory duct of the pancreas is a simple columnar.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Basal lamina lining the serous acini: Both exocrine pancreas and parotid gland have serous acini that are lined by a basal lamina. Basal lamina is a thin extracellular matrix layer that underlies epithelial tissues and surrounds the cells in muscles, fat, and Schwann cells. So, this feature does not differentiate the two.

 

Option C. Presence of serous acini with acidophilic tip: Both the exocrine pancreas and the parotid gland have serous acini. In the pancreas, these acinar cells have an acidophilic (eosinophilic) cytoplasm because they contain zymogen granules, which are precursors of digestive enzymes. The parotid gland is purely serous, and its acinar cells also have zymogen granules. Thus, this feature does not uniquely differentiate the two glands.

 

Option D. Presence of apical acinar villi: While the exocrine pancreas has acinar cells with a fine, microvillous border at the apical side (facing the lumen) to increase the secretory surface, this is not a feature that starkly contrasts with the parotid gland. Acinar cells in the parotid gland also have secretory granules toward their apical side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Striated ducts are a characteristic feature of salivary glands, including the parotid gland. These ducts have basal infoldings associated with mitochondria, which gives them their "striated" appearance. They play a role in modifying the primary saliva produced by the acinar cells. The exocrine pancreas does not possess striated ducts. Instead, it has intercalated ducts that connect the acinar cells to the larger duct system. This feature, therefore, differentiates the exocrine pancreas from the parotid gland.

questions.text: A 27-year-old accountant underwent parotidectomy following which she developed lower lip paralysis. This probably occurred because of an injury to which of the following structures? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mandibular branch of facial nerve

 

The mandibular branch of the facial nerve, also known as the marginal mandibular branch, supplies motor fibers to the muscles responsible for lower lip movement. During a parotidectomy, there is a risk of injuring the nearby facial nerve branches, including the mandibular branch. Damage to this branch can lead to lower lip paralysis or weakness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Temporal branch of facial nerve: The temporal branch of the facial nerve innervates the muscles of the forehead and is not related to the lower lip.

 

Option B. Cervical branch of facial nerve: The cervical branch of the facial nerve innervates certain neck muscles and is also not related to the lower lip.

 

Option C. Parotid duct: The parotid duct, also known as Stensen's duct, carries saliva from the parotid gland to the mouth. Injury to this duct could result in salivary leakage from wound (salivary fistula).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lower lip paralysis is a result of an injury to the marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve.
  • During parotidectomy, the facial nerve may be at risk of injury since it passes through the parotid gland.
  • The branches of the facial nerve include the temporal, zygomatic, buccal, marginal mandibular, and cervical branches.

choices.text: 10-year-old child with multi organ dysfunction syndrome
49-year-old alcoholic man with liver cirrhosis with 1 month abstinence
74-year-old woman with end stage renal disease

questions.text: In the case of a 37-year-old woman who has been declared brain dead and whose family has agreed to donate her organs, who would be the most suitable or optimal candidate to receive the organs? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 31-year-old women with renal failure

 

This candidate is closer in age to the donor, and if her medical condition and compatibility allow for a successful kidney transplant, she may be the most suitable recipient for the kidney.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A 10-year-old child with multi-organ dysfunction syndrome: This candidate is likely in urgent need of multiple organ transplantation, and a younger recipient may generally have better long-term outcomes. However, etiology of multi-organ dysfunction is not provided, thereby the long term prognosis of the patient is uncertain.

 

Option B. A 49-year-old alcoholic man with liver cirrhosis with 1 month abstinence: While this candidate may benefit from a liver transplant, alcoholism can pose challenges to transplantation success. The one-month abstinence period is relatively short, and further evaluation of his liver condition and suitability for transplantation would be necessary.

 

Option C. A 74-year-old woman with end-stage renal disease: Given the age of the recipient and the fact that she has end-stage renal disease, a kidney transplant from the 37-year-old donor may not provide the best long-term outcomes. Older recipients may have a lower life expectancy, and the benefit of a kidney transplant may be less significant compared to younger recipients.

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic smoker presented with mild recurrent hemoptysis without fever or weight loss. The chest X-ray appears normal and the sputum is negative for AFB. Which of the following is the most useful diagnostic investigation? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT Thorax

 

CECT is preferred when suspicion of malignancy is high. HRCT is preferred to look at lung parenchyma/suspected ILD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI is used to assess for metastasis, secondary changes. MRI is NOT preferred over CT scan for evaluation of distant metastasis and invasion.

 

Option B. Bronchoscopy is used for biopsy of mass based on accessibility. More central masses are amenable to bronchoscopic biopsy. Peripheral masses are sampled by CT-guided biopsy.

 

Option D. Bronchography is no longer used in today’s practice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The choice of CT Thorax (HRCT or CECT) is critical for early detection of potential malignancies or other significant lung conditions in a high-risk individual, particularly when initial less sensitive tests like chest X-ray and sputum analysis have failed to elucidate the cause of symptoms.

 

Reference - (Harrison 21E, 597,598) Resp Med/Hemoptysis/Lung CA

questions.text: In the case of a child presenting to the OPD with tense bullae over the torso, and a biopsy of the lesion revealing subepidermal blistering and neutrophil infiltration, what is the preferred drug for treatment? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dapsone

 

  • A diagnosis of linear lgA disease (LIGA), or childhood chronic bullous disease is suggested by the clinical picture of tense blisters with subepidermal separation and neutrophilic infiltration at the basement membrane in a child.
  • This is an autoimmune blistering disorder that can clinically and histologically resemble bullous pemphigoid but is distinguished by linear deposits of IgA at the basement membrane zone.

 

Dapsone:

 

  • The preferred medication to treat LIGA is dapsone.
  • It typically leads to rapid clinical improvement in CBDC
  • Dapsone, which primarily kills bacteria, also has an anti-inflammatory effect by reducing neutrophil enzyme activity.
  • As a result, it is effective in the management of LIGA.
  • Other options such as rituximab, cyclosporine, and azathioprine are reserved for cases that do not respond to dapsone or when dapsone is contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rituximab: This is a monoclonal antibody that targets CD20 on B-cells and is used in a variety of autoimmune diseases, including those with blistering skin manifestations like pemphigus vulgaris. It is not the first-line therapy for Linear IgA disease.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine: This is an immunosuppressant that inhibits T-cell activation and is used in severe cases of many autoimmune disorders and in transplant patients. It may be used in refractory cases of Linear IgA disease but is not the first choice due to potential side effects, especially in children.

 

Option D. Azathioprine: This immunosuppressive agent is used as a steroid-sparing drug in various autoimmune conditions. It is not the first-line treatment for Linear IgA disease and is considered in cases that are refractory to dapsone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for Linear IgA disease (Chronic Bullous Disease of Childhood) is dapsone, due to its efficacy in managing conditions with neutrophilic infiltrates.

 

Ref - Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page no 989,998

choices.text: Can be cultured in a cell-free medium

questions.text: Which of the following is false about mycoplasma pneumonia? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Responds well to amoxiclav

 

Beta-lactam groups of drugs act by inhibiting the transpeptidation process of cell wall synthesis. Mycoplasma does not possess a cell wall and hence is not affected by beta-lactams.

 

Azithromycin (DOC), Doxycycline, Fluoroquinolone (FQ) are effective in management of mycoplasma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Interstitial inflammation characterized by bilateral reticular infiltrates are seen on CXR.

 

Option C. IgM, IgG can be used in the diagnosis of Mycoplasma.

 

Option D. They show fried-egg appearance on cell free medium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycoplasma pneumonia does not respond to beta-lactam antibiotics due to its lack of a cell wall.

 

The preferred antibiotics for treating Mycoplasma pneumonia include macrolides (e.g., azithromycin), tetracyclines (e.g., doxycycline), and fluoroquinolones for adults.

 

Reference - Resp Med/pneumonia, Harrison chap 188/5430

choices.text: Chief cells
Stem cells
Parietal cells

questions.text: Cells lining the isthmus of the gastric pits? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stem cells  

 

The isthmus of the gastric pits, which is the region between the gastric pit and the gland, contains stem cells. These stem cells are crucial for the continuous regeneration of the epithelial lining of the stomach. They have the potential to differentiate into all the different types of cells found in the gastric glands, including surface mucous cells, mucous neck cells, parietal cells, chief cells, and enteroendocrine cells. The high turnover rate of gastric epithelium necessitates the presence of these stem cells in the isthmus to replace the cells lost due to the harsh acidic environment of the stomach.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chief cells: Chief cells are located in the base of the gastric glands and are responsible for secreting pepsinogen, which is the precursor to the digestive enzyme pepsin.

 

Option C. Parietal cells: Parietal cells are found in the neck and body of the gastric glands and are responsible for secreting hydrochloric acid (HCl) and intrinsic factor, which is crucial for vitamin B12 absorption.

 

Option D. Mucous cells: Mucous cells, specifically surface mucous cells, are found lining the gastric pits and are responsible for secreting mucus that protects the stomach lining from the acidic environment. Mucous neck cells are located in the neck of the gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isthmus of the gastric pits is lined with stem cells, which are essential for the regeneration of the various cell types in the gastric glands, ensuring the maintenance of the gastric epithelium.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom of severe dehydration? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thirsty child.

 

Dehydration in children is classified based on clinical signs into mild (some dehydration) and severe dehydration. The symptoms of severe dehydration are crucial for determining the appropriate treatment and urgency of care.

 

"Thirsty child," is typically associated with some dehydration rather than severe dehydration. A thirsty child is likely still alert and responsive, seeking fluids, which suggests that dehydration is present but not yet severe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drowsy child: Indicates severe dehydration where the child’s mental status is altered, often due to inadequate perfusion to the brain.

 

Option B. Skin pinch retracts slowly: This is a reliable sign of severe dehydration and indicates significant fluid loss.

 

Option D. Sunken fontanelle: Especially in infants, a sunken fontanelle is a common and concerning sign of severe dehydration, indicating decreased intracranial pressure due to fluid loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A thirsty child indicates some dehydration, whereas signs like drowsiness, slow skin pinch retraction, and a sunken fontanelle are indicative of severe dehydration.

questions.text: Which of the following topical antifungal has both anti- inflammatory effects and anti-pruritic action? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sertaconazole

 

Sertaconazole has both anti-inflammatory effects and anti-pruritic action. It is used to treat dermatophytosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ketoconazole: Ketoconazole is a broad-spectrum antifungal that also has anti-androgenic effects. However, it does not possess notable anti-inflammatory or anti-pruritic properties.

 

Option C. Luliconazole: Luliconazole is effective against dermatophytes and yeasts, but it does not have significant anti-inflammatory or anti-pruritic actions.

 

Option D. Terbinafine: Terbinafine is mainly used to treat dermatophytosis. It does not have substantial anti-inflammatory or anti-pruritic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Least frequency of slow waves is seen in? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stomach

 

Among the given options, the least frequency of slow waves is seen in the stomach (4/min).

 

Most gastrointestinal contractions occur rhythmically, and this rhythm is determined mainly by the frequency of so-called “slow waves” of smooth muscle membrane potential or basal electrical rhythm.

 

Interactions among the smooth muscle cells and specialized cells, called the interstitial cells of Cajal, that are believed to act as electrical pacemakers for smooth muscle cells.

 

They are slow, undulating changes in the resting membrane potential. Their intensity usually varies between 5 and 15 millivolts, and their frequency ranges in different parts of the human gastrointestinal tract from 3 to 12 per minute:

 

  • Body of the stomach – 3/min
  • Duodenum – 12/min
  • Terminal ileum – 8-9/min
  • Distal ileum: 8/min
  • Cecum: 2/min
  • Sigmoid colon: 6/min

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenum: Incorrect. The duodenum has a higher frequency of slow waves, approximately 12 waves per minute.

 

Option B. Ileum: Incorrect. The terminal ileum has a frequency of about 8-9 waves per minute.

 

Option C. Jejunum: Incorrect. The jejunum has a frequency of approximately 10-12 waves per minute.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stomach has the least frequency of slow waves among the given options, with approximately 3 waves per minute. Slow waves determine the rhythmic contractions of the gastrointestinal tract and vary in frequency throughout different regions.

questions.text: The given chemical structure is of: (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chondroitin sulphate

 

Chondroitin sulphate is present in ground substance of connective tissues widely distributed in cartilage, bone, tendons, cornea and skin. It is composed of repeating units of glucuronic acid → beta-1,3-N-acetyl galactosamine sulphate → beta-1, 4 and so on.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Keratan Sulphate:

  • Composition: Contains galactose and N-acetyl glucosamine.
  • Location: Found in cartilage, cornea, and intervertebral discs.

 

Option C. Heparin:

  • Composition: Contains glucuronic acid or iduronic acid and glucosamine.
  • Location: Primarily found in mast cells and used as an anticoagulant.

 

Option D. Dermatan Sulphate:

  • Composition: Contains iduronic acid and N-acetyl galactosamine.
  • Location: Found in skin, blood vessels, and heart valves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chondroitin sulphate is a glycosaminoglycan found in connective tissues like cartilage and bone, characterized by its repeating units of glucuronic acid and N-acetyl galactosamine sulphate.

questions.text: Ring sequestrum is associated with which of the following? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) External pin fixator

 

  • A sequestrum is infected dead bone formed as a squealae of chronic osteomyelitis.
  • Ring sequestrum is a low grade chronic osteomyelitis following pintract infection producing an unusual sequestrum surrounded by radiolucent area, another circle of sclerotic bone.
  • Improper aseptic technique of skeletal pin traction, thermal necrosis, prolonged duration, poor pin tract care and comorbid conditions can lead to this complications and presents with skin discharge, pin loosening and osteomyelitis.
  • Thorough surgical debridement, sequestrectomy and saucerisation with appropriate antibiotics and dead space management will successfully treat it.

 

 

TYPES OF SEQUESTRUMS

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiation exposure. The response of bone to the trauma of radiation is inflammation. This is seen radiographically as an increase in sclerosis. Irradiated bone has less ability to remodel. Radiation therapy (as well as bisphosphonate therapy) can be considered as macrotrauma that lower the threshold of the ability for bone to repair. Adding in microtrauma events such as dental extraction, denture irritation, break in mucosal protection from traumatic ulceration may lead to exceeding the bone’s capacity to remodel, resulting in necrosis and sequestra formation. When the sequestrum is superficial, bone exposure may occur. When the sequestrum is deeper within the bone, radiographic signs may be the only diagnostic features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ring sequestrum is most commonly caused due to external pin fixators, mainly Steinmann pins.

questions.text: Identify the fetal position in the given image? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Right occipito-anterior

 

The Right occipito-anterior (ROA) position means the fetal occiput (the back of the head) is directed towards the mother's right side and anterior (towards the front of the pelvis). This position indicates that the fetus is facing towards the mother's right side with its back towards the front of the pelvis.

 

In fetal positions:

 

  • Right occipito-anterior (ROA): The occiput is on the right side and anteriorly towards the front of the pelvis.
  • Left occipito-anterior (LOA): The occiput is on the left side and anteriorly towards the front of the pelvis.
  • Right occipito-posterior (ROP): The occiput is on the right side but posteriorly towards the back of the pelvis.
  • Left occipito-posterior (LOP): The occiput is on the left side but posteriorly towards the back of the pelvis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Right occipito-posterior: This position indicates that the occiput is on the right side but towards the back of the pelvis, not the front.

 

Option B. Left occipito-anterior: This position indicates that the occiput is on the left side and anteriorly towards the front of the pelvis.

 

Option C. Left occipito-posterior: This position indicates that the occiput is on the left side but towards the back of the pelvis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the Right occipito-anterior (ROA) position, the fetal occiput is directed towards the mother's right side and the anterior part of the pelvis.

 

Ref: Page 89, DC Ditta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition.

questions.text: Which of the following types of amino acids are present in the trans-membranous part of the membrane receptor? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydrophobic

 

Integral or transmembrane proteins are the proteins that pass through entire thickness of cell membrane from one side to the other side. These proteins are tightly bound with the cell membrane.

 

The trans membranous part of the membrane receptor consists of hydrophobic amino acids.

 

The central core of the cell membrane is hydrophobic.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amphipathic: Incorrect. Amphipathic molecules contain both hydrophobic and hydrophilic regions, but the transmembrane segments of proteins are primarily hydrophobic.

 

Option C. Hydrophilic: Incorrect. Hydrophilic amino acids have polar side chains that would not favorably interact with the hydrophobic core of the lipid bilayer.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect. Hydrophobic amino acids are indeed present in the transmembranous part of the membrane receptor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The transmembrane regions of membrane receptors are composed of hydrophobic amino acids, allowing them to stably integrate into the hydrophobic core of the lipid bilayer.

 

Examples of integral protein:

 

  1. Cell adhesion proteins
  2. Cell junction proteins
  3. Some carrier (transport) proteins
  4. Channel proteins
  5. Some hormone receptors
  6. Antigens
  7. Some enzymes.

questions.text: Which of the following is a second line anti-tubercular drug? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ethionamide

 

Ethionamide is used as a second-line treatment for tuberculosis (TB), particularly in cases of multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB), when the first-line drugs (like isoniazid, rifampicin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide) are not effective or cannot be used due to resistance or side effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: This is a first-line anti-tubercular drug, widely used in the treatment of both latent and active TB infections.

 

Option C. Acyclovir: Acyclovir is an antiviral medication, primarily used for the treatment of herpes simplex virus infections and not for tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Vancomycin: Vancomycin is an antibiotic used to treat serious bacterial infections caused by gram-positive bacteria, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). It is not used in the treatment of tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethionamide is a second-line anti-tubercular drug used in the management of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB), whereas isoniazid is a first-line drug, and acyclovir and vancomycin are not used for tuberculosis treatment.

questions.text: What are the air cells located at the anterior most part of the anterior ethmoidal sinus called?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Agger nasi

 

The Agger nasi cells are the anterior-most air cells of the anterior ethmoid air cells. They are situated just above the attachment of the middle turbinate, making them critical landmarks in sinus surgery due to their proximity to the frontal sinus drainage pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bulla ethmoidalis largest air cells in ethmoidal air sinus

 

Option B. Onodi cell/ Sphenoethmoidal air cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cell. They are significant due to their proximity to the optic nerve and the sphenoid sinus, posing a risk during sinus surgery.

 

 

Option D. Haller cell/ infraorbital ethmoidal air cells are ethmoid air cells located lateral to the maxillo-ethmoidal suture along the inferomedial orbital floor. Haller cells can impact the drainage of the maxillary sinus and are important to consider in imaging and surgical planning for sinus issues.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Agger nasi is the anterior-most air cells of anterior ethmoid air cells.
  • Bulla ethmoidalis is the largest air cells in ethmoidal air sinus
  • Onodi cell/ Sphenoethmoidal air cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cells
  • Haller cells are ethmoid air cells that extend into the floor of the orbit and can affect the integrity and drainage of the maxillary sinus

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 152, 153

questions.text: You are attending physiology viva. The examiner asks you who recorded the first EEG. You say "I don't know "The examiner feels bad for you and gives you a clue that "the name sounds like something you get commonly in McDonalds". You remember the name and answer correctly. What type of memory has been implicated here?" (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Priming

 

Priming is when exposure to a stimulus influences the response to a subsequent stimulus. In this scenario, the examiner's hint about McDonald's (suggesting "burger") facilitated the student's recall of "Berger," who recorded the first EEG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Semantic memory: Semantic memory involves facts and general knowledge, like knowing the capital of a country.

 

Option B. Implicit memory: Implicit memory is unconscious, but involves skills or tasks, like riding a bike.

 

Option C. Associative learning: Associative learning involves pairing two stimuli, like Pavlov's dog experiment.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Priming means that a recent experience makes it easier for you to notice or identify something related.

 

Perceptual Priming: Recognizing something becomes easier because you've recently seen something that looks similar. For example, if you've just seen a picture of a lion, you'll be faster at spotting the word "lion" even if it's a bit unclear.

 

Conceptual Priming: Understanding or noticing something becomes easier because you've recently thought about a related idea. For example, if you've just read about rivers and banks, you'll probably guess the word "bank" when given "ban_" instead of thinking of "band."

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 116.

choices.text: They can differentiate
They can replicate
They can divide without any regulatory stimulus
They can regenerate damaged tissues

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about stem cells? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) They can divide without any regulatory stimulus

 

Stem cells do not divide without any regulatory stimulus.

 

Stem cells are characterized by their self-renewal properties and by their capacity to generate differentiated cell lineages. Stem cells give rise to all the various differentiated tissues. In adults, stem cells replace damaged cells and maintain tissue populations.

 

The properties of stem cells are:

 

  1. Obligatory asymmetric replication, in which with each stem cell division, one of the daughter cells retains its self-renewing capacity while the other enters a differentiation pathway
  2. Stochastic differentiation, in which a stem cell population is maintained by the balance between stem cell divisions that generate either two self-renewing stem cells or two cells that will differentiate.

 

The types of stem cells are:

 

  • Embryonic stem cells which are totipotent
  • Adult stem cells present in stem cell niches

 

The pluripotency of stem cells is due to factors like:

 

  • Oct3/4
  • Kif 4
  • Sox 2
  • c-myc

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. They can differentiate: This is true. Stem cells have the ability to differentiate into various specialized cell types.

 

Option B. They can replicate: This is true. Stem cells can self-renew, meaning they can replicate themselves to maintain the stem cell pool.

 

Option D. They can regenerate damaged tissues: This is true. Stem cells can help regenerate damaged tissues by differentiating into the necessary cell types to replace lost or damaged cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stem cells do not divide without any regulatory stimulus; their division and differentiation are tightly controlled to maintain tissue homeostasis and prevent uncontrolled growth.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 165-170

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parathyroid adenoma

 

Parathyroid adenoma is not a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Secondary hyperparathyroidism is a condition in which the parathyroid glands produce excess parathyroid hormone (PTH) due to a stimulus other than low blood calcium levels. This can occur in response to various conditions that cause chronic kidney disease, vitamin D deficiency, or exposure to certain medications such as lithium.

 

Parathyroid adenoma, on the other hand, is a cause of primary hyperparathyroidism, which is characterized by excess PTH secretion due to an abnormality within the parathyroid gland itself.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lithium intake: Lithium can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism by impairing calcium sensing.

 

Option C. Vitamin D deficiency: Vitamin D deficiency is a well-known cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism due to its role in calcium absorption.

 

Option D. Chronic kidney disease: CKD is a major cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism due to its effects on phosphate and vitamin D metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parathyroid adenoma causes primary hyperparathyroidism, whereas secondary hyperparathyroidism is due to external stimuli such as chronic kidney disease, vitamin D deficiency, or lithium intake.

choices.text: Western blot
Real time PCR

questions.text: Which of the following method is employed to measure the viral load? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Real time PCR

 

A real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR, or qPCR) is a laboratory technique of molecular biology based on the polymerase chain reaction (PCR). It monitors the amplification of a targeted DNA molecule during the PCR (i.e., in real time). Fluorescence is measured after each cycle and the intensity of the fluorescent signal reflects the momentary amount of DNA amplicons in the sample at that specific time. Commonly used for viral load quantification of HIV, hepatitis C virus, hepatitis B virus, and CMV.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. ELISA: Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay is primarily used to detect antigens or antibodies in a sample and is not used for measuring viral load.

 

Option B. Western blot: This technique is used to detect specific proteins in a sample and is not used for measuring viral load.

 

Option D. Immunoelectrophoresis: This method is used to separate and identify proteins based on their antigen-antibody interactions and is not used for measuring viral load.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Real-time PCR measure viral load
  • Western blotting – detects protein.
  • ELISA - detect antigens of infectious agents
  • Immuno electrophoresis – separates antigen following antigen antibody reaction

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is used for diagnosing abdominal pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Studdiford criteria

 

  • Studdiford Criteria is for diagnosis of Primary abdominal pregnancy
    • Both tubes and ovaries normal with no marks of injury
    • Utero-peritoneal fistula should not be seen
    • The placenta should be attached exclusively to the peritoneal surface

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spiegelberg Criteria: Spiegelberg Criteria is for Ovarian ectopic

 

  • The tube on the affected side must be intact
  • The gestation sac must occupy the position of the ovary
  • The gestation sac in the ovary must be connected to the uterus by the ovarian ligament
  • Definite ovarian tissue must be found in the sac wall on histopathology

 

Option B. Rubin criteria: Rubin criteria is for Cervical pregnancy

 

Option D. Ring of fire: Ring of fire is a sign seen on USG-Color doppler in an unruptured tubal ectopic

 

Educational Objective:

 

Studdiford Criteria are used to diagnose primary abdominal pregnancy. This criterion involves:

 

  1. Ensuring that both fallopian tubes and ovaries are normal with no signs of injury.
  2. Confirming that no utero-peritoneal fistula is present.
  3. Verifying that the placenta is attached exclusively to the peritoneal surface.

 

These criteria help distinguish primary abdominal pregnancy from other types of ectopic pregnancies.

 

Ref: Page no 219, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition.

choices.text: Trisodium citrate

questions.text: The vacutainer tube shown in the given image contains: (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clot Activator

 

The plastic tube shown in the given image has a red stopper indicating that it contains clot activator (silica). They don’t contain anticoagulants or additives.

 

The tube is inverted five times to initiate the clotting process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na-EDTA: Na-EDTA is an anticoagulant used in vacutainer tubes with lavender or purple stoppers. These tubes are used for hematological examinations such as complete blood counts (CBC) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).

 

Option B. Trisodium citrate: Trisodium citrate is found in tubes with light blue stoppers and is used for coagulation studies such as PT (Prothrombin Time) and APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time).

 

Option C. NAF (Sodium Fluoride): Sodium fluoride is an anticoagulant and preservative found in tubes with gray stoppers. It is used for glucose estimation as it inhibits glycolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman was taken by her neighbour to the emergency department after an incident involving her husband. She reported that during a domestic altercation, her husband swung an axe at her left arm. Upon examination, a significant injury was observed on her upper left arm. The wound appeared deep, with jagged and irregular edges. The surrounding area showed signs of bruising. Based on the clinical scenario, what type of wound is likely to be present on the patient's upper left arm? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chop wound 

 

A heavy object which is relatively sharp edged, e.g. axe produces chop wounds. Chop wounds have features of both sharp and blunt force injuries. They are characterized by deep, jagged, and irregular edges with surrounding bruising.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incised wound:

 

  • Produced by lighter weapons like knife, blades etc.
  • Margins are not contused and abraded. 
  • Destruction of underlying tissues is less as compared to cop wound.

 

Option C. Lacerated wound:

 

  • Lacerations can result from accidents, falls, or impact with blunt objects.
  • Lacerated wounds are not clean cut, whereas incised and chop wounds are clean cut.

 

Option D. Abrasion:  In abrasions only the superficial skin is damaged. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cut laceration / chop wounds: 

 

  • Produced by a heavy object which is relatively sharp edged, E.g. axe, chopper
    • It has features of both blunt force (bruised and abraded margins, irregular margins) and sharp force (clean margins)
    • A deep and wide cut over the body tissues.
    • Marked destruction of underlying tissues
    • Below image shows chop wound by axe:

questions.text: The image given shows a patient who has undergone total laryngectomy due to laryngeal cancer. Identify the method of voice generation for this patient, as depicted in the provided image.(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tracheoesophageal prosthesis

 

The voice production modality depicted in the image is tracheoesophageal voice prosthesis.

 

The extended air from the trachea is diverted to the esophagus through a device that connects the trachea and esophagus in tracheoesophageal prosthesis. It also has a one-way valve that keeps food from entering into the trachea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrolarynx: Is a vibrating instrument that emits a low-pitched sound in the hypopharynx. The palate, tongue, and teeth then articulate it.

 

Option B. Chicago implant: Is a type of hearing aid.

 

Option D. Esophageal speech: The patient is trained to swallow air and slowly release it into the pharynx. 6-10 words can be spoken in a rough manner before re-swallowing the air.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracheoesophageal prosthesis is a common and effective method for voice restoration following total laryngectomy. It relies on a surgically implanted device that directs air into the esophagus where vibrations are created for speech, significantly enhancing the quality of life for patients who have lost their natural voice box.

choices.text: Intra-articular fracture distal end of radius
Extra-articular fracture distal end of radius

questions.text: An old lady fell in the bathroom with an outstretched hand. She was managed conservatively. Later on, she developed the deformity as shown in the figure. Most likely fracture sustained was:(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Extra-articular fracture distal end of radius

 

COLLE’S FRACTURE

 

  • Fracture of the distal end of radius at its corticocancellous junction, is commonly referred to as a Colle’s fracture.
  • It is typically the result of a FOOSH injury (Fall on outstretched hand) with wrist in extension.
  • It mostly occur in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women.
  • Symptoms and Signs:
    • Patients present with swelling, ecchymosis, tenderness, and painful range of motion of the distal forearm.
    • On examination, the classic “dinner fork” deformity (dorsal displacement of the distal fragment and volar angulation of the distal intact radius with radial shortening) may be identified.

 

 

 

  • Complications:
    • Early complications may include median nerve neuropathy, extensor pollicis longus tendon rupture, and compartment syndrome.
    • Late complications may include radiocarpal arthrosis, complex regional pain syndrome, cosmetic changes of the wrist, and fracture malunion or nonunion.
    • Finger stiffness is most common complication.
    • Malunion is the 2nd most common complication and it leads to dinner fork deformity.
    • Colles fracture is the commonest cause of Sudeck's dystrophy in upper limb.
       
  • Treatment:
    • Non-displaced extra-articular fractures are relatively stable and are treated non-operatively with a long-arm splint acutely to allow for swelling, then transitioned to a short-arm cast.
    • The cast is applied on opposite forces to displacement. The position of immobilization is:

 

  • Displaced fractures should undergo an attempt at closed reduction followed by immobilization in a long-arm sugar-tong splint acutely. Surgical fixation is indicated for distal radius fractures that fail to meet acceptable alignment criteria. Various methods include closed reduction percutaneous pinning, external fixation, and open reduction internal fixation (ORIF).
     
  • Technique of closed manipulation:
    • The muscles of forearm must be relaxed, either by general or regional anaesthesia. The surgeon grasps the injured hand as if he was ‘shaking hands’.

 

  • The first step is to disimpact the fragments which have often been driven together.

  • This is achieved by firm longitudinal traction to the hand against the counter-traction by an assistant who grasps the arm above the flexed elbow.

  • The surgeon now presses the distal fragment into palmar flexion and ulnar deviation using the thumb of his other hand.

  • As this is done, the patient’s hand is drawn into pronation, palmar flexion and ulnar deviation.

A plaster cast is applied extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, maintaining the wrist in palmar flexion and ulnar deviation.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Intra-articular fracture distal end of radius. Barton's fracture is the displaced intra-articular coronal plane fracture-subluxation of dorsal lip of the distal radius with displacement of carpus with the fragment. Intra-articular component usually signifies high-energy trauma occurring in young adults, causing shear and impacted fractures of the articular surface of the distal aspect of the radius with displacement of the fracture fragments. The fracture pattern most commonly observed in geriatric age group is extra-articular while the high-energy intra-articular type is most frequent in young adult patients. Melone's classification of intra-articular distal radius fractures:

 

 

 

Intra-articular fractures of distal end of the radius can be difficult to treat, at times, with traditional conservative method. Type I and type II Melone's fracture can be managed conservatively by closed reduction and cast immobilization. External fixation is accepted as superior to plaster immobilization in the young patients with an intra-articular comminuted fracture of the distal radius. Complex intra-articular fractures in which the articular fragments are displaced, rotated or impacted are treated with open reduction and internal fixation.

 

Option C. Scaphoid fracture. It is the most commonly fractured bone in the carpus, in adult as well as children. Most commonly in males between the ages of 15 and 30. Fullness and tenderness is felt in anatomical snuff box. In adults and adolescents, middle third (Waist) fractures (70%) is more common. Nondisplaced, Stable Fractures are treated conservatively by Scaphoid Glass Holding Cast. Displaced, Unstable Fractures are treated by Headless Screw (Herbert).

 

 

 

Scaphoid glass holding cast

 

Option D. Dislocation of wrist. Wrist dislocations can occur at the radiocarpal joint, the midcarpal joint, the distal radioulnar joint or may represent a combination of these injuries in severe trauma. Carpal instability in the form of lunate and perilunate dislocations are uncommon injuries but can be frequently missed. The majority of carpal instability is centered around the lunate, given its location in the middle of the wrist. Injuries progress from scapholunate instability to lunate dislocation. Perilunate dislocations and lunate dislocations are high-energy wrist injuries involving falls from height, motor vehicle collisions, or athletic injuries. Lunate dislocate anteriorly but the rest of the carpals remain in position. In Perilunate dislocation, the lunate remains in position and the rest of the carpals dislocate dorsally. The most common type of perilunate instability is transscaphoid perilunate fracture dislocation. Median nerve is most commonly involved nerve. The most commonly used method of closed reduction is Tavernier’s maneuver.

 

 

A) Normal; (B) Lunate dislocation; (C) Perilunate dislocation; (D) Normal

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The image shown in the question is a classic dinner fork deformity, which is a complication of Colle’s fracture.
  • Colle’s fracture is most commonly seen in post-menopausal osteoporotic females after a fall on outstretched hand.

choices.text: No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination

questions.text: A resident had a needle stick injury while dealing with a Hepatitis B positive patient. Serology was done and HBsAg was negative and the Anti-HBs was >105 mIU/ml. What is the next step of management? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination

 

No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination: The resident's serology shows that HBsAg is negative and Anti-HBs is greater than 105 mIU/ml, which indicates that he has sufficient immunity against Hepatitis B from prior vaccination. No further treatment is necessary because the antibody titres are already protective.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Booster dose of vaccine: Not required since the resident already has sufficient antibody levels indicating immunity.

 

Option B. Immunoglobulin with full vaccination: This would be necessary if the resident had low or no detectable antibody titres, indicating no prior immunity.

 

Option C. Repeat full course of vaccine: Not necessary because the resident already has adequate antibody titres indicating immunity.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with a headache and altered sensorium. MRI was performed which revealed multiple rings enhancing lesions. MR spectroscopy showed a prominent lipid-lactate peak. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Tuberculoma

 

Explanation:

 

The MRI findings of multiple ring-enhancing lesions in conjunction with a prominent lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy are characteristic of tuberculoma. Tuberculomas are focal infections that typically present as ring-enhancing lesions in the brain, often around the brainstem, and can conglomerate. The lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy is indicative of necrosis, which is a feature seen in tuberculomas (and also in conditions like toxoplasmosis). The combination of imaging and spectroscopy findings helps distinguish tuberculomas from other similar conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurocysticercosis (NCC): Typically presents with cystic lesions in the brain, which may show ring enhancement but does not characteristically show a lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy.

 

Option C. Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML): Generally shows non-enhancing, white matter lesions on MRI without a significant lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy.

 

Option D. Cryptococcomas: These fungal infections might present similarly on imaging but do not typically show a lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculomas: 

 

  • Tuberculomas- foci of infection and show ring enhancing lesion
  • More common around brainstem
  • Show conglomeration
  • MR spectroscopy shows lipid lactate peak – necrosis (also seen in toxoplasmosis)

 

No prominent metabolite is seen in NCC/PML/Cryptococcoses.

choices.text: Transfusion reaction
Acute adrenal crisis
Fat embolism

questions.text: A 24-year-old man met with an road traffic accident and was brought to the casualty after 6 hours. His B.P. was 90/60 mm Hg, heart rate was 110/min, and Sp02 was 92%. A blood transfusion was done. After a few hours, the patient is febrile, tachypneic, and starts bleeding from the IV and NG tube sites. His SpO2 levels started falling. What could be the cause? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transfusion reaction

 

Given the clinical scenario the most likely diagnosis is acute hemolytic transfusion reaction causing DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation) resulting in bleeding from IV catheter and nasogastric tube within a few hours of blood transfusion.

 

Acute Hemolytic Transfusion reaction

 

  • Immune-mediated hemolysis
  • Preformed antibodies in recipient lyse donor erythrocytes.
  • Complement-mediated lysis occurs causing intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria.
  • Severe cases, tissue factor released from the lysed erythrocytes may initiate DIC, which is a consumptive coagulopathy with bleeding manifestations.
  • Other complications include shock, acute kidney injury, and sometimes, death.

 

The various blood transfusion reactions according to their time of occurrence are as follows:

 

  • Anaphylactic reaction - Within a few seconds to minutes of the transfusion. Common in selective IgA deficiency patients.
  • Allergic/Urticarial reactions - Within 2-3 hours of transfusion
  • Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) - Within 24 hours of transfusion
  • Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHT) - Within 6 hours of transfusion
  • Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction (DHTR) - After 24 hours of transfusion


TRALI vs TACO:

 

 

TRALI: transfusion-related acute lung injury, TACO: Transfusion-associated cardiac overload, CXR: chest X-ray, BNP: B type natriuretic peptide, PAOP: pulmonary artery occluding pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute adrenal crisis: This condition involves sudden adrenal insufficiency, leading to hypotension, shock, and electrolyte imbalances. It would not typically cause the specific symptoms of hemolysis and DIC seen in this case.

 

Option C. Fat embolism: Fat embolism syndrome can occur after long bone fractures, presenting with respiratory distress, neurological symptoms, and petechiae. However, it typically occurs within 24-72 hours after injury and is not directly associated with blood transfusions.

 

Option D. Hemorrhagic shock: Hemorrhagic shock results from significant blood loss, leading to hypotension and tachycardia. While this could be a consideration, the transfusion reaction and subsequent DIC better explain the patient's clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) can lead to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), characterized by rapid onset of fever, bleeding from multiple sites, and hemolysis shortly after a blood transfusion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Bishop score? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type of maternal pelvis

 

Explanation:

 

Bishop Score

 

  • This is a scoring system used to assess the favorability of the cervix to respond to induction of labor. 
  • A cervix that is soft in consistency, a little dilated, short in length, anteriorly placed and the station of the presenting low down will respond well to induction of labor. 
  • The Bishop score was replaced by the Modified Bishop score, wherein, the cervical effacement (in terms of percentage) was replaced by cervical length (in cm). 
  • The 5 components of the Modified Bishop score are:
    1. Cervical Dilatation
    2. Cervical length
    3. Cervical consistency
    4. Cervical Position
    5. Station of the presenting part

 

Easy to remember Mnemonic

 

B – Bishop

 

I – Effacement

 

S – Station of presenting part

 

H – Hard/ soft (consistency)

 

O – Os dilatation (cervical dilatation)

 

P – Position of the cervix
 

  • The scoring is as shown in the table.
  • Each component is scored from 0 to 3
  • The highest score is 13 and the lowest is 0
  • A favourable score is > 6. This means the patient will respond favorably to methods of induction of labor. 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Cervical length: This is a component of the Modified Bishop score, measuring the length of the cervix in centimeters.

 

Option C. Cervical position: This is a component of the Bishop score, assessing the position of the cervix relative to the vaginal canal.

 

Option D. Dilatation of cervix: This is a component of the Bishop score, measuring the extent to which the cervix has opened.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Type of maternal pelvis is not a component of the Bishop score.

 

Ref: Page no 600, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: ERCP is least useful in the diagnosis of: (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute Pancreatitis without choledocholithiasis

 

  • ERCP is not the best diagnostic option for acute pancreatitis without choledocholithiasis.

 

ERCP is typically not the first-line diagnostic tool for acute pancreatitis unless there is a specific reason to suspect bile duct involvement or gallstones as a cause. It is not routinely used for diagnosing acute pancreatitis without choledocholithiasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrent pancreatitis: ERCP can be useful in diagnosing the cause of recurrent pancreatitis, especially if there is a suspicion of gallstones or other biliary problems contributing to the condition like pancreas divisum.

 

Option B. Unexplained jaundice: ERCP is valuable in cases of unexplained jaundice because it can help identify any blockages or abnormalities in the bile ducts or pancreatic ducts that may be causing the jaundice.

 

Option C. Periampullary mass: ERCP can aid in the evaluation of periampullary masses, as it allows visualization and potential tissue sampling from this region, helping in Diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • ERCP stands for Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography, which is used to visualize the pancreatic or biliary tree using a side-viewing endoscope.
  • ERCP can be therapeutic or diagnostic and is the best modality for examining the distal biliary tree.
  • Indications for ERCP include relieving biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease, biliary drainage, biliary stenting for strictures and leakage, tissue sampling of the biliary or pancreatic ductal system, balloon dilation of the duodenal papilla or ductal strictures, sphincterotomy, and sphincter of Oddi manometry.
  • Therapeutic ERCP is most commonly used to alleviate biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease and benign or malignant biliary strictures.
  • ERCP can be used to diagnose pancreatic divisum, which may present with recurrent pancreatitis.

questions.text: All of the following are the contents of the carotid sheath except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sympathetic chain

 

Explanation:

 

The carotid sheath's content is not the sympathetic chain. It is located in the neck, behind the carotid sheath and in front of the transverse processes of the cervical vertebrae.

 

The carotid sheath is a layer of loose connective tissue formed by adjacent portions of the investing layer of deep cervical fascia, the pretracheal fascia, and the prevertebral fascia.

 

Contents of carotid sheath:

 

  • Common and internal carotid arteries
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve (10th Cranial nerve)
  • Ansa cervicalis

 

Note: The glossopharyngeal, accessory, and hypoglossal nerves are located in the carotid sheath's upper portion.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carotid artery: The common carotid artery and its internal branch (the internal carotid artery) are primary contents of the carotid sheath. In the neck, the common carotid bifurcates into the internal and external carotid arteries. Only the internal carotid artery continues to ascend within the carotid sheath.

 

Option C. Internal jugular vein: The internal jugular vein is a major vein in the neck that drains the brain, face, and much of the neck. It runs in close proximity to the internal and common carotid arteries and is another primary content of the carotid sheath.

 

Option D. 10th cranial nerve, which is also known as Vagus nerve. It is present in carotid sheath medial to internal jugular vein and lateral to internal carotid artery. It is a mixed nerve.It descends from the skull base through the jugular foramen and is present in the carotid sheath. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sympathetic chain (sympathetic trunk) is a bilateral series of ganglia that run vertically alongside the vertebral column. It is involved in the autonomic sympathetic innervation of the body. Importantly, the sympathetic chain itself is not contained within the carotid sheath. However, sympathetic fibers that come from the chain (e.g., the carotid plexus) do accompany structures within the sheath, especially the internal and common carotid arteries.

questions.text: Medial lemniscus is a continuation of which of the following structures? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fasciculus gracilis

 

Medial lemniscus is a continuation of fasciculus gracilis as well as fasciculus cuneatus.

 

Posterior column-medial lemniscal pathway:

 

In the dorsal horn, first-order axons carrying proprioception vibration  and two point discrimination sensations continue their upward journey as the fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus.

 

Fibers of these fasciculi synapse on the second-order neurons of the ipsilateral nuclei gracilis and cuneatus in the medulla oblongata, respectively.

 

Axons of these second-order neurons then cross over as the internal arcuate fibers to form the medial lemniscus in the contralateral medulla.

 

These second-order axons ascend through the brainstem to reach the third-order neuronal cell bodies in the ventral posterior lateral nucleus of the thalamus. Axons from the third-order neurons then project through the posterior limb of the internal capsule to reach the primary somatosensory cortex.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spinothalamic tract: The spinothalamic tract is an important ascending pathway that primarily carries pain, temperature, and crude touch sensations. The pathway originates from the spinal cord and projects directly to the thalamus without becoming the medial lemniscus. However, after relaying in the thalamus, fibers from the spinothalamic tract and the medial lemniscus converge to project to similar regions of the cerebral cortex.

 

Option B. Spinocerebellar tract: The spinocerebellar tracts (anterior and posterior) are pathways that convey proprioceptive information (concerning the position and movement of body parts) from the body to the cerebellum. They do not form the medial lemniscus.

 

Option C. Spinotectal tract: The spinotectal tract is an ascending pathway that carries sensory information related to reflex movements of the eyes and head in response to visual and tactile stimuli. It connects the spinal cord to the tectum of the midbrain (specifically, the superior colliculus). It does not become the medial lemniscus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fasciculus gracilis (and its counterpart, the fasciculus cuneatus) are ascending tracts in the spinal cord that carry fine touch, vibration, and proprioceptive sensations from the body to the brain.

 

These fibers travel upwards in the spinal cord and synapse in the nucleus gracilis (and nucleus cuneatus for the fasciculus cuneatus) located in the medulla oblongata. After synapsing, second-order neurons cross the midline and form the medial lemniscus, which then ascends to the thalamus.

 

Thus, the medial lemniscus is indeed a continuation of the fibers originally present in the fasciculus gracilis (and fasciculus cuneatus).

questions.text: A healthcare professional is reviewing vaccine protocols to update patient information materials. In doing so, she focuses on the type of vaccine used for diphtheria prevention. Which option correctly describes the type of diphtheria vaccine? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Toxoid

 

  • The diphtheria vaccine is a toxoid vaccine, which involves the use of toxins produced by the bacterium that causes the disease.
  • These toxins are chemically inactivated to form toxoids, which are safe for use in vaccines but still capable of eliciting a strong immune response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of vaccine -

questions.text: All of the following are crosslinking fixatives except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methanol

 

Methanol is not a crosslinking fixative. It is a dehydrant coagulant fixative.

 

 

Compound fixatives are mixtures of reagents. Eg: alcoholic formalin fixes tissues in two ways i.e firstly, by adding covalent hydroxymethyl groups and crosslinking proteins and secondly, by coagulation and dehydration.

 

Crosslinking fixatives, on the other hand, work by forming covalent bonds between proteins and other molecules, stabilizing the tissue structure and preserving the morphology for microscopic examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutaraldehyde: A crosslinking fixative that forms stable covalent bonds between proteins, commonly used in electron microscopy.

 

Option B. Formaldehyde: Another crosslinking fixative, often used in light microscopy, that preserves tissues by forming crosslinks between proteins.

 

Option D. Osmium tetroxide: A crosslinking fixative used primarily in electron microscopy to preserve and ultrastructural visualization of cell membranes, as an additive for post-fixation after glutaraldehyde.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methanol is a dehydrant coagulant fixative and does not function as a crosslinking fixative like glutaraldehyde, formaldehyde, or osmium tetroxide.

questions.text: Specimen handling for molecular testing of SARS CoV-2 would require? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) BSL2

 

Biosafety Level 2 (BSL-2) is required for handling specimens for molecular testing of SARS-CoV-2. BSL-2 facilities are designed for work involving agents that pose moderate hazards to personnel and the environment. This includes diagnostic and other procedures involving the manipulation of known or suspected infectious materials, such as SARS-CoV-2, which causes COVID-19.

 

For culturing SARS-CoV-2, which involves growing the virus, higher containment is necessary. Therefore, BSL-3 facilities would be required to ensure higher levels of protection against aerosol transmission and potential infection.

 

Other Options
