Option A. BSL1: This level is used for work with well-characterized agents that are not known to consistently cause disease in healthy adults and present minimal potential hazard to laboratory personnel and the environment. It is not suitable for handling SARS-CoV-2 specimens.

 

Option C. BSL3: While this level is appropriate for culturing SARS-CoV-2 due to the need for higher containment, it is not required for routine molecular testing.

 

Option D. BSL4: This level is reserved for work with dangerous and exotic agents that pose a high risk of aerosol-transmitted laboratory infections and life-threatening disease. It is not necessary for handling SARS-CoV-2 specimens for molecular testing.

 

Educational Objective

 

SARS CoV 2 requires BSL-2 or equivalent facilities.

questions.text: A young male who is shy and prefers social isolation appears to be emotionally cold and resides alone. There is no history of hallucinations or delusions. The most likely diagnosis is: (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schizoid personality disorder

 

Schizoid personality disorder is marked by detachment from social relationships and a restricted range of emotional expression. Individuals prefer solitude and appear emotionally cold.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paranoid personality disorder: It is characterized by excessive suspiciousness and distrust of others. They may be excessively sensitive and give excessive importance to themselves. The vignette described above does not mention suspiciousness, infact mentions there is no history of delusions. Hence the answer is not paranoid personality disorder.

 

Option C. Antisocial personality disorder: These patients disregard others' rights and frequently violates them. They frequently get involved in unlawful behaviours such as theft, conning etc. 

 

Option D. Emotionally unstable personality disorder: Otherwise known as Borderline personality disorder. They are almost always in the state of crisis. They have a history of unstable relationships and emotions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by detachment from social relationships and prefer solitary activities. They are emotionally cold and are indifferent to praise or criticism. There is also an absence of close relationships. It is classified as Cluster A personality disorder.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 746.

choices.text: Contraction stress test

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of fetal biophysical profile? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Contraction stress test

 

The fetal biophysical profile (BPP) is a comprehensive assessment used to evaluate fetal well-being, and it includes five components:

 

  1. NST (Non-Stress Test): Evaluates fetal heart rate reactivity.
  2. Amniotic Fluid Volume (AFV): Assessed through ultrasound to check the amount of amniotic fluid.
  3. Fetal Movement: Observes fetal movements through ultrasound.
  4. Fetal Tone: Evaluates the presence of fetal muscle tone and limb movements.
  5. Fetal Breathing: Assesses the presence and duration of fetal breathing movements.

 

The Contraction Stress Test (CST) is not part of the BPP. Instead, it is a separate test used to assess the fetal heart rate response to uterine contractions, helping to evaluate how well the fetus handles the stress of contractions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal movement: This is a component of the BPP, assessing the number of fetal movements.

 

Option B. Fetal breathing: This is a component of the BPP, evaluating the presence of fetal breathing movements.

 

Option C. NST: The Non-Stress Test is a key component of the BPP, measuring fetal heart rate reactivity to movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Contraction Stress Test is not a component of the fetal biophysical profile.

 

Ref: Page no 122, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient comes to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of repetitive thoughts that, he always feels his hands are dirty, though they are not. This gives him discomfort and hence he has to wash them again and again. This is a disorder of thought:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Possession

 

The patient is experiencing obsessive thoughts. Obsessions are repetitive, intrusive, and unwanted thoughts that cause significant anxiety or distress. The individual recognizes that the obsessions are a product of his or her own mind, but they feel as though they can't control the thoughts, hence they fall under the category of disorders of thought possession.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Flow: Refers to the rate and speed of thoughts. Examples of disorders of flow include flight of ideas or inhibition of thinking.

 

Option B. Form: Refers to the organization and structure of thought. Examples of disorders of form include tangentiality, circumstantiality, and word salad.

 

Option D. Content: Refers to what person is actually thinking about, such as delusions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Obsessions, as seen in obsessive-compulsive disorder, are considered disturbances of thought possession because while the individual recognizes the thoughts as their own, they feel as though they can't control them.

 

Reference: Fish’s Clinical Psychopathology, 4th edition, Page No 46.

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo, diplopia, hoarseness, dysphagia and left Horner's syndrome associated with numbness of the left face and right-side limbs. Which artery is affected in this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

 

Clinical features are suggestive of Lateral Medullary syndrome/Wallenburg syndrome which occurs due to PICA occlusion. His syndrome is characterized by a range of neurological deficits due to ischemia in the lateral part of the medulla oblongata, where PICA provides blood supply.

 

Clinical Features Associated with PICA Occlusion:

 

  • Vertigo and Diplopia: Caused by the involvement of the vestibular nuclei and adjacent structures.
  • Hoarseness and Dysphagia: Result from damage to the nucleus ambiguous, affecting the vagal and glossopharyngeal nerve functions.
  • Horner’s Syndrome: Occurs due to disruption of the sympathetic pathways.
  • Numbness of the Face and Contralateral Limbs: Caused by damage to the spinal trigeminal nucleus and the spinothalamic tract, respectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (AICA): Affects a similar region but typically presents with symptoms like hearing loss due to its supply to the inner ear structures, which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Option C. Superior Cerebellar Artery: Occlusion typically results in ataxia and coordination difficulties without the cross-sensory loss observed in Wallenberg's Syndrome.

 

Option D. Basilar Artery: A much broader array of symptoms would be expected, potentially affecting multiple cranial nerve and long tract functions simultaneously.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Image: Arteries involved in brainstem syndromes lateral vs medial brainstem

 

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Chap 426, Neurology/stroke

choices.text: Haemophilus influenzae

questions.text: Pneumonia caused by a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus growing on chocolate agar which is catalase and oxidase-positive. Identify the microorganism. (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Haemophilus influenzae

 

Findings are suggestive of Hemophilus influenza.

 

Hemophilus influenza –

 

  • Slender, short, gram negative rods or coccobacillus
  • Non-Motile, no flagella or pilli
  • Capsules are present and important in pathogenicity.
  • Encapsulated form are coccobacilli, CSF Sample
  • Non-Capsulated are pleomorphic, long, thread, filamentous
  • Fastidious Microorganism

 

Culture:

 

  • Blood Agar: translucent, low, convex or flat pin point colonies, Satellitism.
  • Chocolate Agar: Grayish, Transparent, smooth, low, convex or flat with a slightly splayed out, entire edge, mucoid, pale
  • In liquid medium like Levinthal’s Broth or Filde’s Broth: Uniform Turbidity.

 

Hemophilus influenzae biochemical reactions-

 

 

  • Haemophilus influenzae can cause many kinds of infections. Which can range from mild ear infections to severe diseases, like meningitis. Haemophilus influenzae bacteria most often cause pneumonia, bacteremia, and meningitis mostly in infants and children younger than five years of age.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. E. coli: Although it can cause pneumonia, E. coli is typically a gram-negative rod that grows on MacConkey agar and is not usually pleomorphic. It is catalase-positive but not typically grown on chocolate agar.

 

Option B. Pseudomonas: This genus includes Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is a gram-negative rod that grows on various media, including nutrient agar and MacConkey agar. It is oxidase-positive but does not typically present as pleomorphic.

 

Option D. Actinomyces: This is a gram-positive bacterium and not relevant to this question as it does not fit the gram-negative description.

 

Educational Objective

 

Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus that grows on chocolate agar and is catalase and oxidase-positive. It is a common cause of respiratory infections, including pneumonia, particularly in young children.

 

Additional Information

choices.text: Light green SF
Orange G
Eosin B

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Papanicolaou stain? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Eosin B

 

Eosin B is not a component of Papanicolaou stain.

 

Papanicolaou stain is the most popular stain used in the practice of histopathology. It is a polychrome stain containing multiple dyes to stain the various components of cells differentially. Papanicolaou stain includes both acidic and basic dyes:

 

The classic form of Pap stain involves five dyes in three solutions:

 

  1. A nuclear stain, hematoxylin, is used to stain cell nuclei.
  2. First OG-6 counterstain. The Orange G is used to stain keratin.
  3. Second EA (Eosin Azure) counterstain, comprising of three dyes
    • Eosin Y stains the superficial epithelial squamous cells, nucleoli, cilia, and red blood cells.
    • Light Green SF yellowish stains the cytoplasm of all other cells.
    • Bismarck brown Y – omitted in contemporary formulations

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Light green SF: This dye is used in the Pap stain to color the cytoplasm of various cells green.

 

Option B. Orange G: This dye stains keratin and protein-rich components orange.

 

Option D. Hematoxylin: A nuclear stain used to color cell nuclei blue-purple.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eosin B is not a component of the Papanicolaou stain, which uses a combination of hematoxylin, Orange G, and Eosin Azure (including Eosin Y and Light Green SF) to differentially stain cellular components.

questions.text: This is the graph depicting the filterability of dextran through the kidney, 1 representing complete filtration and 0 representing no filtration. Choose the substance A, B, C respectively? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Polycationic, Neutral, polyanionic

 

Based on the given graph, that A has the highest filterability, followed by B and C, it is likely that A has a smaller size and/or a positive charge, making it easier to pass through the filtration membrane. Similarly, C is likely larger and/or negatively charged, leading to reduced filterability. Therefore, the answer would be: Polycationic, Neutral, Polyanionic.

 

Negatively charged glomerular filtration barrier is responsible for the differential filtration of charged substances. The order of filterability observed in the graph suggests that A is polycationic, B is neutral, and C is polyanionic. This is because polycationic substances would be readily filtered due to their positive charge, while polyanionic substances would be repelled by the negatively charged barrier and exhibit low filterability. Neutral substances would fall somewhere in between, depending on their size and shape. The molecular size exclusion limit you mentioned (between 4-8 nm) is also important for determining which substances are able to be filtered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The filterability of substances through the kidney glomerular filtration barrier depends on their charge and size. Polycationic substances (positively charged) filter most readily, neutral substances have intermediate filterability, and polyanionic substances (negatively charged) have the least filterability due to repulsion by the negatively charged barrier.

questions.text: A child was brought to the OPD with a swollen, red knee joint that is tender to touch. 2 weeks prior, he had an episode of fever with bloody diarrhea. Which of the following could be the possible organism? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shigella

 

The given clinical history is suggestive of reactive arthritis after shigella infection.

 

Shigellosis is a diarrheal infection caused by Shigella species—gram-negative, non-spore forming, facultative anaerobes that infect the intestinal lining—and spread by fecal-oral transmission.

 

Shigella species (eg, S dysenteriae, S flexneri, S sonnei, S boydii) are aerobic, nonmotile, glucose-fermenting, gram-negative rods that are highly contagious, causing diarrhea after ingestion of as few as 180 organisms.

 

These pathogens cause damage by two mechanisms, (1) invasion of the colonic epithelium, which is dependent on a plasmid-mediated virulence factor, and (2) production of an enterotoxin, which is not essential for colitis but enhances the virulence.

 

Symptoms of shigellosis include acute bloody diarrhea, abdominal cramping, tenesmus, urgency, fever, occasional vomiting and dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E. coli: Certain strains of E. coli (such as EHEC) can cause bloody diarrhea and may lead to complications like Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS), but reactive arthritis is less commonly associated with E. coli.

 

Option C. Giardia: Giardia typically causes watery diarrhea rather than bloody diarrhea and is not commonly associated with reactive arthritis.

 

Option D. Rotavirus: Rotavirus infection primarily causes watery diarrhea in young children and is not associated with bloody diarrhea or reactive arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reactive arthritis can occur following an infection with Shigella species, which is known for causing bloody diarrhea. This condition presents with joint inflammation and pain, typically occurring several weeks after the initial gastrointestinal symptoms.

 

Infection with Shigella species may be associated with extra gastrointestinal complications-

 

  1. Bacteremia
  2. Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome characterized by acute hemolysis, renal failure, uremia, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
  3. Metabolic disturbances: Hyponatremia secondary to the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) secretion may occur.
  4. Leukemoid reaction: An elevated white blood cell (WBC) count of 50,000/mm3 occurs in approximately 4% of patients, mainly in children aged 2-10 years.
  5. Neurologic disease: Seizures, the most common neurologic complication.
  6. Encephalopathy with lethargy, confusion, and headache
  7. Reactive arthritis (also known as Reiter syndrome) may occur.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with a history of bipolar disorder has recently been started on lithium therapy. During a follow-up visit, the healthcare provider wants to educate the patient on the signs of lithium toxicity. Which of the following side effects should the patient be instructed to monitor and report immediately as they may indicate lithium toxicity? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ataxia and Diarrhea

 

Ataxia, tinnitus and diarrhea are common signs of lithium toxicity. Lithium has a narrow therapeutic range, meaning that the difference between a therapeutic dose and a toxic dose is small. Therefore, monitoring for signs of toxicity is crucial. Other signs of lithium toxicity can include tremors, confusion, and vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaise and sore throat: While these symptoms can be concerning, they are not typically associated with lithium toxicity. They might be indicative of an infection or other unrelated conditions.

 

Option C. Fever: Fever is not a common sign of lithium toxicity. It may indicate an infection or other illness.

 

Option D. Breathlessness: This symptom is not typically associated with lithium toxicity. Breathlessness might be related to other medical conditions such as respiratory or cardiac issues.

 

Therefore, patients on lithium therapy should be particularly vigilant for symptoms like ataxia and diarrhea, as they could indicate the onset of lithium toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients on lithium therapy should be educated to monitor and immediately report signs of lithium toxicity, such as ataxia and diarrhea, to prevent serious adverse effects.

 

Mnemonic

 

If DAT symptom is present, report to hospital:

 

  • Diarrhea
  • Ataxia
  • Tinnitus

questions.text: A muscle is attached to the area marked in the given image. What is the action of this muscle on the hip joint?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Extension and lateral rotation

 

Explanation:

 

The gluteal tuberosity is indicated by the marked area in the photograph. The gluteus maximus, which is implanted here, produces lateral rotation and extension of the hip joint. Extension involves increasing the angle between the femur and the pelvis, essentially the opposite of flexion. Lateral rotation, refers to turning the anterior aspect of the femur away from the midline.

 

Three-quarters of the gluteus maximus attach to the iliotibial tract, while one-fourth attach to the gluteal tuberosity (marked in image). The inferior gluteal nerve supplies it. At the hip joint, it serves as the primary extensor of the lower limb. Abduction and lateral rotation are additional effects.

 

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Flexion and medial rotation:

 

  • Flexion is the movement of bending the joint, resulting in a decrease of the angle between the femur and the pelvis. Medial rotation involves turning the anterior aspect of the femur inwards, toward the midline.
  • The gluteus maximus is not primarily responsible for these actions. Instead, other muscles, such as the iliopsoas and anterior fibers of the gluteus medius and minimus, play roles in hip flexion and medial rotation.

 

Option B. Adduction and lateral rotation:

 

  • Adduction involves drawing the limb toward the midline of the body, while lateral rotation refers to turning the anterior aspect of the femur away from the midline.
  • While the gluteus maximus does have fibers that can contribute to lateral rotation, it's not a primary adductor of the hip. Instead, the hip adductors (like adductor longus, adductor brevis, adductor magnus) primarily mediate adduction

 

Option C. Abduction and medial rotation:

 

  • Abduction involves moving the limb away from the midline, and as mentioned above, medial rotation involves turning the anterior aspect of the femur inwards.
  • The gluteus maximus is not a primary abductor or medial rotator of the hip. The gluteus medius and minimus are the primary muscles responsible for hip abduction, and various other muscles, including anterior fibers of the gluteus medius and minimus, contribute to medial rotation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gluteus maximus is a primary extensor and lateral rotator of the hip joint. When you stand up from a seated position, climb stairs, or rise from a squat, the gluteus maximus is heavily involved in extending the hip.

choices.text: Gently replace the cord inside the vagina
Inform the doctor and shift to OT
Do vaginal examination and find the fetal presentation

questions.text: A midwife is examining a pregnant woman in labour when she noticed that there is cord prolapse. What should be the next immediate step of management? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Put her in Trendelenburg position

 

Cord prolapse is an obstetric emergency where the umbilical cord slips ahead of the presenting part of the fetus in the birth canal, leading to compression of the cord. This compression can restrict blood flow and oxygen to the fetus, causing fetal distress or hypoxia.

 

The immediate management of cord prolapse includes:

 

  • Relieving pressure off the cord: This is crucial to prevent fetal hypoxia. This can be achieved by positioning the patient in a way that minimizes pressure on the cord.
  • Trendelenburg position: This position involves tilting the patient’s body with the head down and the pelvis up. This helps to shift the fetal presenting part off the prolapsed cord and relieves compression.
  • Left lateral position or All-fours position: Alternative positions can also help in relieving pressure on the cord.

 

While preparing for an emergency cesarean section (LSCS) to deliver the fetus urgently, these positions and techniques are used to temporarily alleviate the pressure on the cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gently replace the cord inside the vagina: Attempting to reposition the cord is not recommended as it can cause further damage or spasm of the vessels in the cord.

 

Option B. Inform the doctor and shift to OT: While informing the doctor and preparing for cesarean delivery is necessary, immediate steps to relieve cord compression should be taken first.

 

Option D. Do vaginal examination and find the fetal presentation: This may be done, but the primary focus should be on relieving the pressure on the cord immediately to prevent fetal distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of cord prolapse, placing the patient in Trendelenburg position helps to relieve pressure on the prolapsed cord and is a critical step in managing the emergency until a cesarean section can be performed.

 

Ref: Page 1129, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drug is not bactericidal? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Thioacetazone

 

Thioacetazone is a bacteriostatic anti-tubercular drug. Bacteriostatic drugs inhibit the growth and replication of bacteria, rather than killing them outright. Thioacetazone is less commonly used nowadays due to its side effects and the availability of more effective treatments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: Isoniazid is a bactericidal drug against actively dividing Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria. It works by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid, a critical component of the bacterial cell wall.

 

Option B. Rifapentin: Rifapentin is a bactericidal antibiotic and is a derivative of rifampicin. It works by inhibiting bacterial RNA synthesis and is used primarily in the treatment of tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Kanamycin: Kanamycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic and is bactericidal. It works by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis. It is used as a second-line drug for the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thioacetazone is a bacteriostatic anti-tubercular drug, which means it inhibits bacterial growth rather than killing the bacteria outright. In contrast, isoniazid, rifapentin, and kanamycin are all bactericidal drugs used in the treatment of tuberculosis.

questions.text: Cardiac output can be determined using the following except? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Capnography 

 

  • Function: Capnography primarily measures the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled air, which gives information about ventilation and metabolism.
  • Usage: It is used to confirm tracheal intubation and monitor ventilation status but does not measure cardiac output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thermal dilution technique: The thermal dilution technique is a method used primarily with a pulmonary artery catheter (also known as a Swan-Ganz catheter). Cold saline is injected into the right atrium, and the change in blood temperature is measured as it passes a thermistor in the pulmonary artery. The degree of temperature change allows for the calculation of cardiac output. This method is invasive and provides continuous or intermittent measurements, depending on the specific catheter and monitor used.

 

Option C. Esophageal Doppler: The esophageal Doppler uses ultrasound waves to measure blood flow velocity in the descending aorta via a probe placed in the esophagus. By knowing the cross-sectional area of the aorta and calculating the velocity of blood flow, cardiac output can be estimated.

 

Option D. Echocardiography: Echocardiography, or cardiac ultrasound, allows for visualization of cardiac structures and blood flow. Cardiac output can be estimated by measuring the velocity of blood flow across the mitral or tricuspid valves and then multiplying this by the valve area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Capnography is used to measure end-tidal CO2 and confirm tracheal intubation but is not used to determine cardiac output. Cardiac output can be measured using invasive methods such as the thermal dilution technique and non-invasive methods such as esophageal Doppler and echocardiography.

questions.text: The life cycle of an organism is given below. Identify the vector involved? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trombiculid mite

 

The above picture shows the life cycle of trombiculid mite.

 

Orientia tsutsugamushi, an obligate intracellular Gram-negative bacterium, is the causative agent of scrub typhus, a vector-borne disease transmitted by infected chiggers (trombiculid mite larvae).

 

Host: A number of small rodents particularly wild rats of subgenus Rattus are the natural hosts for scrub typhus

 

The incubation period of scrub typhus is about 6 to 21 days

 

The infection is transmitted to man and rodents by some species of infective trombiculid mites.

 

Once, the mite is infected in nature by feeding on the body fluid of small mammals, including the rodents, they maintain the infection throughout their life stages and, as adults, pass the infection on to their eggs in a process called transovarial transmission. Similarly, the infection passes from the egg to the larva or adult in a process called transstadial transmission. In this way, chigger mite populations can autonomously maintain their infectivity over long periods of time.

 

A large number of the Orientia tsutsugamushi are present in the salivary glands of the larvae and these are injected into its host when it feeds. The bite of the mite leaves a characteristic black eschar that is useful to the doctor for making the diagnosis.

 

Human infection takes place when man accidentally picks up an infective larval mite while walking, sitting, or lying on the infested ground.

 

The adult mites have a four-stage lifecycle: egg, larva, nymph and adult.

 

The larva is the only stage (chigger) that can transmit the disease to humans and other vertebrates, since the other life stages (nymph and adult) do not feed on vertebrate animals. Both the nymph and the adult are free-living in the soil.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Hard tick: Hard ticks, such as Ixodes species, are vectors for diseases like Lyme disease and are not involved in the life cycle shown in the image.

 

Option B. Soft tick: Soft ticks, like Ornithodoros species, are vectors for diseases such as tick-borne relapsing fever, but are not depicted in the life cycle in the image.

 

Option D. Louse: Lice are vectors for diseases like epidemic typhus, caused by Rickettsia prowazekii, and are not involved in the life cycle shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective

 

The trombiculid mite, particularly its larval stage (chigger), is the vector for scrub typhus, transmitting Orientia tsutsugamushi to humans and rodents through its bite, which leaves a characteristic black eschar.

questions.text: The sequence of vitamin D synthesis is? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Skin- Liver- Kidney

 

The sequence of vitamin D synthesis is skin-liver-kidney.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The synthesis of vitamin D follows the sequence of Skin → Liver → Kidney, with each organ playing a critical role in converting the precursor to its active form.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with tuberculosis is learning about available government support for nutritional aid during treatment. Which of the following accurately represents a feature of the Nikshay Poshan Yojana? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) ₹ 500 is given per month

 

  • Nikshay Poshan Yojana provides nutritional support in the form of money to patients of TB.
  • Patients receive ₹ 500 per month under this scheme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nikshay Poshan Yojana:

 

  • Financial incentive of Rs 500/- per month for each notified TB patient for duration for which the patient is on anti-TB treatment
  • All TB patients notified on or after 1st April 2018 including all existing TB patients under treatment are eligible to receive incentive

choices.text: Tidal volume - 12 ml/kg of actual BW

questions.text: A patient of blunt chest trauma has been intubated and started on mechanical ventilation. Which of the following is not correct about the initial setting? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tidal volume – 12 ml/kg of actual BW 

 

  • Incorrect Setting: The generally recommended starting tidal volume for many patients, especially those at risk for or with established acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), is closer to 6 ml/kg of ideal body weight. Using 12 ml/kg of actual body weight can potentially lead to lung injury, especially in patients with pre-existing lung pathology or those who are at risk, such as trauma patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory rate - 12 Breaths/min: This is a typical starting point for the respiratory rate (RR) in many mechanically ventilated adults. The RR can be adjusted based on the patient's metabolic needs, acid-base balance, and CO2 levels.

 

Option B. PEEP - 5 cm H2O: Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) helps keep alveoli open at the end of expiration, improving oxygenation and potentially preventing alveolar collapse. A starting PEEP of 5 cm H2O is a common initial setting in many ventilated patients, and it can be titrated based on oxygenation needs and potential hemodynamic effects.

 

Option C. FiO2 - 100%: Fraction of Inspired Oxygen (FiO2) refers to the concentration of oxygen in the gas mixture. Starting with a high FiO2, like 100%, ensures that the patient is receiving the maximum amount of oxygen. However, it's important to titrate this down as quickly as clinically feasible to avoid potential oxygen toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient started on mechanical ventilation, ideal ventilatory settings include a tidal volume of 4-6 ml/kg of ideal body weight, a respiratory rate of 12-18 breaths/min, an initial FiO2 of 100% titrated down to maintain SpO2 > 95%, and a starting PEEP of 5 cm H2O. Using a tidal volume of 12 ml/kg of actual body weight is incorrect and can lead to lung injury.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2660

questions.text: A known alcoholic patient is brought to the emergency in a disoriented state. He complains of seeing snakes and insects crawling on his skin. Which of the following should be given to this patient? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lorazepam + thiamine

 

Explanation:

 

The patient is displaying signs of alcohol withdrawal, particularly delirium tremens (DTs) which is characterized by confusion, visual and tactile hallucinations (like seeing snakes and feeling bugs crawling on the skin), tremors, and autonomic hyperactivity.

 

  • Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine and is the treatment of choice for alcohol withdrawal, including DTs.
  • Thiamine is essential to administer before or alongside glucose administration to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy in alcohol-dependent individuals.

  • Haloperidol may be used to control severe agitation or hallucinations but is not a first-line therapy for DTs and could lower the seizure threshold.

     

Educational Objective: 

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 631-632.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about skeletal muscle contraction? (INICET May 2020)

 

  1. Extracellular Ca2+ is important for contraction
  2. Ca2+ is released from mitochondria
  3. Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
  4. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on T tubule have no role in EC coupling
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3 only

 

During the contraction of the skeletal muscle, the Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Only statement 3 is correct.

 

Excitation contraction coupling refers to the process by which the membrane depolarization of the muscle fibre (excitation) leads to the contraction of the muscle.

 

The steps of excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle are as follows:

 

 

  • Motor-neuron discharge causes the release of acetylcholine at the motor endplate, which binds to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.
  • This causes increased Na+ and K+ conductance in the endplate membrane generating local end-plate potential.
  • When the local endplate potential reaches a threshold for the muscle fibre, and an action potential is generated.
  • The generated action potential passes inward through the T tubules, via activating voltage gated Ca2+ channels, leading to the spread of depolarization.
  • The depolarization of the muscle fibre releases of Ca2+ from terminal cisterns of sarcoplasmic reticulum and diffusion to thick and thin filaments.
  • The calcium released, binds to troponin C, uncovering myosin-binding sites on actin.
  • Cross-linkages formed between actin and myosin and sliding of thin on thick filaments causes contraction of the skeletal muscle.

 

Steps in relaxation:

 

 

Extracellular calcium levels play an important role in muscle contraction specially in smooth and cardiac muscle, when there is a decrease in extracellular calcium as in hypocalcemia, the voltage-gated sodium channels are activated, which causes sodium influx. The increased intracellular sodium concentration causes sustained depolarization, which may lead to tetany.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2, 3, 4: Incorrect. Ca2+ is not released from mitochondria do not play a direct role in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on T tubule needs to be activated in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle.

 

Option C. 1, 2, 4: Incorrect. Extracellular Ca2+ is not directly important for skeletal muscle contraction, and Ca2+ is not released from mitochondria. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on T tubule needs to be activated in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle.

 

Option D. 1, 3, 4: Incorrect. Although Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (statement 3 is correct), Extracellular Ca2+ is not directly important and voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on T tubule needs to be activated in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During skeletal muscle contraction, Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, which is essential for muscle contraction.

questions.text: Which of the following caspase binds to Cytochrome C and APAF-1 complex? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Caspase 9  

 

Caspase 9 binds to Cyt-c and APAF-1 complex.

 

Apoptotic stimuli cause the release of cytochrome C into the cytosol. Cytochrome-C binds to a protein called APAF-1 (apoptosis-activating factor-1) to form the apoptosome.

 

This complex then binds caspase-9, resulting in the activation of other caspases.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caspase 1: Involved in the inflammatory response and not in the intrinsic apoptotic pathway.

 

Option B. Caspase 8: Associated with the extrinsic apoptotic pathway, activated by death receptors on the cell surface.

 

Option D. Caspase 4: Involved in the inflammatory response and not directly related to the intrinsic apoptotic pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caspase 9 is the initiator caspase in the intrinsic apoptotic pathway and is activated by binding to the cytochrome C and APAF-1 complex (the apoptosome).

choices.text: All zone 1 injury to be treated conservatively
Zone 3 injury whether blunt or penetrative should always be explored
Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically
Mattox maneuver is when the ascending colon is mobilized to the right to visualise the Aorta

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding retroperitoneal trauma? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically

 

Zone 2 hematoma is seen in flank region and typically related to renal injury. Zone 2 hematomas may be conserved unless they are expanding, when surgery is indicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All zone 1 injury to be treated conservatively: Zone 1 hematoma refers to central zone, where likely structures injured are abdominal aorta or IVC are injured. Since these are major vascular injuries, all zone 1 hematomas should be explored.

 

Option B. Zone 3 injury whether blunt or penetrative should always be explored: Zone 3 refers to the pelvis region, and injuries in this area Should be managed conservatively with pelvic binder or external fixator. Exploration in these areas is dangerous and should be avoided whenever possible.

 

Option D. Mattox maneuver is when the ascending colon is mobilized to the right to visualise the Aorta: The Mattox maneuver is a surgical technique used during emergency laparotomies to visualize the abdominal aorta. It involves mobilizing the left sided abdominal viscera medially, which allows for better visualization of the retroperitoneum and the aorta. This maneuver can be useful in cases of trauma or other emergency situations where visualization of the aorta is necessary.

choices.text: A, B, C and D

questions.text: Which of the following are used to stop esophageal variceal bleed? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A, B and C

 

 A, B, C can be used to stop esophageal variceal bleed.

 

 A: Sengstaken Blakemore tube

 

 B: Minnesota tube

 

 C: Gastric endoscope

 

A. Sengstaken Blakemore Tube:

 

  • The Sengstaken Blakemore tube is a medical device used for emergency management of esophageal and gastric variceal bleeding by causing balloon tamponade effect, typically associated with liver cirrhosis.
  • It consists of three lumens: one for inflation of esophageal and gastric balloons each and one for aspiration of gastric contents

 

B. Minnesota Tube:

 

  • Similar to SB tube, this has 4 channels, additionally for esophageal aspiration. It is also used for balloon tamponade.

 

C. Gastric Endoscope:

 

  • A gastric endoscope, also known as a gastroscopy or upper endoscopy, is a flexible tube with a camera at the end used for examining the esophagus, stomach, and the beginning of the small intestine.
  • It is primarily a diagnostic tool which can also be used for therapeutic interventions like variceal banding or sclerotherapy.

 

Other option:

 

D. Fiberoptic Bronchoscope:

 

  • A fiberoptic bronchoscope is a medical instrument used for examining the airways and lungs. It consists of a flexible tube with a light source and a camera that is passed through the nose or mouth into the trachea and bronchi.
  • It is used for diagnostic and therapeutic procedures related to the respiratory system, such as visualizing and obtaining samples from the airways, removing foreign bodies, and managing airway issues.

choices.text: Urine specimen is used
Sanger sequencing is used
Study of fluid in tumor microenvironment
DNA is collected in micro vessels

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding liquid-based cytology? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urine specimen is used

 

Liquid-based cytology can also be done using a urine specimen. It is commonly used in cervical cancer screening in place of a pap smear.

 

Liquid-based cytology is a method of preparing samples for examination in cytopathology. The sample is collected, normally by a small brush, in the same way as for a conventional smear test, but rather than the smear being transferred directly to a microscope slide, the sample is deposited into a small bottle of preservative liquid. At the laboratory, the liquid is treated to remove other elements such as mucus before a layer of cells is placed on a slide.

 

Liquid-based cytology uses:

 

  • Used in place of PAP smear for cervical screening (most common use)
  • Thyroid cyst fluid examination.
  • Oral lesions
  • Body fluids sampling (e.g., urine, pleural effusions), brushing samples (e.g. gastrointestinal tract, lung), and fine needle aspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sanger sequencing is used: Sanger sequencing is a method of DNA sequencing and is not related to liquid-based cytology.

 

Option C. Study of fluid in tumor microenvironment: Liquid-based cytology is not specifically focused on the study of tumor microenvironment fluids; rather, it is a method for preparing and analyzing cellular samples.

 

Option D. DNA is collected in micro vessels: This is not a description of liquid-based cytology but may relate to other molecular biology techniques.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liquid-based cytology can use urine specimens, among others, to prepare samples for cytological examination, offering advantages over traditional smear techniques in terms of sample preservation and clarity.

questions.text: A patient who was on antiepileptics for the management of seizure disorder started having visual disturbance. Evaluation reveals the contraction of the visual field. The drug responsible is likely to be? (AIIMS NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vigabatrin

 

Vigabatrin is an antiepileptic that works by inhibiting GABA Transaminase. It is used for the treatment of infantile spasms. It is known to cause visual field constriction in some patients. This adverse effect is thought to be due to the drug's influence on the retina and the central nervous system. Vigabatrin is particularly associated with bilateral concentric visual field constriction, and patients on this medication are often monitored with regular visual field testing.

 

Mnemonic

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenobarbitone: This is a barbiturate used to treat epilepsy, but it is not commonly associated with visual field defects. Its side effects may include sedation, dizziness, and cognitive changes, but not specifically visual disturbances like those described.

 

Option C. Ethosuximide: Primarily used for absence seizures, ethosuximide is not typically associated with visual field contractions. Its side effects can include gastrointestinal disturbances, drowsiness, and headaches.

 

Option D. Levetiracetam: Commonly used in various forms of epilepsy, levetiracetam's side effects can include drowsiness, weakness, and behavioral changes, but it is not commonly associated with significant visual field disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vigabatrin is an antiepileptic drug associated with visual field contraction, requiring regular monitoring of visual fields in patients receiving this medication.

questions.text: Indications for surgery (including biopsy) in a patient with Potts spine are all except: (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cold abscess without neurological involvement

 

POTT’S SPINE

 

  • Like tuberculosis of the bones and joints elsewhere in the body, TB of the spine is always secondary.
  • The tubercular spread to spine usually takes place from Lungs > lymph nodes.
  • The bacteria reach the spine via the hematogenous route, from the lungs or lymph nodes.
  • Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

 

 

 

  • Clinical features: 
    • Back pain, usually minimal, is the commonest and 1st symptom.
    • Tenderness is the earliest sign.
    • Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When picking an object up from floor, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine is in extension – Coin test
    • Earliest sign of neurological deficit – increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response.
    • The prominence of 2-3 spinous process, called angular kyphosis is commonest in tuberculosis because of 2 contiguous vertebra involved with paradiscal destruction.
    • In the thoracic region, kyphosis is most marked because of normal kyphotic curvature.

 

 

  • Tuberculosis is the most common cause of cold abscess.
  • Imaging:

 

1. Plain radiograph:

 

  • Earliest X-ray feature is loss of Curvature due to paravertebral spasm.
  • Reduction of disc space
  • Vertebral body destruction
  • Paravertebral abscess
  • Widening of mediastinum

 

2. CT scan:

 

  • It may detect a small paravertebral abscess, not otherwise seen on plain X-ray; may indicate precisely the extent of destruction of the vertebral body and posterior elements; and may show a sequestrum or a bony ridge pressing on the cord.

 

3. MRI:

 

  • Investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord.
  • It also shows condition of the underlying neural tissues, and thus helps in predicting the prognosis in a particular case.

 

 

4. Biopsy:

 

  • CT guided needle biopsy, or an open biopsy may be required in a case with doubtful diagnosis.
  • Stages of TB Spine with Neural Deficit:

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Middle path regimen is used in India
    • Treatment is done with antitubercular therapy (ATT), spinal brace and rest.
    • Patient is followed on with complete neural examination and if progress is good then continued on nonoperative management but if indications of surgery exist then, surgery needs to be done.
       
  • Stage-wise Treatment:

 

 

  • ATT: 
    • Rifampicin is always a part of all regimens.
    • Minimum duration is 9–12 months in spinal TB and may be given up to 18–24 months depending upon clinical, radiological (MRI) and hematological (ESR) healing (in non-spinal TB the duration of ATT is 6 months–1 year).|
       
  • Indications of surgery in any disease of spine:
    1. Bowel bladder involvement
    2. Deterioration in neural or clinical status on treatment
    3. No improvement in neural or clinical status after conservative trial of 3-4 weeks
    4. Paravertebral abscess
    5. Spine instability due to kyphotic deformity (kyphotic angles 50-60° or more which is likely to progress)
    6. Pott’s spine resistant to current anti-tuberculosis drugs
    7. To prevent/treat complications like late-onset paraplegia
       
  • Surgical options for most of the cases are anterior decompression + bone grafting or anterolateral decompression + bone grafting and both have similar success rates.
  • Hong Kong operation is also carried out for Pott’s spine.
  • Structures removed in anterolateral decompression are part of rib, one side transverse process, one pedicle and small part of vertebral body (intercostal nerves are exposed).

 

 

Structures removed in anterolateral decompression

 

Note:

 

  • Posterior structures like lamina are never removed in tuberculosis because disease destroys anteriorly and if surgeon destroys posteriorly then there will be instability.
  • These surgeries are carried out in right lateral position (right side down and left side up) approaching the spine from left side as the vessel handled is aorta on left side which is thick muscular vessel with more resilience to handling pressure as compared to vena cava on right side which is friable to handle.
  • Prognostic Factors:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Presence of cold abscess without any neurological involvement is not an indication for biopsy or surgical treatment of Pott’s spine.
  • Neurological involvement which is deteriorating with time is an important indication for surgical intervention.

choices.text: BP > 160/90 mmHg with one anti-hypertensive
BP > 140/90 mmHg with one anti-hypertensive
BP > 140/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives
BP > 160/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives

questions.text: Resistant hypertension is defined as? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) BP > 140/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives.

 

Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure that remains above goal despite the concurrent use of three anti-hypertensive agents of different classes. Typically, one of the three medications should be a diuretic, and all agents should be prescribed at optimal dose amounts. The threshold set for defining resistant hypertension is blood pressure greater than 140/90 mmHg.

 

Resistant hypertension indicates a situation where blood pressure control is inadequate despite the use of multiple medications, which can pose significant risks for cardiovascular complications and requires careful evaluation for secondary causes. This includes assessing for white-coat HTN/Pseudo HTN, medication adherence, lifestyle factors, and secondary causes of hypertension like renal artery stenosis, endocrine disorders, or medication-induced hypertension.

 

Home BP monitoring, ABPM (Ambulatory BP monitoring) can help in optimization of drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Resistant HTN refers to BP > 140/90 mmHg despite three anti-HTN, one being a diuretic.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Cardiology/Hypertensive Disease/ chap 277

questions.text: The enzyme that is common for both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phosphoglycerate kinase

 

Phosphoglycerate kinase catalyzes the conversion of 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate to 3-phosphoglycerate, which is a reversible step involved in glycolysis and gluconeogenesis hence it is common for both pathways.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyruvate kinase: Pyruvate kinase is involved only in glycolysis and catalyzes the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) to pyruvate. It is not involved in gluconeogenesis.

 

Option B. Phosphofructokinase: Phosphofructokinase is a key regulatory enzyme in glycolysis, converting fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate. It does not play a role in gluconeogenesis.

 

Option C. Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase: Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase is involved in gluconeogenesis, converting oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate. It is not involved in glycolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phosphoglycerate kinase is a common enzyme in both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis, catalyzing a reversible reaction that interconverts 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate and 3-phosphoglycerate.

 

Other reversible steps of glycolysis are catalyzed by the following enzymes:

  • Phosphoglycerate mutase
  • Glyceraldehyde phosphate dehydrogenase
  • Triose phosphate isomerase
  • Aldolase
  • Phosphohexose isomerase

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prodrug? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Primidone

 

  • Prodrugs are drugs that are present in their inactive form and are converted to the active form in the body after undergoing metabolism.
  • Among the given options primidone is not a prodrug. Although it produces active metabolites like phenobarbitone and phenylethylmalonamide (PEMA) but it cannot be considered as a prodrug because primidone itself is also active.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proguanil: Proguanil is a prodrug and its active metabolite is cycloguanil. It is used in the treatment and prevention of malaria.

 

Option C. Sulindac: Sulindac is a sulfoxide prodrug used in inflammatory diseases including osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis.

 

Option D. Flurouracil: Flurouracil  is a prodrug having the active metabolite as fluorouridine monophosphate. It is an anticancer chemotherapeutic agent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primidone is not a prodrug because it is pharmacologically active in its original form, although it also produces active metabolites. Prodrugs like Proguanil, Sulindac, and 5-Fluorouracil require metabolic activation to exert their therapeutic effects.

 

Mnemonic

choices.text: It is a screening test for cervical cancer
It is a diagnostic test for trichomonas infection
It helps to diagnose cancer in her genital tract
It helps to diagnose other associated genital infections in her

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes with repeated infections of trichomonas vaginitis; her physician advises for a Pap smear. She asks you regarding the purpose of this test. What would be your appropriate response? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a screening test for cervical cancer

 

Explanation:

 

  • Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer.
  • A cervical smear is prepared using the pap test which is sent for cytological examination
  • The presence of malignant cells on Pap smear requires further evaluation with colposcopy, cervical biopsy, fractional curettage, etc.

 

Prerequisites:

 

  • It should be done prior to vaginal examination
  • Lubricants should not be used
  • The patient should not be menstruating during the pap test
  • The ideal time is around ovulation
  • The patient should not have intercourse 24hrs prior to the test

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is a diagnostic test for trichomonas vaginalis: Trichomonas vaginalis is diagnosed by seeing the flagellated organism (T. vaginalis) on a vaginal smear

 

Option C. It helps to diagnose cervical cancer in her genital tract: A pap smear is specifically for cervical cancer screening and also for recurrence from the vaginal vault following hysterectomy for CIN/ cervical cancer.

 

Option D. It helps to diagnose other associated genital infections in her: A pap smear can detect associated genital infections especially cervical infections but is not routinely used for this purpose

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer, used to identify abnormal cells in the cervix.

 

Ref: Page no 113, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition.

questions.text: During a telemedicine session with patients in a rural health clinic, Dr. Reddy emphasized preventive measures for COVID-19. He highlighted certain practices that are widely recommended. Which of the following, however, is NOT effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1% glutaraldehyde

 

  • A 1% glutaraldehyde solution does not prove effective in preventing the transmission of COVID-19.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Face Mask: Wearing face masks significantly helps reduce the transmission of COVID-19 by blocking respiratory droplets.

 

Option C. 70% Alcohol: Alcoholic solutions, particularly those containing at least 60-70% alcohol, are effective in killing viruses on surfaces and are recommended for hand sanitation to reduce viral transmission.

 

Option D. Hand Washing: Regular and thorough hand washing with soap and water for at least 20 seconds is one of the most effective ways to remove viruses and prevent the spread of COVID-19.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The key measures that effectively curb its spread include behaviors such as maintaining a physical distance of at least 6 feet from others, washing hands with soap and water for a duration of 20 seconds, or employing a hand sanitizer containing a minimum of 70% alcohol.
  • Additionally, wearing a face mask in situations necessitating public outings remains crucial.

choices.text: All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotic
Caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space

questions.text: A 55-year-old female came to the hospital with a history of trauma to the ear. On examination, there is swelling, tenderness, and discoloration of the ear. Which of the following is false regarding the given image? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Resolves spontaneously

 

A hematoma of the auricle is depicted in the image given.

 

The scenario described seems to suggest a case of auricular hematoma, which is a collection of blood in the perichondrial space of the ear, usually following trauma. Here is a breakdown of the options provided:

 

This statement is false regarding Perichondral hematoma . If an Perichondral hematoma is left untreated, it usually does not resolve spontaneously. Instead, it often requires intervention to prevent complications such as infection or the development of 'Cauliflower ear'. The standard treatment involves aspiration of the hematoma or surgical intervention to prevent permanent deformity and to reestablish the connection between the cartilage and the overlying perichondrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotic: While not all cases may strictly require prophylactic antibiotics, they are often administered in practice to prevent infection, especially because the ear cartilage is avascular and therefore more susceptible to infection. The effectiveness of prophylactic antibiotics is debated, but it is a common practice, particularly when there's been a break in the skin.

 

Option B. May lead to Pugilistic ear: This is true. A 'Pugilistic ear' is another term for 'Cauliflower ear', which can occur if an auricular hematoma is not adequately treated, leading to fibrosis and cartilage deformity.

 

Option C. Caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space: This is correct. An auricular hematoma occurs when blood accumulates in the space between the cartilage and the perichondrium, which can occur after a blunt trauma to the ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perichondral hematoma (cauliflower ear, wrestler's ear, or pugilistic ear):

 

  • It is a deformity of the ear brought on by repeated trauma.
  • Perichondral space refers to the area of blood between the auricular cartilage and its perichondrium.
  • Due to blunt trauma, it is frequently observed in boxers, wrestlers, and rugby players.
  • It does not resolve spontaneously.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Prophylactic antibiotics should be administered in all cases.
  • Under strict aseptic guidelines, aspiration of the hematoma and application of a pressure dressing to stop re-accumulation.
  • Aspiration might have to be done again. Aspiration that doesn't work should be followed by incision and drainage.

 

Ref - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470424/

questions.text: The fornix of the brain is composed of which types of nerve fibers? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Association and commisural fibers

 

All of the fornix's fibres are association fibres, with the exception of the hippocampal commissure, which possesses commissural fibres. As a result, option A—both association and commissural fibers—is the best response.

 

Association fibers connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere whereas commissural fibers connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

 

Fornix arises from the hippocampus and ends in the mamillary body of the hypothalamus. Its blood supply - anterior cerebral artery.

 

Note: The function of the commissure of the fornix is to connect the hippocampal formations of the two sides.

 

 

  • The commissural fibers or transverse fibers: are axons that connect the two hemispheres of the brain.
  • Association fibers: connect regions within the same hemisphere of the brain
  • Projection fibers: connect each region to other parts of the brain or to the spinal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Association and Projection fibers: Projection fibers: These fibers connect the cerebral cortex to the lower brain regions and spinal cord. They are mainly involved in conveying information between the cerebral cortex and other parts of the CNS. The fornix doesn't primarily contain projection fibers; its main constituents are association and commissural fibers.

 

Option C. Commissural and Projection fibers: As previously stated, while the fornix contains commissural fibers, it doesn't mainly contain projection fibers.

 

Option D. Association fibers: Association fibers, as mentioned, connect different parts of the same hemisphere. The fornix does contain association fibers, but it's not limited to just these; it also has commissural fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fornix contains both association fibers (linking parts of the hippocampus to other regions within the same hemisphere) and commissural fibers (connecting the hippocampi of the two hemispheres).

 

Association fibers: These fibers connect different parts of the same hemisphere. Their function is to enable communication between different cortical areas within the same cerebral hemisphere.

 

Commissural fibers: These are axons that connect one cerebral hemisphere to the other. Their primary function is to allow the two hemispheres to communicate with each other. The corpus callosum is the most significant group of commissural fibers, but the fornix also contains commissural fibers. Specifically, fibers from the fornix contribute to the hippocampal commissure, which connects the two hippocampi of the right and left hemispheres.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female underwent hip replacement. After 1 year, she developed fever and pain in the joint. Radiograph revealed loosening of prosthesis. The implant had to be removed. The histological image of the tissue adjoining the implant is shown below. What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metallosis

 

  • The microscopic image shows multiple foci of extracellular metal deposits (seen as black deposits) surrounded by inflammatory cells, suggestive of metallosis.

 

METALLOSIS

 

  • Metallosis is a rare, potentially fatal complication after arthroplasty characterized by the deposition and build-up of metal debris in the soft tissues of the body, associated with metal-on-metal prosthetic devices, but it has also been described in non-metallic prostheses.
  • It is defined as aseptic fibrosis, local necrosis, or loosening of a device secondary to metal corrosion and release of wear debris.
  • It occurs due to metallic erosion and release of metallic debris products, which induce massive local cytokines liberation from inflammatory cells.
  • It can present with local/systemic symptoms and signs due to a chronic inflammatory host response.
  • The local effects have been described as pseudotumours or osteolysis.
  • The systemic effects are caused by an immunological response to metal debris, including constitutional symptoms such as nausea, vomiting and malaise, cognitive impairment, haematological abnormalities and neuromuscular changes.
  • Risk factor for the development of metallosis include female gender, bilateral implants, high doses of corticosteroids, renal insufficiency and a suppressed immune system.
  • Its histology is characterized by widespread lymphoplasmacytic and histiocytic infiltration around metal debris, foreign body giant cells, metal particles, extracellular metal deposits and intracytoplasmic debris in giant cells.
  • Treatment consists of surgical revision with replacement of the prosthesis components, complete surgical debridement of osteolytic lesions and bone grafting with allograft chips.
  • Complete removal of all metal debris is difficult and may result in extensive tissue damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanoma. Melanoma, also known as malignant melanoma, is a type of cancer that develops from the pigment-producing cells known as melanocytes. Melanomas typically occur in the skin. In women, they most commonly occur on the legs, while in men, they most commonly occur on the back. About 25% of melanomas develop from moles. Changes in a mole that can indicate melanoma include an increase in size, irregular edges, change in color, itchiness, or skin breakdown. The primary cause of melanoma is ultraviolet light (UV) exposure in those with low levels of the skin pigment melanin. Those with many moles, a history of affected family members, and poor immune function are at greater risk. Diagnosis is by biopsy. Using sunscreen and avoiding UV light may prevent melanoma. Treatment is typically removal of the melanoma and potentially affected tissue (border around the melanoma) by surgery. In those with slightly larger cancers, nearby lymph nodes may be tested for metastasis. For those in whom melanoma has spread, immunotherapy, biologic therapy, radiation therapy, or chemotherapy may improve survival. 

 

Option C. Ochronosis. Ochronosis is named for the reddish-brown hue of tissue termed "ochre-like". It is inborn error of metabolism. Ochronosis is due to deposition of a phenolic compound – "alkaptons" polymerizing into connective tissue, leading to black urine disease called alkaptonuria. Inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion, alkaptonuria is an inactive gene, mapped on chromosome 3q21-23 coding for the enzyme homogentisate 1,2 dioxygenase (HGD). The result is systemic sequestration of homogentisate, that upon the decay to benzoquinone, can irreversibly bind with collagen. Polymerization of this molecule takes on an iridescent dark hue, tinting affected tissue and turning urine black. Aside from just discoloration, these processes can cause degradation, degeneration, and developmental problems in all types of collagen. The earliest sign is from parents who notice infants’ diapers are black in color. This disease can be insidious and manifest later in life. Patients may present with back pain or large joint arthralgias in their post-teenage years or early 30s. Pigmentation of the sclera and pinna of the ear is often seen later in life. Constant tendon ruptures especially with minimal trauma. On physical examination, thickened Achilles tendon and bursa effusions are common. For alkaptonuria, a chromatography assay in the urine for homogentisate can be diagnostic, especially, if the color change is noted after being exposed to the air. A genetic test can determine the existence of the autosomal recessive disease.

 

Option D. Rosai-Dorfman syndrome. Rosai-Dorfman disease is a disease that occurs when the body produces too many histiocytes in the lymph nodes. These histiocytes accumulate in the cervical nodes most commonly. Histiocytes may also build up in the skin, upper respiratory tract, and sinuses. Rosai-Dorfman disease is seldom life-threatening. In many instances, the patient’s symptoms resolve on their own. The majority of patients experience enlarged lymph nodes on both sides of the neck. While often painless, these nodes can swell and grow rather larger. Swelling may also be reported in the lymph nodes of the groin, armpits, and in the central portion of the chest. This swelling may be accompanied by fever. The diagnosis is made following a tissue biopsy from the affected site. Though it is most commonly diagnosed in the first 10 years of life, it is also found in adults, affecting men and women equally. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image in the question shows extracellular metal deposits (black deposits) surrounded by inflammatory cells, suggestive of metallosis.
  • It is associated with metal-on-metal prosthetic devices.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with long standing history of back pain for 20 years and chest tightness. Lateral radiograph of the cervical spine is shown. What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DISH

 

DIFFUSE IDIOPATHIC SKELETAL HYPEROSTOSIS

 

  • Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) is a spon­dyloarthropathy also known as Forestier’s disease or ankylosing hyperostosis.
  • It is a noninflammatory disease, with the principal manifestation being calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and the entheses.
  • Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis is characterized by florid hyperostosis of the spine.
  • Marginal bony proliferation leads to the formation of anterior osseous ridges that fuse and give the appearance of flowing wax on the anterior bodies of the vertebrae on radiography.
  • Ossification of paraspinous ligaments, such as the anterior and posterior longitudinal ligaments, may be seen.
  • The whole spine may be involved, and bony ankylosis occurs, although the disc spaces and facet joints remain unaffected.
  • The thoracic spine is most commonly involved, although the cervical and lumbar regions may also be affected.
  • Lesions are most prominent anteriorly and along the right lateral aspect of the spine.
  • Intervertebral disc spaces are preserved, unless there is co-existing lumbar spondylosis, and sacroiliac and facet joints appear normal. This helps differentiate diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis from spondylosis and the spondyloarthritis.
  • Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis is usually seen in the middle-aged and the elderly.
  • In advanced stages, the disease may look like melted candle wax. The calcification and ossification is most common in the right side of the spine.
  • The distinctive radiological feature of DISH is the continuous linear calcification along the anteromedial aspect of the thoracic spine.
  • The disease is not fatal, however some associated complications can lead to death. Complications include paralysis, dysphagia, and pulmonary infections.
  • DISH has no indication of a genetic link, and does not affect organs other than the lungs, which is only indirect due to the fusion of the rib cage.
  • DISH may be discovered as a radiological abnormality, as mentioned above, without any symptoms.
  • Morning stiffness is also noticed in almost two-thirds of patients.
  • Calcification and ossification may be seen at peripheral entheseal sites, including the shoulder, iliac crest, ischial tuberosity, trochanters of the hip, tibial tuberosities, patellae, and bones of the hands and/or feet.
  • Treatment: NSAIDs can be helpful in relieving pain and inflammation associated with DISH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ankylosing spondylitis. Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease. It is a seronegative chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints. HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients. Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis & synovitis. It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years. Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, associated with morning stiffness for few hours that improves with activity. Question mark (?) posture due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis. Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation. Anterior uveitis is the most common extra-articular manifestation. Spine radiograph shows loss of lumbar lordosis, haziness of SI joint margins (earliest change), calcification of supraspinous & interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign), Trolley/Tram-track sign i.e., three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification, Bamboo spine appearance due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

 

 

A. Trolley/Tram track sign; B. Bamboo Spine

 

 

Dagger Sign

 

Option C. Klippel feil syndrome. It is congenital fusion of one or more cervical vertebrae presenting with classical triad of limited neck motion, low hair line and short ‘web' neck (prominent trapezius muscle). Clinical features includes abnormal head position, true torticollis, restricted range of motion, without an obvious SCM contracture, congenital osseous fusions (synostosis) and failure of segmentation of the cervical spine.

 

 

Option D. Sprengel deformity. It consists of permanent elevation of the shoulder girdle due to developmental defect. The scapula is smaller in its vertical diameter and appears broad. It lies high in position. Para scapular muscles are composed of imperfectly developed muscle fibers or fibrous tissue. From the superior angle of scapula, a sheet or band like structure composed of fibrous tissue cartilage or bone extends upwards to attach to the transverse process of several cervical vertebrae, known as Omovertebral bar.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image shows DISH i.e., diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis, which is the non-inflammatory disease, with calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and the enthuses, mainly at the thoracic spine.

questions.text: An individual who is experiencing vertigo but does not have hearing impairment has consulted an ENT surgeon. The surgeon proceeds with a diagnostic technique followed by a carefully executed therapeutic procedure. What is the diagnostic maneuver?(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dix-Hallpike maneuver

 

Vertigo without hearing loss diagnosed by a positional maneuver is benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The diagnostic maneuver used in BPPV is the Dix-Hallpike maneuver and therapeutic maneuver is the Epley's maneuver.

 

Dix-Hallpike maneuver:

 

  • Gold standard for diagnosing BPPV. 
  •  Nystagmus has a short latency period of 2-20 seconds, lasts for less than a minute, and has a fixed direction towards the lower placed ear, and is fatigable.
  • Associated with vertigo.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hampton's maneuver: This is not a widely recognized or standard maneuver in the diagnosis or treatment of vertigo. It does not relate to any commonly accepted procedure in the management of vertigo in otolaryngology.

 

Option C. Epley's maneuver: The therapeutic maneuver is the Epley maneuver which repositions the otolith to the utricle/saccule from the posterior semicircular canal.

 

 

Option D. Simon's maneuver: Like Hampton's maneuver, Simon's maneuver is not a standard or widely recognized technique in the diagnosis or management of vertigo associated with BPPV or other inner ear conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is specifically used for diagnosing BPPV by eliciting nystagmus induced by position changes.
  • The Epley's maneuver is used to treat the vertigo symptoms once BPPV is confirmed by the Dix-Hallpike test.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 47

questions.text: A nursing assistant posted in the obstetric care unit was asked to plot a partograph to monitor the progress of labour. After how much dilatation of the cervix, should she start plotting the graph? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4cm

 

  • In the WHO modified partograph, labor ((Cervical dilatation vs time)  is plotted on a graph and analysis includes use of action lines and alert lines.
  • In the WHO modified partograph, the plotting starts in active phase (4cm)
  • The alert line is plotted at a cervical dilatation rate of 1cm/h
  • The action line is plotted 4h to the right of the alert line
  •  The 1st marking is always on the alert line
  • The WHO modified partograph has now been replaced by the WHO labor care guide where the new definition of active labor is 5 cm so when answering a question read carefully what is asked – WHO modified partograph or WHO Labor care guide

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plotting on the partograph should start at 4 cm cervical dilatation during the active phase of labor.

 

Ref: Page no 152, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 7th edition

choices.text: Cell mediated and antibody mediated response

questions.text: Type IV hypersensitivity is due to: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cell mediated response

 

A Type IV hypersensitivity reaction is mediated by T cells that provoke an inflammatory reaction against exogenous or endogenous antigens. In certain situations, other cells, such as monocytes, eosinophils, and neutrophils, can be involved. After antigen exposure, an initial local immune and inflammatory response occurs that attracts leukocytes. The antigen engulfed by the macrophages and monocytes is presented to T cells, which then becomes sensitized and activated. These cells then release cytokines and chemokines, which can cause tissue damage and may result in illnesses. It is considered a delayed hypersensitivity reaction because it usually occurs more than 12 hours after exposure to the allergen, with a maximal reaction time between 48 and 72 hours.

 

Examples of illnesses resulting from type IV hypersensitivity reactions include contact dermatitis and drug hypersensitivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cell mediated and antibody mediated response: This is not correct for Type IV hypersensitivity, which is exclusively cell-mediated and does not involve antibodies.

 

Option C. Antibody mediated response: This describes Type I, II, and III hypersensitivities, which involve IgE, IgG, or IgM antibodies, respectively. Type IV is exclusively cell-mediated.

 

Option D. Innate response: While the innate immune response involves cells like macrophages and neutrophils, Type IV hypersensitivity specifically involves the adaptive immune system, particularly T cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type IV hypersensitivity is a cell-mediated response primarily involving T cells and other immune cells, leading to delayed-type reactions such as contact dermatitis and drug hypersensitivity.

 

The four types of hypersensitivity are:

 

  1. Type I: reaction mediated by IgE antibodies
  2. Type II: cytotoxic reaction mediated by IgG or IgM antibodies
  3. Type III: reaction mediated by immune complexes
  4. Type IV: delayed reaction mediated by cellular response

questions.text: False about the Ebola virus is: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transmitted by mosquito

 

Ebola viruses belong to a family of viruses termed Filoviridae. Filovirus particles form long, sometimes branched, filaments of varying shapes, as well as shorter filaments. Viral particles contain one molecule of single-stranded negative-sense RNA, enveloped in a lipid (fatty) membrane.

 

Mode of transmission - direct contact with blood or other bodily fluids, such as semen, feces, or vomit, of infected persons (or animals), including close contact with deceased EVD victims, which are highly infectious.

 

Reservoir hosts – Fruit bats are the most likely natural reservoir

 

Accidental Hosts – Man

 

Incubation period - 2 to 21 days.

 

Symptoms include fever, intense weakness, vomiting, diarrhea, rashes, and, in extreme cases, internal and external bleeding. The current treatment is mainly supportive. Nosocomial transmission seen.

 

Symptoms – severe headache muscle and joint pain, weakness and fatigue, sore throat, loss of appetite, gastrointestinal symptoms including abdominal pain, diarrhea, and vomiting, Unexplained hemorrhaging, bleeding or bruising.

 

Treatment – symptomatic and supportive

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a filovirus: This is true. Ebola virus belongs to the family Filoviridae and forms filamentous viral particles containing single-stranded negative-sense RNA.
