Option C. Bats act as reservoir: This is true. Fruit bats are considered the most likely natural reservoir hosts for the Ebola virus.

 

Option D. Nosocomial transmission seen: This is true. Nosocomial transmission, which occurs in healthcare settings, is a recognized mode of transmission for Ebola virus, often due to inadequate infection control practices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ebola virus is a filovirus transmitted through direct contact with the bodily fluids of infected individuals or animals, not by mosquitoes. Fruit bats are the most likely natural reservoir, and nosocomial transmission is a known route of spread.

choices.text: Most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries
Can be diagnosed with CECT
Improves with food rich in carbohydrates
Increased risk of GI lymphoma

questions.text: Which of the following is true about celiac disease? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased risk of GI lymphoma

 

Individuals with celiac disease have an increased risk of Gl lymphoma.

 

Celiac disease is also known as celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy. It is an immune mediated enteropathy triggered by the ingestion of gluten-containing cereals, such as barley, rye, oats & wheat (BROW) in genetically predisposed individuals. In countries where most people are Caucasians of European ancestry, celiac disease is a common disorder, with an estimated prevalence of 0.5% to 1%.

 

The histopathology is characterized by increased numbers of intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis), crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy. This loss of mucosal and brush-border surface area accounts for the malabsorption.

 

 

Noninvasive serologic tests are generally performed prior to biopsy. The most sensitive tests are the presence of IgA antibodies to tissue transglutaminase or IgA or IgG antibodies to deamidated gliadin. Anti-endomysial antibodies are highly specific but less sensitive than other antibodies.

 

Individuals with celiac disease have a higher-than-normal rate of malignancy. The most common celiac disease–associated cancer is enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma, an aggressive lymphoma of intraepithelial T lymphocytes. Small intestinal adenocarcinoma is also more frequent in individuals with celiac disease.

 

The treatment is lifelong gluten free diet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries: This is incorrect. While celiac disease can cause malnutrition due to malabsorption, it is not the most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries. Infectious diseases, poor diet, and other factors are more common causes.

 

Option B. Can be diagnosed with CECT: This is incorrect. Celiac disease is not typically diagnosed with contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT). The diagnosis is usually based on serologic tests for specific antibodies and confirmed by duodenal biopsy showing characteristic histopathological changes such as villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and intraepithelial lymphocytosis.

 

Option C. Improves with food rich in carbohydrates: This is incorrect. Celiac disease improves with a gluten-free diet, not with an increase in carbohydrates. The treatment requires strict lifelong avoidance of gluten.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease is associated with an increased risk of gastrointestinal lymphoma, specifically enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma, making it a critical long-term concern for individuals with this condition.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1518-1519

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided head tilt which on straightening leads to right hypotropia increases on dextroversion and right head tilt. Paralysis of which of the following muscles is involved? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right superior rectus

 

  • The clinical scenario described is due to right superior rectus palsy.
  • The three-step test, also called the Parks-Bielschowsky three-step test, can help diagnose which muscle is paralyzed in acquired hypertropia. It involves using the cover-uncover test and Maddox rod to measure deviation in different head positions.
  • The three-step test can also diagnose inferior oblique or vertical rectus muscle palsy, but it's not reliable for multiple paretic muscles or restrictive strabismus.
  • In patients with inhibitional palsy of the contralateral antagonist, the three-step test can distinguish between true or simulated superior rectus palsy.

 

Using the three-step test in the above clinical scenario:

 

Step 1. Which eye is hypotropic?

 

The eye hypotropic in the primary position is the right eye. The paretic muscles can be right eye elevator or left eye depressor.

 

  • Right superior rectus
  • Right inferior oblique
  • Left inferior rectus
  • Left superior oblique

 

Step 2. Does the hypotropia increase in the right gaze or left gaze?

 

The hypotropia increases in right gaze.

 

Therefore, the paretic muscle must be either (1) one of the muscles whose primary action is elevating the right eye on the right gaze, or (2) one of the muscles whose primary action is depressing the left eye in the right gaze. The left inferior oblique and the right superior rectus both have a primary action of elevation in right gaze. Therefore, one of these muscles could be the paretic muscle. Likewise, the left superior oblique and the right inferior rectus have a primary action of depression in the right gaze and could be paretic. But since the left inferior oblique and the right inferior rectus did not meet step 1, they can be eliminated from the possible paretic muscles. This leaves us:

 

  • Left superior oblique
  • Right superior rectus

 

Step 3. Does the hypotropia increase in the right head tilt or left head tilt?

 

The hypotropia increases in the right head tilt. If the deviation increases on right head tilt and decreases on left head tilt, as it does in this example patient, then the right superior rectus is implicated as the paretic culprit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right superior oblique: Incorrect, as paralysis typically leads to hypertropia and excyclotorsion, not hypotropia.

 

Option C. Right inferior oblique: Incorrect, as paralysis would not result in the described pattern of hypotropia.

 

Option D. Left inferior oblique: Incorrect, since paralysis here does not explain the increase in hypotropia with right head tilt and right gaze.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The three-step test is a vital diagnostic tool in strabismus evaluations to identify which extraocular muscle is paretic based on the changes in eye position with head tilt and gaze direction. In this scenario, the findings align with a right superior rectus muscle palsy, consistent with its role in elevating the right eye especially during right gaze and head tilt to the right.

questions.text: In a patient with non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). All the following can be used for treatment except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Streptokinase

 

In the management of NSTEMI, the focus is on antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy rather than fibrinolytic agents like streptokinase. Streptokinase is specifically used in the treatment of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) where there is a fibrin-rich thrombus completely occluding a coronary artery. NSTEMI, in contrast, involves a partial occlusion by a platelet-rich thrombus, and fibrinolytics are generally not recommended because they are less effective and could potentially increase the risk of bleeding without significant benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: As a foundational antiplatelet agent, aspirin is used in both STEMI and NSTEMI to reduce platelet aggregation and further thrombus formation.

 

Option C. Clopidogrel: This is another antiplatelet drug that is used in the management of both STEMI and NSTEMI as part of dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) along with aspirin to provide greater protection against thrombotic events.

 

Option D. Prasugrel: Similar to clopidogrel, prasugrel is used in acute coronary syndrome (ACS) management, including NSTEMI, especially when percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is planned, due to its potent antiplatelet effects. (Prasugrel is given peri-procedurally).

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21e chap 118/3518

questions.text:
Arrange the sequence of evets occurring after p wave in ECG? (INICET May 2020)

 

  1. a wave in JVP
  2. First heart sound
  3. Rapid filling of ventricles
  4. T wave in ECG
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-2-4-3

 

The correct sequence of events that occur after the p-wave is 1-2-4-3, i.e.: - a wave in JVP (right atrial filling) -› First heart sound (closure of AV valve) -› T wave in ECG (ventricular systole) -> Rapid filling of ventricles.

 

The sequence of the events in this question can be better understood with the following diagram:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequence of events following the P wave in an ECG is: a wave in JVP, first heart sound, T wave (Electrical activity first i.e. repolarization) followed by rapid filling of ventricles (Mechanical activity i.e. relaxation).

questions.text: Dicoumarol inhibits the action of vitamin K by? (AIIMS 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Competitive inhibition

 

Vitamin K Dependent Carboxylase is microsomal enzyme. It requires oxygen, CO2, NADPH and reduced vitamin K. In this process, the vitamin passes through a cycle. This process is competitively inhibited by warfarin and dicoumarol.

 

 

Vitamin K cycle

 

Dicoumarol - Structural analog inhibits vitamin K reductase

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suicide inhibition:

  • Definition: The inhibitor binds irreversibly to the enzyme, inactivating it permanently.
  • Relevance: Dicoumarol does not irreversibly inactivate vitamin K reductase.

 

Option C. Noncompetitive inhibition:

  • Definition: The inhibitor binds to a different site on the enzyme, not the active site, altering the enzyme's activity.
  • Relevance: Dicoumarol competes at the active site, not at a different site.

 

Option D. Uncompetitive inhibition:

  • Definition: The inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, preventing the reaction from proceeding.
  • Relevance: Dicoumarol binds to the enzyme regardless of the presence of the substrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dicoumarol inhibits the action of vitamin K by competitively inhibiting vitamin K reductase, preventing the regeneration of active vitamin K necessary for blood clotting.

questions.text:
Which of the following increases in COPD? (INICET May 2020)

 

  1. FRC
  2. TLC
  3. VC
  4. FEV1/FVC
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 2

 

In Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), there is an increase in both functional residual capacity (FRC) and total lung capacity (TLC). These changes occur due to air trapping and hyperinflation of the lungs, which are characteristic of COPD.

 

  • FRC (Functional Residual Capacity): The volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration. This increases in COPD due to air trapping.
  • TLC (Total Lung Capacity): The maximum volume of air the lungs can hold. It may be increased or remain normal in COPD due to hyperinflation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In COPD, both functional residual capacity (FRC) and total lung capacity (TLC) increase due to air trapping and lung hyperinflation.

questions.text: Following is a graphic representation of a patient admitted in medicine ward with fever. What could be the possible diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

Image shows typical biphasic illness with initial leptospiremic phase followed by immune phase.

 

Other illness that shows biphasic pattern include measles, Tick borne encephalitis virus, rarely Zika virus.

 

Modified Faine Criteria is used for diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monophasic illness with predominant CNS and multisystem involvement.

 

Option C. Undulant fever presenting with PUO, muscle pain, thoracic backpain

 

Option D. Enteric fever causes step ladder pattern of fever.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Leptospirosis should be considered in patients presenting with a biphasic fever pattern, especially when supported by epidemiologic data pointing to possible exposure to contaminated water or animals. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent complications such as Weil's disease, which can lead to severe renal and hepatic issues.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Leptospirosis/Chap 184

choices.text: To induce anesthesia and relax muscles
To prevent memory loss after the ECT

questions.text: A patient undergoing ECT for his severe depression was given thiopentone and succinylcholine. The purpose of these medications was to? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To induce anesthesia and relax muscles

 

During electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), thiopentone is used to induce anesthesia, ensuring that the patient is unconscious and doesn't experience pain during the procedure. Succinylcholine is a muscle relaxant, used to prevent forceful and uncontrolled muscle contractions that can occur during the ECT, thus reducing the risk of injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To bring calming effect: Neither thiopentone nor succinylcholine is specifically used for their calming effects in the context of ECT.

 

Option B. To produce mood elevation: The medications aren't administered to produce mood elevation. The therapeutic effect of ECT itself is what aids in mood elevation.

 

Option D. To prevent memory loss after the ECT: Memory loss can be a side effect of ECT, but the drugs mentioned are not given to prevent this effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiopentone and succinylcholine are administered prior to ECT to induce anesthesia and relax muscles, respectively, to ensure patient safety and comfort during the procedure.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 1069.

questions.text: JAK2 mutation is most commonly associated with? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Polycythemia vera

 

Polycythemia vera is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2.

 

The exact etiology of PV is not known but about a third of cases show inconsistent and varied chromosomal abnormalities such as 20q, trisomy 8 and 9p. Major pathogenetic mechanism is a tyrosine kinase JAK2 mutation which removes the autoinhibitory control and activates the kinases.

 

The JAK2 V617F mutation is an acquired, somatic mutation present in the majority of patients with myeloproliferative cancer (myeloproliferative neoplasms) i.e. nearly 100% of patients with polycythemia vera and in about 50% of patients with essential thrombocytosis and primary myelofibrosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Essential thrombocytosis: The JAK2 V617F mutation is also found in approximately 50% of patients with essential thrombocytosis, but it is most strongly associated with polycythemia vera.

 

Option C. CML (Chronic Myeloid Leukemia): CML is associated with the Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22) translocation), not the JAK2 mutation.

 

Option D. PMF (Primary Myelofibrosis): The JAK2 mutation is present in about 50% of patients with PMF, but again, it is most strongly associated with polycythemia vera.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The JAK2 V617F mutation is most commonly associated with polycythemia vera, where it drives the excessive production of red blood cells through constitutive activation of the JAK-STAT pathway.

 

Ref: Robbins and cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1161

questions.text: A 20-year-old female with easy fatiguability and pallor presented to the OPD. The image of her hand is as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

Knuckle pigmentation is an easily visible and early sign of vitamin B12 deficiency due to increase in tyrosinase activity. It may occur even before the development of hematological and neurological complications.

 

In megaloblastic anemia, there is impairment of DNA synthesis that leads to ineffective hematopoiesis. It also causes distinctive morphologic changes, including abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aplastic anemia: This condition involves pancytopenia and hypocellular bone marrow but does not typically present with knuckle pigmentation.

 

Option C. Iron deficiency anemia: Iron deficiency anemia usually presents with pallor and fatigue but is not associated with knuckle pigmentation.

 

Option D. Hypoalbuminemia: Hypoalbuminemia may cause edema and other systemic symptoms but is not associated with knuckle pigmentation or anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Knuckle pigmentation is an early and visible sign of vitamin B12 deficiency, which can precede the more severe hematological and neurological complications associated with megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: The serum electrolyte values of a patient weighing 60 kg are given below. Calculate the sodium deficit in the patient. pH: 7.42, Na+: 120 mEq/L, serum K+: 4 mEq/L, serum CI-: 90 mEq/L? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 720 mEq

 

Sodium Deficit = Body weight x (0.6) x (desired sodium- actual sodium) [Note: 0.5 if female]= 60*0.6*(140-120) = 720 mEq.

 

Note: Correction should not exceed 6-8 mEq/day in chronic hyponatremia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium deficit -

 

Rate of Correction: It's critical to correct chronic hyponatremia slowly to avoid complications like osmotic demyelination syndrome. The recommended rate of correction should not exceed 6-8 mEq/L per day.


Monitoring: Frequent monitoring of serum sodium levels is necessary during the correction phase to adjust the treatment as needed and prevent overcorrection.

 

Ref: Harrison 21/Fluid and electrolyte/Chap 53

choices.text: Extend knee and plantar flex foot
Flex knee and plantar flex foot

questions.text: A pregnant woman has cramps in her legs. What will you suggest to her to relieve the pain? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extend knee and dorsiflex foot

 

Explanation:

 

To relieve leg cramps, the recommended technique is to:

 

  • Extend the knee: Straightening the leg helps in relieving tension and alleviating the cramp.
  • Dorsiflex the foot: This involves pulling the toes towards the shin, which stretches the calf muscles and helps in reducing the cramp.

 

Leg cramps during pregnancy are commonly caused by factors such as deficiencies in serum calcium, elevated serum phosphorus, or increased pressure on the leg veins. Stretching and adjusting the foot position can provide immediate relief from cramps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flex knee and dorsiflex foot: Flexing the knee while dorsiflexing the foot can help in some cases, but extending the knee is generally more effective in relieving cramp pain.

 

Option C. Extend knee and plantar flex foot: Plantar flexion (pointing the toes downward) can actually exacerbate calf cramps. Extending the knee while performing plantar flexion is not as effective for cramp relief.

 

Option D. Flex knee and plantar flex foot: Flexing the knee while performing plantar flexion will likely increase the cramp discomfort. This position may not provide effective relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To relieve leg cramps during pregnancy, extend the knee and dorsiflex the foot.

 

Ref: https://americanpregnancy.org/healthy-pregnancy/pregnancy-health-wellness/leg-cramps-during-pregnancy

choices.text: Bradycardia with AV block
Torsades’ de pointes

questions.text: A patient was taking metoprolol for hypertension but blood pressure was not controlled. Verapamil was added to the regimen. Which of the following adverse effect is likely to be present with combination? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bradycardia with AV block
 

  • Metoprolol is a beta-blocker that is commonly used to hypertension, heart failure, and arrhythmias. It works by slowing down the heart rate and reducing the heart's demand for oxygen.
  • Verapamil, on the other hand, is a calcium channel blocker used for similar indications as metoprolol. It reduces the heart rate and has a negative inotropic effect (reduces the force of heart muscle contraction), and can affect the electrical conduction in the heart.
  • When used together, metoprolol and verapamil can have additive effects on the heart rate and atrioventricular (AV) nodal conduction. This can lead to:
    • Bradycardia: An abnormally slow heart rate.
    • AV block: A delay or complete block in the electrical impulse conduction through the AV node of the heart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Torsades de pointes: This is a specific type of ventricular tachycardia that is not typically associated with the combination of metoprolol and verapamil. It is more often related to medications that prolong the QT interval.

 

Option C. Tachycardia: This is an increased heart rate, which is an unlikely side effect of combining metoprolol and verapamil, as both tend to slow the heart rate.

 

Option D. Ventricular fibrillation: While this is a serious cardiac arrhythmia, it is not a typical side effect of combining metoprolol and verapamil. It's more commonly associated with ischemic heart disease or other structural heart problems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of metoprolol and verapamil can lead to significant bradycardia and AV block due to their additive effects on slowing heart rate and AV nodal conduction.

questions.text: A child transfers an object from one hand to another. What does it signify? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ability to compare objects

 

When a child transfers an object from one hand to another, it signifies their ability to compare objects. This milestone typically occurs around 5.5 to 6 months of age. At this stage, the child is beginning to understand the differences between objects, which is why they are capable of transferring an object between hands. This action demonstrates the child's growing cognitive ability to recognize and compare different objects, an important part of early development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Visual motor coordination: Visual motor coordination refers to the ability to use the eyes and hands together to perform tasks, such as reaching for and grasping objects. While this is important for transferring objects, the key developmental significance of transferring an object from one hand to another lies in the child's ability to compare objects.

 

Option C. Ability to handle small objects: The ability to handle small objects, such as developing a pincer grasp, occurs later, typically around 8 to 9 months of age. This milestone involves more fine motor control and precision, which is different from the broader action of transferring objects between hands.

 

Option D. Voluntary release: Voluntary release refers to the ability to let go of an object intentionally, which is generally seen after the palmar grasp reflex disappears around 4 to 6 months. However, the act of transferring an object from one hand to another is more about the child’s ability to compare objects rather than just releasing them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transferring an object from one hand to another in a child signifies their developing ability to compare objects, a cognitive milestone typically reached around 5.5 to 6 months of age.

 

Developmental Milestones in 1st Yr of Life

questions.text: Surgical correction of VSD is performed in an infant. This will help in relieving which of the following features? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Failure to thrive.

 

Surgical correction of a Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) primarily helps in relieving the symptoms of congestive heart failure, which often manifest as failure to thrive in infants. Infants with VSD may experience poor weight gain, difficulty feeding, excessive sweating, irritability, and signs of respiratory distress such as tachypnea and labored breathing. These symptoms arise because the left-to-right shunt created by the VSD increases pulmonary blood flow, leading to pulmonary overcirculation and congestive heart failure. Surgical intervention closes the defect, thereby normalizing blood flow and alleviating the symptoms of heart failure, allowing the infant to grow and thrive normally.

 

The key indications for VSD surgery include:

 

  • Large defects associated with pulmonary hypertension.
  • Qp ratio greater than 2:1 (indicating a significant left-to-right shunt).
  • Supracristal VSD, which carries a risk of aortic valve involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory alkalosis: Respiratory alkalosis is not typically associated with VSD. VSD primarily affects the heart and pulmonary circulation rather than directly causing changes in the acid-base balance.

 

Option C. Arrhythmia: Arrhythmias in infants are usually related to electrolyte imbalances or other cardiac conditions, but not directly to VSD. Surgical correction of VSD is aimed at correcting the structural defect, not managing arrhythmias.

 

Option D. Heart block: Heart block is a conduction issue in the heart and is not a feature directly caused by VSD. VSD surgery does not specifically address heart block.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgical correction of VSD in infants primarily helps relieve congestive heart failure symptoms, particularly failure to thrive, by normalizing pulmonary blood flow.

questions.text: DNA methylation is not related to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Capping

 

DNA methylation is usually associated with triggering histone deacetylation, chromatin condensation, and gene silencing. Differentially methylated cytosines give rise to distinct patterns specific for each tissue type and disease state. Such methylation-variable positions (MVPs) are not uniformly distributed throughout our genome, but are concentrated among genes that regulate transcription, growth, metabolism, differentiation, and oncogenesis.

 

Alterations in MVP methylation status create epigenetic patterns that appear to regulate gene expression profiles during cell differentiation, growth, and development, as well as in cancer.

 

Environmental stressors including toxins, as well as microbial and viral exposures, can change epigenetic patterns and thereby effect changes in gene activation and cell phenotype.

 

Note - Capping is done for mRNA (7-methyl guanosine cap) not DNA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mismatch repair: DNA methylation is involved in distinguishing parental DNA strands during the mismatch repair process.

 

Option B. Chromatin Remodeling: DNA methylation plays a significant role in the remodeling of chromatin structure.

 

Option D. Gene silencing: DNA methylation is a key mechanism involved in the silencing of genes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA methylation is not related to RNA capping, which is an mRNA modification process. Instead, it is involved in processes such as mismatch repair, chromatin remodeling, and gene silencing.

questions.text: Identify the grip shown in the image below: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral grip

 

Obstetric grips (Leopold manoeuvres)

 

  1. Fundal grip (1st Leopold)
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Lateral/umbilical grip (2nd Leopold)
  3. ﻿﻿﻿1st pelvic grip /Pawlik grip (3rd Leopold)
  4. 2nd pelvic grip (4th Leopold)

 

 

The Lateral grip, also known as the Umbilical grip or Second Leopold's maneuver, is used to assess the position of the fetus in the uterus by palpating the sides of the maternal abdomen. This grip helps determine the location of the fetal back and limbs.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Pawlik's grip: Also known as the First pelvic grip or Third Leopold's maneuver, Pawlik's grip involves palpating the lower uterine segment to determine the fetal presenting part (e.g., whether it is a head or breech presentation).

 

Option C. Pelvic grip: This term is sometimes used to refer to the Second pelvic grip or Fourth Leopold's maneuver, which is used to assess the fetal engagement and the degree of descent in the pelvic cavity.

 

Option D. Fundal grip: This is the First Leopold's maneuver, which involves palpating the upper part of the uterus (fundus) to identify the fetal presentation (e.g., head or breech) and the lie of the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lateral grip (Second Leopold's maneuver) is used to assess the position of the fetal back and limbs by palpating the sides of the maternal abdomen.

 

Ref: Page 89, DC Ditta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition.

questions.text: Which of the following is the enzyme conjugate in the given ELISA technique? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

The enzyme conjugate in the given ELISA technique is '2'.

 

 

The sandwich ELISA is a type of Enzyme-linked immunosorbent Assay that uses two antibodies: a capture antibody and a detection antibody. It is called a sandwich because your antigen is bound between antibodies. The purpose of any ELISA is to detect the presence of a target antigen in a sample. In a sandwich ELISA the target antigen is bound between a capture antibody and a detection antibody. The capture antibody is immobilized on a surface, while the detection antibody (conjugated to an enzyme or fluorophore label) is applied as a last step before quantitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: Represents the substrate that produces a detectable signal when reacted with the enzyme.

 

Option C. 3: Represents the primary detection antibody that binds to the antigen.

 

Option D. 4: Represents the capture antibody that is immobilized on the surface and captures the antigen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the sandwich ELISA technique, the enzyme conjugate is part of the detection antibody, which binds to the antigen and, upon addition of a substrate, produces a detectable signal. In this diagram, '2' is identified as the enzyme conjugate.

questions.text: Rosuvastatin should not be combined with which of the following drugs? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Clarithromycin

 

  • Statins are metabolized by CYP3A4 enzyme, which is inhibited by clarithromycin. The plasma levels of statins may rise to high levels if used with clarithromycin, resulting in serious adverse effects like myopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxycodone: Oxycodone is an opioid analgesic used for pain management. It does not interact significantly with rosuvastatin and does not affect its metabolism.

 

Option C. Adalimumab: Adalimumab is a monoclonal antibody used to treat autoimmune conditions. It does not interfere with the metabolism of rosuvastatin and therefore is not associated with increased risk of myopathy when used in combination.

 

Option D. Rivoraxaban: Rivaroxaban is an anticoagulant used to prevent and treat blood clots. It does not interact with the metabolism of rosuvastatin and does not pose a risk of increased myopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs increasing the risk of statin induced myopathy are:

 

  • Amiodarone
  • Gemfibrozil
  • HIV protease inhibitors like saquinavir, ritonavir etc.
  • Clarithromycin
  • Itraconazole

choices.text: Should not be used due to risk of addiction
Can be used as both have different mechanism of action
Should not be used as it is irrational
Can be used to treat cough effectively

questions.text: If Codeine is coming to the market in combination with dextromethorphan as an anti-tussive, this combination? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Should not be used as it is irrational

 

  • Codeine is an opioid agonist and Dextromethorphan is a centrally acting NMDA receptor antagonist. Both codeine and dextromethorphan are antitussives, but they work through similar central mechanisms to suppress cough. Combining them does not offer additional therapeutic benefits but can increase the risk of side effects
  • A rational fixed dose drug combination would be to combine one centrally acting anti-tussive (either codeine or dextromethorphan) with expectorants (like potassium iodide, Guaifenesin), antihistaminic and mucolytics like (Ambroxol, Bromhexine, Acetyl cysteine)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Should not be used due to risk of addiction: While codeine has a potential for addiction, the main concern with this combination is not solely the risk of addiction but the lack of rationality in combining two centrally acting antitussives.

 

Option B. Can be used as both have different mechanisms of action: This is incorrect. Codeine and dextromethorphan both act centrally to suppress cough, and their mechanisms are similar enough that combining them does not provide a significant therapeutic advantage.

 

Option D. Can be used to treat cough effectively: Although both drugs are effective cough suppressants individually, their combination is not advisable due to the redundancy in action and increased risk of side effects without additional therapeutic benefit.

 

Therefore, the most accurate answer is C. The combination should not be used as it is irrational due to the overlapping mechanisms of action and increased risk of adverse effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Combining codeine with dextromethorphan as an anti-tussive is irrational due to their overlapping mechanisms of action and the increased risk of side effects without additional therapeutic benefit. Rational combinations for cough treatment involve combining one centrally acting antitussive with expectorants, antihistamines, and mucolytics.

questions.text: A patient with a known case of chronic plaque psoriasis with more than 50% skin involvement presents to you. Which of the following will you not recommend? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oral steroids

 

Oral/systemic steroids are not used in the management of chronic plaque psoriasis. Topical steroids may be used.

 

The only clear-cut indication for systemic steroids is pregnancy, as they are contraindicated in all other forms of psoriasis due to the risk of sudden withdrawal causing severe pustular or erythrodermic psoriasis.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Oral methotrexate: Methotrexate is an antimetabolite and immune modulator commonly used as a systemic treatment for moderate to severe plaque psoriasis. It is effective in reducing the proliferation of skin cells and has anti-inflammatory properties.

 

Option B. NB UVB (Narrowband Ultraviolet B): NB UVB phototherapy is a well-established treatment for moderate to severe plaque psoriasis. It works by reducing skin cell proliferation and modulating the immune system.

 

Option D. Oral cyclosporine: Cyclosporine is a calcineurin inhibitor that suppresses the immune system and is used for severe psoriasis. It is effective for quick control of the disease due to its potent immunosuppressive effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral steroids are not recommended for the long-term treatment of chronic plaque psoriasis due to the risk of disease exacerbation upon steroid withdrawal and the potential for serious side effects with long-term use.

 

Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis:

 

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 35.22, 35.35, 35.37

questions.text: Rees and Ecker diluting fluid is used in? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) RBC Pipette

 

Rees and Ecker's solution is used as a diluting fluid in the RBC pipette for performing platelet counts. This diluting fluid is formulated to preserve the platelets while preventing their clumping, allowing for accurate counting under a microscope.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wintrobe tube: This is a tube used for measuring the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and not related to the use of Rees and Ecker's solution.

 

Option B. WBC Pipette: A WBC pipette is used for counting white blood cells, typically with a different diluting fluid that is specific for leukocytes i. e Turk's fluid.

 

Option D. Hemoglobin pipette: This pipette is used for hemoglobinometry, which involves measuring the concentration of hemoglobin in the blood, and does not involve Rees and Ecker's solution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rees and Ecker's solution is used with the RBC pipette to accurately count platelets by preventing clumping and preserving the cells for microscopic examination.

 

Mnemonic:

 

Rees - RBCs (R-R)

questions.text: Identify the type of skin lesion? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Annular

 

The given image shows annular lesions, which are ring shaped with central clearing i.e., only the edges are active & appear raised, or in different colour. It is present in granuloma annulare and tinea corporis.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Nummular: Nummular lesions are coin-shaped and may be mistaken for annular lesions. However, nummular lesions are usually more solid in appearance without the central clearing seen in annular lesions.

 

Option C. Discoid: Discoid lesions are disc-like and typically solid without a central clearing. They can be seen in conditions like discoid lupus erythematosus. The lesion in the image is not entirely solid as it has central clearing, which is not characteristic of discoid lesions.

 

Option D. Target: Target lesions have a bulls-eye appearance with multiple rings and a dusky center as shown in the image below.

 

 

They are typically associated with conditions such as erythema multiforme. The lesion in the image does not have the concentric rings of color that define a target lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Annular lesions is identified by their characteristic ring-like appearance with central clearing, differentiating them from nummular, discoid, and target lesions.

 

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4. Page no 4.11- 4.13

questions.text: Which of the following is a non-parametric test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Friedman test

 

The Friedman test is a non-parametric test. It is used to test for differences between groups when the dependent variable being measured is ordinal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Student t test: Incorrect. The Student t-test is a parametric test used to compare the means of two groups based on quantitative data.

 

Option C. ANOVA: Incorrect. ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) is a parametric test used for comparing the means of more than two groups based on quantitative data.

 

Option D. Pearson: Incorrect. Pearson correlation is a parametric test used to measure the linear relationship between two continuous variables.

 

Educational Objective:


Understand that non-parametric tests, like the Friedman test, are used when data does not meet parametric assumptions, such as normal distribution or when data is ordinal. Parametric tests like the Student t-test, ANOVA, and Pearson correlation are used for quantitative data with assumptions of normality and equal variances.

questions.text: A neuron is receiving 400 inputs from 150 sensory neurons. This is an example of?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Convergence 

 

A single neuron receiving 400 inputs from 150 sensory neurons is an example of convergence.

 

Convergence means signals from multiple inputs unite to excite a single neuron. It can be categorized into two types:

 

  • Convergence from a single source
  • Convergence from multiple sources

 

The significance of convergence is that neurons are rarely excited by an action potential from just one input terminal. Instead, action potentials converging on the neuron from multiple terminals provide enough spatial summation to bring the neuron to the threshold required for discharge.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Divergence: Incorrect. Divergence refers to a single neuron sending its output to multiple target neurons, the opposite of convergence.

 

Option C Feedback inhibition: Incorrect. Feedback inhibition occurs when a neuron sends signals to inhibit its own activity, usually through an interneuron.

 

Option D Feedforward excitation: Incorrect. Feedforward excitation describes a chain of neurons in which one excites the next in a unidirectional sequence.

 

Educational Objective:


Convergence is a neural network phenomenon where multiple input signals from different sources come together to excite a single neuron, providing the spatial summation necessary for triggering an action potential. This mechanism is crucial for integrating information from various sensory inputs.

questions.text: The given condition is caused by which drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bleomycin

 

The given image shows flagellate dermatitis, which is caused by bleomycin.

 

Flagellate dermatitis presents as bands of pruritic, flagellate (whip-like) erythema over the trunk and extremities, appearing within a few hours to 6 months after bleomycin administration. The rash heals with persistent flagellate hyperpigmentation.

 

  • Management: No specific treatment is required as the lesions usually resolve once bleomycin is discontinued. If itching occurs, managing pruritus with an antihistamine may help to avoid further trauma and hyperpigmentation.
  • Another significant side effect of bleomycin to monitor is the development of pulmonary fibrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Actinomycin: Incorrect. Actinomycin is associated with various side effects but does not cause flagellate dermatitis.

 

Option C. Mitomycin C: Incorrect. Mitomycin C can cause cutaneous reactions but is not known for causing flagellate dermatitis.

 

Option D. Doxorubicin: Incorrect. Doxorubicin is associated with skin discoloration and other dermatologic reactions, but not flagellate dermatitis.

 

Educational Objective:


Flagellate dermatitis is a characteristic skin reaction caused by bleomycin, presenting as whip-like erythematous lesions that heal with hyperpigmentation. Clinicians should also be aware of bleomycin’s potential to cause pulmonary fibrosis.

choices.text: Dilated loops of intestine with plica circularis

questions.text: Which of the following is a finding of large bowel obstruction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dilated loops with haustrations

 

Dilated bowel loops with haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction.

 

In large bowel obstruction, the colon is distended proximally with the distal portion collapsed. The colon is considered dilated if it is more than 6 cm in diameter, while the cut-off for the caecum is 9 cm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dilated loops of intestine with plica circularis: Incorrect. Dilated loops of the intestine with plica circularis (valvulae conniventes) and central loops are features of small bowel obstruction. The small bowel is considered dilated if it is more than 3 cm in diameter.

 

Option C. String of pearls sign: Incorrect. The string of pearls sign is a feature of small bowel obstruction, seen on radiographs or CT. It indicates a row of gas bubbles trapped between the valvulae conniventes.

 

Option D. Central dilated bowel loops: Incorrect. Central dilated loops are characteristic of small bowel obstruction, not large bowel obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:


Large bowel obstruction is identified by dilated loops with haustrations. Understanding the differences in radiographic features between small and large bowel obstructions is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: In which of the following bags are latex gloves disposed of after use?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Red

 

Latex gloves are disposed of in a red-colored bag after use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yellow: Incorrect. Yellow bags are used for human anatomical waste and soiled waste like dressings, cotton swabs, and plaster casts contaminated with blood or body fluids.

 

Option C. Blue: Incorrect. Blue bags are used for glassware and metal implants in biomedical waste management.

 

Option D. Transparent: Incorrect. Transparent bags are not typically used for biomedical waste; they may be used for regular waste or in other non-hazardous contexts.

 

Educational Objective:


Proper disposal of biomedical waste is crucial for infection control and environmental safety. Latex gloves, after use, should be disposed of in a red bag, which is designated for items like contaminated plastic waste.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is diagnosed with a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) of the cervix and no obvious macroscopic growth. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Colposcopy and biopsy

 

In a woman diagnosed with a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL), the next step in management is to perform a colposcopy and biopsy.

 

Patients with HSIL are further evaluated using colposcopy, which involves visual inspection with acetic acid (VIA) to identify aceto-white areas and taking biopsies from any abnormal areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: Incorrect. Hysterectomy is not the immediate management for HSIL without macroscopic growth. It is considered in cases of invasive cancer or recurrent high-grade lesions when conservative management fails.

 

Option B. Conization: Incorrect. Conization may be considered if colposcopy and biopsy confirm significant dysplasia or carcinoma in situ. It is a treatment method, not the initial step.

 

Option D. Follow-up after 6 months: Incorrect. HSIL requires immediate evaluation, not delayed follow-up. Delay could increase the risk of progression to invasive cancer.

 

Educational Objective:


For HSIL, the immediate management is colposcopy and biopsy to assess the extent and severity of dysplasia. Prompt evaluation and intervention are essential to prevent the progression to invasive carcinoma.
